list.item: is a Depravation of the imagination and judgment, ariſing from a Tumultuary and diſorderly motion of the Animal Spirits; whereupon the Perſons Affected ſpeak ſeveral abſurd and incongruous things, the antecedent cauſe whereof lies either in the Blood, or in the Animal Spirits; there are ſeveral ſpecies of it: ſome who ſpeak little, ſome who dote in their talk; and not onely think, but ſpeak things ridiculous, ſtrange, magnificent, and malicious; others again really execute what they think, and that either with laughter, or in great earneſt: but all theſe orders of doting people, are reduced to certain deſtinctions.
list.label: Dejectio
list.item: is an Evacuation of the Excrements by the Periſtaltick Motion of the Guts.
list.label: Deleterium
list.item: is any Poyſonous Medicine.
list.label: Deligatio
list.item:
is a part of Chyrurgery that concerns the binding up of Wounds, Ulcers, broken Bones, &c. and it is either Simple or Compound. The Simple is either equal or unequal: the equal is onely round, which ſwathes the affected Member without any Declention to either ſide: the unequal is divided into Aſcia and Sima, which at leaſt differ upon the account of one being greater, and the other leſs; Aſcia declines little from a round,
but Sima much. There are a great many diſtinctions of Swathing, taken from the likeneſs of the parts which are ſwathed, or from certain Animals and other things.
list.label: Deliquium animi,
list.item: the ſame with Eclipſis.
list.label: Deliquium chymicum,
list.item: is a Diſtillation by the force of Fire: or a melting of the Calx which is ſuſpended in moiſt Cells, and a Reſolution of it into a Lixivious Humour.
list.label: Deltoides
list.item: is a Triangular Muſcle, like the Greek Δ, it proceeds from the Channel Bone, from the upper Proceſs of the Shoulder-blade, and from the Proceſs of the ſame, which is called Spiniforme, or like a Thorn; and being faſtned to the middle ſtrong Tendon of the Shoulder, lifts up the Shoulder it ſelf.
list.label: Denarius
list.item: is the Seventh part of an Ounce.
list.label: Dentarpaga,
list.item: ſee Forfex.
list.label: Dentes the Teeth,
list.item: are little bones of both Jaws faſtned one within another like ſo many Nails. Men are ſaid to have Thirty, and Women Twenty eight; as far as they appear above the Gums there's no Membrane about them; they grow continually, otherwiſe they would be worn out by daily grinding, they are not onely provided with Veins and Arteries, but with Nerves too; as the great pains which they are ſubject to, manifeſtly evince.
list.label: Dentiducum,
list.item: ſee Forfex.
list.label: Dentifricium
list.item: is a Medicine for whitening, ſcouring, and faſtning the Teeth, and for ſtrengthning the Gums.
list.label: Dentitio
list.item:
is the time that Children breed Teeth, which is about the ſeventh Month, or later; and
uſually the upper Teeth come firſt, in ſome the under; and amongſt theſe, the fore-teeth firſt: many times Fevers, Convulſions, Looſneſſes, &c. attend Children in the time of breeding Teeth.
list.label: Derivatio
list.item: is a means whereby blood that flows towards one part, but is not fixed there, is drawn away by a neighbouring part.
list.label: Derma,
list.item: the ſame with Cutis.
list.label: Deſcenſum, or per deſcenſum deſtillare;
list.item: See Delicquium.
list.label: Deſiccatio
list.item: is an Evaporation of ſuperfluous moiſtneſs by heat.
list.label: Deſtillatio
list.item: is an Extraction of the moiſt or unctuous parts, which are rarified into Miſt, or Smoak as it were, by the force of Fire. Diſtillation is performed by a Bladder, by the Chymical Inſtrument called Cucurbita, (before deſcribed) by a Retort, by Deliquium, by Filtre, by Deſcent; &c. and that either in Balneo Mariae, Sand, Vapours, Dung, the Sun, a Reverberatorie, &c.
list.label: Detergentia,
list.item: ſee Abſtergentia.
list.label: Deuteropathia
list.item: is a Diſeaſe that proceeds from another Diſeaſe; for Example, If the Head-ach from the Diſtemper of another part, the Morbific Matter being tranſlated thither from its former Repoſitorie.
list.label: Diabetes,
list.item:
ſo Galen calls it, and Agineta dipſacus, from the great Thirſt that attends it: and as others will have it, from a certain ſort of Serpent called Dipſacus, found eſpecially in Lybia, which Poyſons with its bite, and brings an unquenchable Thirſt upon the perſon Affected. It is a rare Diſtemper, which Galen ſays, he has ſeen but twice. The Famous Doctor J. Van Dueren, and I, obſerved
it once in a Reverend Paſtor of the Church; and it is too great a Fuſion of the Blood, whereupon the Serum, joyned with a violent Thirſt, paſſes the Reins, and is Excerned in great quantity by the paſſages of the Urine; it proceeds ordinarily from a too much exalted, or a too Acid Ferment in the Reins.
list.label: Diabroſis
list.item: is a ſolution of the Continuum, by eating out of parts.
list.label: Diacliſma
list.item: is a waſhing of the Mouth to cleanſe it, or to ſtrengthen the Teeth or Gums; the Waſhes are made of ſeveral Aſtringents, as of the Herbs Britannica, Tormentil, bark of Pomgranates, Galls, Allum, Flowres, or Bloſſoms of wild Pomgranates, &c.
list.label: Diacopraegia
list.item: is a Medicine made of Goats-dung, againſt Tumors in the Spleen, and Glandules behind the Ears, called Parotides.
list.label: Diacriſis
list.item: is a diſtinction and dijudication of Diſeaſes and Symptomes.
list.label: Diacritica,
list.item: ſee Diacriſis.
list.label: Diadoche
list.item: is a ſucceeding by a Criſis.
list.label: Diadoſis
list.item: is a diſtribution of Nouriſhment through all the parts.
list.label: Diaereſis
list.item:
is an Eating out, or conſuming of Veſſels, as Senertus ſays, when from ſome cutting corroding Cauſe, ſome ways and paſſages are made which naturally ought not to have been; or when ſome which really are, yet are dilated more than ordinary, ſo that the Humours which ought to have been contained in the Veſſels, run out. For firſt, a Diaereſis may be occaſioned by ſharp Humors which diſſolve the Unity, and cut away; which likewiſe ſharp Medicines will do, if they
conſiſt of thick parts; for thoſe of Minute parts are not Corroſive, becauſe they ſtick not long enough. Again, plenty of Humours may occaſion a Diaereſis, by diſtending and burſting the parts. Thirdly, There are ſeveral evident cauſes of a Diaereſis; to wit, all thoſe which by Contuſion and Stretching, do break the Unity of the Veſſels; ſuch as are Vehement Motion, Noiſe, great Weight, things that Wound, that Bruiſe, a Fall, a Leap, and the like; amongſt which, you may reckon Wind, which being long pent up, does ſometimes ſo forcibly diſtend the parts of the Body, that it does not onely Dilate the natural Cavities which contain it, but make new, when it breaks our, and diſſolves the Unity of the parts alſo; a Chyrurgical Operation, which either by Inciſion, Burning, Perforating, Shaving, Filing, Sawing, or Eating, ſolves the Continuity of parts.
list.label: Diaeta, Diet,
list.item:
is a method in ſound Perſons of living moderately; in Sick, a Remedy conſiſting in the right uſe of things neceſſary to life; and upon that account is either of a thick, moderate, or thin conſiſtence: the firſt is done by a good quantity of firm ſolid Meats, and ſuch as afford good nouriſhment; this ſort of Diet is called ſimply full, and was formerly made of whole Barleycorns husked and boyled, like Furmety: or it is more full and thick, which is done by Pullets fleſh, and poched Eggs: or it is most full, which allows of eating of things Gelt: that of a moderate conſiſtence, is which conſiſts of Meats of a moderate quantity and ſubſtance; this was formerly done by Bread ſopt in Pottage, or with young tender Fleſh: that of a thin conſiſtence is, which is done
by little Nouriſhment, and that thin and weak; which for the moſt part is agreeable in ſharp Diſeaſes: and this is Threefold, either ſimply weak, which was formerly done by the juice of Ptiſane: or more weak, when the Patient drunk Water and Honey boiled together: or weakeſt of all, when the Patient took no meat; but now-adays Diets are not ſo ſtrictly obſerved as formerly; eſpecially in theſe Countries.
list.label: Diaetetica
list.item: is a part of Phyſick that preſcribes the uſe and knowledge of Six things which are not Natural.
list.label: Diagnoſis
list.item: is the Knowledge of preſent ſigns: or a knowledge whereby we underſtand the preſent condition of a Diſtemper; and it is Threefold, either a right inſtigation of the part Affected, of the diſeaſe it ſelf, or of its Cauſe.
list.label: Dialeimma,
list.item: the ſame with Apyrexia.
list.label: Diapaſma,
list.item: according to Pliny, is a dry Medicine, made up of dry Powders, to be ſprinkled upon ſomething; as either upon Clothes to Pertume them, or upon Ulcers, and Wounds, ſeveral ways; or upon Drink, to make it more Delicious.
list.label: Diapedeſis
list.item: is an Eruption of the Blood, by reaſon of the thinneſs of the Veſſels.
list.label: Diaphanum
list.item: is that which is Tranſparent, as the Humors of the Eyes, the Tunica Cornea, &c.
list.label: Diaphoreſis, Sweating,
list.item: is a Perſpiration of all manner of Effluvia through the inviſible pores of the Body.
list.label: Diaphragma, or Septum Tranſverſum, and Diſſeptum,
list.item:
is a Tranſverſe Muſcle which ſeparates the Thorax or Cheſt from the Abdomen; in the middle it is Membranous; the Gullet, the great Arterie,
and the great hollow Vein, all paſs through it: it conduces to reſpiration with other Muſcles, and preſſing upon the Guts, helps forward the Secretion of the Excrements.
list.label: Diaphrattontes
list.item: are Membranes called Pleura, which cover the inſide of the Thorax, and leave a kind of partition in the middle, called Mediaſtinum.
list.label: Diaphthora
list.item: is a Corruption of any part of the Body.
list.label: Diaplaſis
list.item: is the ſetting of a Limb out of joynt.
list.label: Diaplaſma
list.item: is an Ointment or Fomentation.
list.label: Diapnoe,
list.item: the ſame with Diaphoreſis.
list.label: Diapyema,
list.item: the ſame with Empyema.
list.label: Diapyetica
list.item: are Medicines which ripen the Pus, or Craſs ſnotty Matter.
list.label: Diaria febris,
list.item: the ſame that Ephemera.
list.label: Diarrbaea
list.item: is a looſeneſs in the Belly which Ejects ſeveral Bilious, Pituitous, and other faeculent Excrements.
list.label: Diarthroſis
list.item: is a good conſtitution of the Bones, whereby they are apt to move eaſily and ſtrongly; ſuch as is in the Arm, Hands, Thigh, Foot, &c.
list.label: Diaſtole
list.item: is the Dilatation of the Heart, when the Blood flows into it, from the place where it is accended, the Lungs.
list.label: Diateretica
list.item: is part of the art of preſerving Health, which is various according to the Age and Conſtitution of Men.
list.label: Diatheſis
list.item: is the Natural or Praeternatural Diſpoſition of the Body, whereby we are inclined to perform all Natural Actions, ill or well.
list.label: Dichophyia
list.item: is a fault in the Hair, when it parts.
list.label: Dicrotus
list.item: is a Pulſe that beats twice.
list.label: Didymi
list.item: are twins.
list.label: Dies Critici,
list.item: ſee Critici dies.
list.label: Digaſtricus
list.item: is a double-bellied Muſcle, which ariſes from the Proceſs called mammiformis, or like a Teat, and ends in the inner middle part of the Chin, and draws it downwards.
list.label: Digerentia, or praeparantia,
list.item: are thoſe things which change the qualities of fermenting Heat, which reſiſt Action.
list.label: Digeſtio Chymica,
list.item: a Chymical Digeſtion, is when things are Digeſted by an Artificial heat, juſt as they are naturally in the Stomach.
list.label: Digestiva,
list.item: ſee Digerentia.
list.label: Dilatatio
list.item: is when any Paſſages or Receptacles in the Body are too much diſtended, as in Veins that ſwell with Melancholy, corrupt Blood in the Temples, Legs, &c.
list.label: Dilatatorium
list.item: is a Chyrurgeons Inſtrument wherewith the Womb or the Mouth is dilated or opened. It is called likewiſe Speculum, becauſe by it one may ſee into the Mouth, or Womb.
list.label: Dilutum,
list.item: the ſame with infuſio.
list.label: Dinus
list.item: the ſame with Vertigo.
list.label: Diota
list.item: is a Veſſel that ſurrounds a thing; ſo called from its Two Ears, which Environ both Arms, applyed to its ſides: its Inferior part is made like a Cupping-glaſs, upon which an Alembic is put, wherein there is a Channel at the top which ſerves to pour Liquor in and it has beſides two crooked Noſes conveniently placed, which convey the Condenſed Humor from the Head of the Inſtrument into the Cucurbite.
list.label: Dioptra
list.item:
is an Inſtrument whereby one may ſee
into the Matrix, otherwiſe called Dilatatorium, wherewith the Womb is dilated and enlarged in the extraction of a dead Faetus out of it, or in inſpecting any Ulcers that are in it.
list.label: Diplaſiaſmus
list.item: is a Reduplication of Diſeaſes: alſo Two Muſcles of the Arm, which ſerve to turn it about.
list.label: Diploe
list.item: is the lower thin plate or ſhell of the Scull: alſo a double Veſſel uſual with Chymiſts.
list.label: Diploma,
list.item: the ſame with Diploe: ſometimes it is taken for a complicated or folded cloth.
list.label: Dipſacus,
list.item: the ſame with Diabetes.
list.label: Diſlocatio,
list.item: the ſame with Luxatio.
list.label: Diſpenſatorium,
list.item: a Diſpenſatorie, is a Book uſeful for Apothecaries, wherein all Medicines, at leaſt the moſt uſual, are contained, and preſcribed; that they may be prepared in the Shops all the Year round.
list.label: Diſpoſitio
list.item: is an Habit whereby we are well or ill diſpoſed to perform an Action.
list.label: Diſſimilares partes,
list.item: Diſſimilar parts, are ſuch as can be divided into various parts different from one another; as the hand into Veins, Muſcles, Bones, &c.
list.label: Diſſolutio
list.item: is when Electuaries and Powders are mingled and diſſolved in water or a decoction.
list.label: Diſtentio
list.item: is when parts are puffed up, dilated, or relaxed by any thing, as the Guts by Wind, raiſed from Effervencies within them, whence Oppreſſions and Pains frequently proceed.
list.label: Diſtorſio
list.item: is when parts are ill placed, or ill figured.
list.label: Diſtributio Chyli,
list.item:
the Chyle is diſtributed when after a due fermentation in the Ventricle and the
Guts, it ſoaks into the little Teats in the Inteſtines (which Dr. Willis calls the Glandulous Tunic) and paſſing through the Lacteal Veins, and its proper Channel along the ſide of the Thorax, at laſt falls into the Subclavian Vein, that it may Circulate with the Blood, and receive its Colour.
list.label: Diſtricheaſis
list.item: is a double row of Hair on the Eye-lids.
list.label: Dieureſis,
list.item: is a Secretion of the Urine by the Reins; which is done after this manner: there are little Glandules placed near the Emulgent Arteries, wherewith the Serum is ſeparated from the Blood, and is conveyed by little Channels (of which the ſubſtance of the Reins does principally conſiſt) to the Carunculae Papillares, little Pappie pieces of Fleſh, thence to the Pelvis, the Baſin, thence to the Ureters, thence to the Bladder, and ſo out of Dores.
list.label: Diuretica,
list.item: are thoſe Medicines which by parting, diſſolving, and funding the Blood, do precipitate the Serum by the Reins to the Bladder.
list.label: Dodecadactylum
list.item: is the firſt of the ſmall Guts, beginning from the Pylorous of the Stomach, and ending where the Gut jejunum begins: it is ſo called, as if it were the length of Twelve Fingers, which yet is never obſerved in any men amongſt us; perhaps the Ancients miſtook from inſpecting the Guts of ſome Brutes.
list.label: Dogmatica Medicina,
list.item: or rational: Hippocrates was its firſt Author, and after him Galen; who both added reaſon to experience.
list.label: Dolor,
list.item: Pain, the ſame with Algema.
list.label: Dolor Nephriticus,
list.item: the ſame that Nephritis.
list.label: Dorſum, or Tergum,
list.item: the back, is the hinder part of the Thorax; The Dorſum, back, of the Hand or Foot, is their out-ſide.
list.label: Doſis
list.item: is a ſet quantity of Phyſick, or as much as is given at once.
list.label: Dothien
list.item: is an hard ſwelling, or puſh, as big as a Pigeons Egg, accompanied with a grievous Pain, and proceeding from thick Blood.
list.label: Dracunculus
list.item: is a Ulcer which eats through a Nerve it ſelf: alſo, a long ſort of Earth worm, white, plain, but not very broad; which frequently grows to Indians Legs.
list.label: Drachma,
list.item: a Dram, is the Eighth part of an Ounce, it contains three Scruples.
list.label: Drastica
list.item: are the moſt ready Medicines.
list.label: Dropaciſmus
list.item: is that wherewith all the External Members being extenuated, looſened, cold and moiſt, are anointed; and it is either Simple or Compound: the Simple is made of a little Pitch melted with Oyl: The Compound, beſides that, has Pepper, wild Pellitory, Brimſtone, and Roſemary-ſeed in it; and if there be occaſion for drying, they add Natural Brimstone, as it is digged out of the Earth, Salt, and the Aſhes of Vine-branches: but if it be to Vellicate, then you muſt add Euphorbium, (a Tree firſt found by King Juba) it is made up in different Forms; ſometimes like an Emplaſtrum, other times like a Cataplaſme.
list.label: Dropax,
list.item: the ſame that Dropaciſmus.
list.label: Ductus bilarius,
list.item: ſee Porus bilarius.
list.label: Ductus Chyliferus
list.item:
is a Veſſel, in the lower part whereof, all the Lacteal Veins, and many Lympheducts are terminated: it ariſes about the Glandule of the Kidney on the left ſide; and aſcending
along the Thorax near the great Arterie, ends at the Subclavian Vein on the left ſide; it is furniſhed with ſeveral Valves, that the Matter which aſcends by it, may not fall down again: betwixt the Fourth and Sixth Vertebre it is variouſly forked as Nature has been pleaſed to ſport. Its uſe is to convey the Chyle and the Lympha from the lower parts to the Heart.
list.label: Ductus pancreaticus,
list.item: is a little Channel which ariſes from the Pancreas or Sweet-bread, which is inſerted into the Guts near, or not far off the paſſage which conveys the Bile; it runs with a Lymphatic juice, which it diſcharges into the Gut Duodenum, to ferment and volatiſe the Meat from the Acid ferment of the Stomach, and the mixture of Gall: The Learned Dr. Graaf knew how to get a juice out of it, that was ſomething Acid; though other Phyſicians doubt of it, and of certain Diſeaſes which the Excellent Sylvius Attributes to the Efferveſcence of this Acid Pancreatic juice, with the Gall in the Duodenum. But we Affirm, That there is ſometimes an Acid juice found in it, and often a ſalt and auſtere; but frequently an inſipid volatile Liquor. See my Antomie Reformed. Chap. 11. l. 1.
list.label: Ductus Roriferus,
list.item: ſo the Noble Bilſius calls it; the ſame with Ductus Chyliferus.
list.label: Ductus Salivares, or Salivarii,
list.item: are paſſages which proceeding from the Maxilarie Glandules, goes as far as the Jaws and ſides of the Tongue, where they emit the juice we call Spittle, which conduces to the better chewing and ſwallowing of ſolid Meat, and ſomething to its Fermentation too.
list.label: Ductus Thoracicus,
list.item: ſee Ductus Chyliferus.
list.label: Ductus Umbilicalis,
list.item: ſee Funiculus.
list.label: Duodenum inteſtinum,
list.item: the ſame with Dodecadactylon.
list.label: Dura Mater,
list.item: ſee Mater Dura.
list.label: Dyſaeſtheſia
list.item: is a difficulty of, or fault in ſenſation.
list.label: Dyſcraſia
list.item: is an unequal mixture of Elements in the Blood, or Nervous Juice.
list.label: Dyſelces
list.item: is one who is troubled with Ulcers that are very hard to be Cured.
list.label: Dyſenteria
list.item: is a Looſneſs, accompanied with Gripings in the Belly, wherein bloody and purulent Excrements, and Membraneous pieces of the Inteſtines too are Excerned, always or very frequently attended with a continual Fever, and a Drought.
list.label: Dyſepulatica
list.item: are great Ulcers, beyond Cure.
list.label: Dyſodes
list.item: is any thing that ſwells ill, as Excrements.
list.label: Dyſorexia
list.item: is want of Appetite, proceeding from an ill diſpoſition of the Stomach.
list.label: Dyſpathia
list.item: is an Impatient Temper.
list.label: Dyſpepſia
list.item: is a difficulty of Digeſtion, or Fermentation in the Stomach and Guts, whereupon the Nouriſhment is often turned into Acidity, and ſmells ill.
list.label: Dyſphonia
list.item: is a difficulty of Speech, from an ill diſpoſition of the Organs.
list.label: Dyſphoria
list.item: is an Impatience in Suffering.
list.label: Dyſpnaea
list.item: is a difficulty of Breathing, which proceeds from vitiated, obſtructed, or irritated Organs.
list.label: Dyſtherapeuta,
list.item: are Diſeaſes of difficult Cure.
list.label: Dyſthimia
list.item: is a ſickneſs of the Mind.
list.label: Dyſtichia
list.item: is a double row of Hair on the Eyelids.
list.label: Dyſthriachiſis
list.item: is a continual defluction of Tears, from the pricking of Hairs in the Eye-lids, which grow under the Natural Hairs.
list.label: Dyſtocia
list.item: is a difficulty of bringing forth; or a preternatural Birth; as when the Faetus comes forth Obliquely, Tranſverſe, or with its Feet foremoſt; or when the Paſſages are ſtraitned by Inflamation, or otherwiſe; or when the Faetus is very large, weak, fat, or dead.
list.label: Dyſtrichiaſis
list.item: is when the Hairs grow inverſe.
list.label: Dyſuria
list.item: is a difficulty of Urine, proceeding from an ill diſpoſition of the Organs, or from an Obſtruction of them by the Stone, Gravel, or Viſcous Clammy Humours, accompanied with an heat of the Urine.

list.head: E.
list.label: ECbolica
list.item: are Medicines which help the Delivery in hard Labour. Alſo Medicines which cauſe Abortions.
list.label: Eccathartica,
list.item: ſee Cartharticum.
list.label: Ecchyloma,
list.item: the ſame with Extractum.
list.label: Ecchymoma
list.item: ſignifies Marks, and Spots in the Skin, from the Extravaſation of Blood.
list.label: Ecchymoſis,
list.item: the ſame with Ecchymoma.
list.label: Eccope,
list.item: the ſame with Extirpatio.
list.label: Ecchoprotica,
list.item: the ſame with Catharticum.
list.label: Eccrimocritica
list.item: are ſigns from particular Excretions.
list.label: Eccriſis
list.item: is a Secreſion of Excrements.
list.label: Eclegma, or Linctus,
list.item: which the Arabians call Loch, and Lohoch; others Illinctus, is a Medicine applyed inwardly, of a middle conſiſtence, between a Syrup and an Opiate, made up of ſeveral Pectorals againſt the Diſtempers of the Throat, and the Lungs.
list.label: Eclipſis
list.item: is a Defection of Spirit.
list.label: Eclyſis
list.item: is when the ſtrength is a little decayed, proceeding from a want of ſufficient warmth, and ſpirits in the Body.
list.label: Ecphracticum
list.item: is a Medicine good againſt Obſtructions.
list.label: Ecphraxis
list.item: is a taking away of Obſtructions in any part, by opening cutting Medicines.
list.label: Ecphyſeſis
list.item: is a breathing thick.
list.label: Ecphyſis
list.item: is a Proceſs that coheres with the Bone.
list.label: Ecpieſma
list.item: is a juice ſqueezed out: alſo dregs which remain of any thing that is ſqueezed: likewiſe a fracture of the Scull, wherein the broken parts preſs upon the Meninges or Skins of the Brain.
list.label: Ecpieſmus
list.item: is a very great Protuberance of the Eyes.
list.label: Ecplexis
list.item: is a fright or Stupor.
list.label: Ecpneumatoſis,
list.item: ſee Exſpiratio.
list.label: Ecptoſis,
list.item: the ſame that Luxatio.
list.label: Ecpuctica
list.item: are condenſing Medicines, ſee Incraſſantia.
list.label: Ecpyema,
list.item: the ſame with Empyema.
list.label: Ecpyeſis,
list.item: ſee Ecpyema.
list.label: Ecrythmus
list.item: is a Pulſe which obſerves no method, nor Number incident to any age.
list.label: Ecſtaſis,
list.item: an Ecſtaſie, is a commotion of the Mind: alſo a dimotion of any thing from the ſtate wherein it was, into another.
list.label: Ecthlimma
list.item: is an Ulceration ariſing from a violent compreſſion in the Surface of the Skin.
list.label: Ecthymata
list.item: are Pimples, or certain breakings out in the Skin, as the ſmall Pox, &c.
list.label: Ecthymoſis
list.item: is a Commotion and Intumeſcencie of the Blood: alſo a chearfulneſs of mind.
list.label: Ectillotica
list.item: are Medicines which conſume Callous parts, and pull out hairs.
list.label: Ectropium
list.item: is a growing of the Eye-lids, when the lower is ſhorter than the upper.
list.label: Eczemata
list.item: are red hot, and burning Pimples; ſome take Hydroa for Eczema, but 'tis a miſtake.
list.label: Efferveſcentia
list.item: is an Inteſtine Motion of Particles of different nature and qualities, tending to ſudden Deſtruction; ſometimes attending with heat, and a flame, as in unquenched Lime, Hay laid up moiſt, Chymical mixtures, &c.
list.label: Egeſtio,
list.item: the ſame with Dejectio.
list.label: Elaſtica vis,
list.item: is an Exploſion of Animal Spirits, as is frequent in Cramps, Convulſions: alſo an Inteſtine Commotion of the Air.
list.label: Elaterium
list.item: is the Juice of wild Cucumbers made up in a thick and hard conſiſtence: alſo any Medicine that purges the Belly.
list.label: Elctica,
list.item: ſee Attrahentia.
list.label: Elcus,
list.item: ſee Helcus.
list.label: Electuarium
list.item:
is a Confection of Simple Ingredients, Paps or Pithes, Gums mixed with Syrup, or Honey, of a Conſiſtence like a Conſerve; and it is either Simple, or Compound; the Simple conſiſts onely of the Pith of Caſſia, Tamarinds, or Pruines; but the Compound, for the moſt part of ſeveral Simple Ingredients, Pulps, condenſated Juices, Gumms, &c. made up with Honey or Syrup.
Electuaries are Digeſtive, Looſning, Purging, Strengthning, Alexipharmic, &c.
list.label: Elementa, or Principia,
list.item: are the Simpleſt Bodies that can be, which are neither made of one another, nor of any thing elſe, of which all things are made, and into which they are ultimately reſolved. There are Five Elements, Spirit, Salt, Sulphur, Water, and Earth; the two laſt whereof are called Paſſive, the reſt Active. Others reckon Three only, Salt, Sulphur, and Mercury; but not ſo well. The Peripateticks reckon Four, Fire, Air, Water, and Earth. Carteſius ſuppoſes a Firſt Matter, a Second, and a Third; but all thoſe Elements are compounded of others; wherefore to ſay, that any thing conſiſts thereof, is as if one ſhould ſay, That a Tree is compounded of a Root, Trunc, Branches, Leaves, Flowers, &c.
list.label: Eleoſaccharum,
list.item: is nothing but Diſtilled Oyl, mixed with Sugar.
list.label: Elephantiaſis Arabum,
list.item:
of which the Greeks ſpeak nothing, but the Arabians do frequently, is a kin to a varix, or crooked ſwelling in the Veins; and proceeds from thence, and is only a Tumor in the Feet. Avicenna Treats of this Diſtemper, where he ſpeaks of the varices: yet Rhaſes differs from him, and Haly Abbas follows the Greeks; who ſays, That an Elephas is a Diſeaſe, which corrupts all the Members of the Body, and is as it were an Univerſal Cancre: but neither is he conſiſtent with himſelf when he Writes, That Ulcers in the Legs and Feet are called Elephas; and that Elephanticus Morbus is an Apoſthume proceeding from Melancholy, in the Legs and Feet: and a ſign of it, is that the ſhape of the Foot is like the figure of an
Elephant. All the reſt Treat ſeparately of a Leproſy, and an Elephantia, and make the latter to be a ſwelling of the Feet, proceeding from Melancholy and Pituitous Blood, and the crooked ſwelling of the Veins, whereby the Feet reſemble the Feet of an Elephant in ſhape and thickneſs, and this ſort of Tumor is often ſeen in Beggars who wander much.
list.label: Elephantiaſis Grecorum,
list.item:
which the Arabians call a Leproſie: it is called alſo Elephas, Elephantiaſis, and Elephantia, from an Elephant; as ſome think, becauſe it makes People big like an Elephant: which is a fooliſh notation of the Word; for the Body is no bigger, though the Diſeaſe be. Others think it ſo called, becauſe the Diſtemper lying in the Legs, makes them ſtiff and equal, like an Elephant: or becauſe 'tis a ſtrong vehement Diſeaſe like an Elephant; with ſuch like ſtuff. Galen in his Fourteenth Chapter of Tumors ſays, That this Diſeaſe is called Saturiaſmus, when it firſt begins, becauſe it makes the face like that of a Satyr. For the Lips are thick, the Noſe ſwells, the Ears decays, the Jaws are red, the Forehead is ſet with Tumours, like ſo many horns. Though others think it is called Saturiaſmus, becauſe the Perſons Affected are much inclined to Leachery at the beginning, as Satyrs are. Celſus Deſcribes it thus, The whole Body, ſays he, is ſo affected, that the very bones may be ſaid to be Corrupted: the upper parts of the Body are full of Spots and Tumours, the Redneſs whereof is gradually turned into Black: the top of the Skin is unequally Thick, Thin, Hard, Soft, Rough, as if it had Scales on it; the Body decays, the Bone, Calves of the Legs, and Feet ſwell: when the Diſeaſe is old and
inveterate, the Toes and Fingers are hid in the ſwelling, and a ſmall Fever ariſes which eaſily conſumes a man loaden with ſo many Infirmities.
list.label: Elevator,
list.item: the ſame with Elevatorium.
list.label: Elevatorium,
list.item: ſo called from lifting up, is a Chyrurgions Inſtrument wherewith Sculls that are depreſſed are raiſed up again.
list.label: Elixir,
list.item: ſo called from the Arabic Word Elecſchir, or Elieſchir, or Eleſchus; is the Eſſence of any thing Extracted with the Spirit of Wine, or ſomething of that Nature; it is the ſame that a Tincture.
list.label: Elminthes
list.item: are little Worms bred in the Guts; eſpecially that called Rectum, the lowermoſt.
list.label: Elodes
list.item: is a continual Fever, wherein the Patients are almoſt melted through moiſture.
list.label: Elythroides, or Vaginalis,
list.item: is the ſecond proper Tunic which mediately involves the Teſticles.
list.label: Embrocatio,
list.item: the ſame that Embroche.
list.label: Embrocha,
list.item: the ſame that Embroche.
list.label: Embroche,
list.item:
an irregulation, or inſtillation, is a ſort of Fomentation, when a Liquor is diſtilled from on high, like Rain, upon a part, which is either done by a Veſſel with a Noſe that inclines, or by diſtillation, or out of an Ewer. Firſt, it is uſed in Diſtempers of the Brain, where the Liquor is firſt poured upon the Suturs called Coronalis, and is permitted to run by that called Sagittalis. Secondly, it is applyed to the top of the Spinal Marrow, in Diſeaſes of the Nerves, and is permitted to run down the whole ridge of the Back. Thirdly, it is uſed to warm or dry the Ventricle, and the Liquor is ſuffered to run through the whole Abdomen; and if the Bowels be weak, they apply
a Sear-cloth of Santalum (ſome Engliſh it Sanders) to the Liver, when they apprehend it may be over-heated. The matter whereof theſe Embroches are made in common Bathe water, a Decoction, Milk, and Oyl, according as the Diſtemper of the part, and neceſſity require.
list.label: Embryon
list.item: is the Rudiment of a Child in the Womb.
list.label: Embryatomia
list.item: is an Anatomical Diſſection of a Faetus.
list.label: Emetica or Vomitoria,
list.item: are Medicines which with their Pungent Particles contract the Fibres of the Stomach upwards, and ſo Eject at the Mouth whatſoever is offenſive to the Stomach; they are made of Decoctions, Tinctures, and Infuſions, &c. and therefore for the moſt part are Liquid.
list.label: Emetologia
list.item: is a deſcription of things that provoke Vomiting.
list.label: Emmenagoga
list.item: are Medicines which excite the Courſes.
list.label: Emmoton
list.item: is a Liquid Medicine, which is injected into Ulcers, with a little Inſtrument which they uſe in Wounds, faſhioned like a Man's Yard.
list.label: Emollientia,
list.item: ſoftning things, are ſuch as with a moderate heat and moiſture, diſſolve the parts, which before cohered cloſe, and diſſipating others, make them looſe and ſoft.
list.label: Empaſma,
list.item: the ſame with Catapaſma.
list.label: Emphraxis
list.item: is Obſtruction in any part.
list.label: Emphractica,
list.item: the ſame with Emplattomena.
list.label: Emphyſema
list.item: is an Inflamation, proceeding from an Effervencie, or otherwiſe.
list.label: Emphyton Thermon,
list.item:
is the innate heat, or heat
firſt ſown in the Faetus from the Parents Seed, which afterwards, when Reſpiration is begun, and the Faetus ſubſiſts of it ſelf, decays by degrees. Both Philoſophers and Phyſitians call this heat an innate and native Spirit, and ſay that it conſiſts of Three parts, of a primogenial moiſture, an innate Spirit and Heat. Whence Fernelius defines innate heat, to be a primogenial moiſture every way qualified with an innate ſpirit and heat: but theſe toys of the Ancients are nothing to us; for 'tis certain, that Heat belongs onely to new-born creatures.
list.label: Empirica Medicina,
list.item: quacking, is Curing the Sick by gueſs, without reaſon. Acron Agrigentinus was the firſt Author of it, who neglecting the reaſons of things, contented himſelf with bare Experience. Quacks firſt flouriſhed amongſt the Aegyptians; from this Trade came Mountebanks.
list.label: Emplaſtica,
list.item: the ſame with Emplattomena.
list.label: Emplaſtrum a Plaiſter,
list.item: is a Medicine applyed outwardly to the skin, ſpread upon Linnen, or Leather; it is commonly made of Oyls, or of thoſe things which are of a like conſiſtence with Oyl; as Swines-greaſe, Butter, Slimie viſcous extractions from Gums, Roots, &c. alſo of Powders and Wax, or thoſe things which are of a like conſiſtence with Wax; as Roſin, Pitch, Gum, &c. the Maſs whereof being yet hot, is formed into a Cylindriacal Figure.
list.label: Emplattomena, or Emplastica,
list.item: are Salves which ſo conſtipate and ſhut up the pores of the Body, that Sulphureous Vapours cannot paſs.
list.label: Empneumatoſis
list.item:
is an alternate dilatation of the Cheſt, whereby the Nitrous Air is continually breathed in, and by the Wind-pipe, and its Bladdery
parts is communicated to the Blood to accend it: but if we inſpect the matter narrowly, Inſpiration does not ſeem to depend principally upon the Thorax, but upon the contraction of the Membrane which covers the Wind-pipe, the upper part of the Gullet, and the Noſtrils; for take this away, and you take away the motion of the Cheſt, the Lungs, and the Abdomen.
list.label: Emproſthotonos
list.item: is the continual Contraction of the Muſcles of the Neck towards the fore-parts.
list.label: Empyema,
list.item: properly ſo called, is a Collection of Purulent Matter in the Cavity of the Thorax; but largely taken, ſignifies the ſame in the Abdomen too.
list.label: Empyreumata
list.item: are little Feveriſh remains after a Criſis: alſo that thick Viſcous Matter which ſubſides to the bottom in Diſtilled Waters.
list.label: Emulgentia vaſa
list.item: are the Arteries and Veins which paſs under the Reins.
list.label: Emulſio,
list.item: an Emulſion is a Medicine to be Drunk, made of the Kernel of ſome Seeds, infuſed in a convenient Liquor.
list.label: Emuncteria
list.item: are Cavities into which ſomething is emptied, as the Pituitous Humour of the Brain into the Noſtrils; the yellow thickiſh Humour, which we call Ear-wax, into the Ears, the Excrements into the Bowels; the Urine into the Bladder, &c.
list.label: Enarthroſis
list.item: is joynting, when the Cavitie that receives is deep, and the head of the bone that's inſerted is Oblong; as may be ſeen in the Hucclebone, and its Cavitie; in the principal Bone of that part of the Foot which immediatly ſucceeds the Leg, with the Bone call'd Cymbiforme, or like a Boat.
list.label: Enaemen
list.item:
is a Medicine which ſtops the Blood, or which by binding, cooling, or drying, cloſes the paſſages
of the Veſſels which were open, ſtops or diminiſhes the fluidity and violent Motion of the Blood.
list.label: Enaeorema
list.item: is that craſs Subſtance which is ſuſpended in the middle of Urines.
list.label: Encanthis
list.item: is the Caruncula Lachrymalis, or an Excreſcence & Swelling of the inner angles of the eye.
list.label: Encathiſma,
list.item: the ſame with Inſeſſus.
list.label: Encephalos
list.item: is whotſoever is within the compaſs of the Scull: as the Brain, the Cerabellum, the Oblongated Marrow, &c.
list.label: Encharaxis,
list.item: ſee Scarificatio.
list.label: Encheireſis Anatomica,
list.item: is a readineſs in Diſſections; when an Anatomiſt ſhews the parts of a Carcaſe dexterouſly.
list.label: Enchymoma
list.item: is an Afflux of the Blood, whereby the External parts are rendred black and blew; as in the Scurvey, Blood ſhot Eyes, &e. alſo an Afflux of Blood, by the quickneſs and ſuddenneſs of its Motion, as in Anger and Joy.
list.label: Enchyta
list.item: is an Inſtrument wherewith Liquids are inſtilled into the Eyes, Noſtrils, or Ears.
list.label: Enclyſma,
list.item: the ſame that Clyſter.
list.label: Encope
list.item: is an Inciſion of any part, as in a Gangrene.
list.label: Encranium,
list.item: the ſame that Cerebellum.
list.label: Endeixis
list.item: is an indication of Diſeaſes, whereby is ſhown what is to be done: as for Example, a Plethora, too much fullneſs of blood, indicates the opening of a Vein.
list.label: Endemius, or Morbus Vernaculus, and Communis,
list.item: is a Diſeaſe which always infects a great many in the ſame Country, proceeding from ſome cauſe peculiar to the Countrey where it reigns. Such is Scurvie to the Hollanders.
list.label: Endemus,
list.item: the ſame with Endemius.
list.label: Enema,
list.item: the ſame with Clyſter.
list.label: Energia
list.item: is an agitation or operation of the Animal Sp • rits and Blood.
list.label: Engizoma
list.item: is a blow upon the Skull, wherewith the bone deſcends to the inner Membrane of the Brain, and preſſes upon it. Alſo an Inſtrument which we uſe in ſuch like caſes.
list.label: Engonios
list.item: is the bending of the Arm or Leg.
list.label: Enſiſormis Cartilago
list.item: is the loweſt part of the Breſt bone, pointed like a Sword.
list.label: Entera
list.item: are long Membraceous Winding-pipes, annexed to the Meſenterie, that they be not confounded with one another; and they are ſix (unleſs you reckon the Gullet, the Stomach, and the Bladder amongſt the Inteſtines, which I ſhould not ſtand upon, ſince they have the ſame ſubſtance, and almoſt the ſame action) the Gut Duodenum, Jejunum, Ileum, Caecum, Colon, and the Rectum; the Three uppermoſt are called ſmall Guts, the lower great Guts, they are clothed with Four Tunics; the outermoſt is Membranous, which ariſes from the Paeritoneum: The Second is Fibrous or Fleſhie, whoſe Exteriour Fibres are long, the Interior round, placed upon one another at Right Angles: The Third is Nervous, and contains the meetings of both Lacteal and Sanguinarie Veſſels, to which there inwardly adheres a Fourth Tunic, which is Glandulons, or rather of a pappie Subſtance, whereby the Chyle is imbibed and communicated to the Milkie Veins. The Inteſtines, for the moſt part are about ſix times as long as the Man whoſe they are. Some take Lactes to ſignifie the ſmall Guts only; others take them for fat Guts, as particularly Perſius.
list.label: Enterenchyta
list.item: is a Clyſter-pipe, which is alſo called Siphon, and Syringa.
list.label: Enterocele, or Hernia Inteſtinalis
list.item: is the fall of the Inteſtines, eſpecially of the Ileum, through the Proceſſes of the Peritoneum Dilated, into the Groins or outer skin that covers the Cods.
list.label: Epacmaſtica
list.item: is a Fever that continually grows ſtronger.
list.label: Epaphaereſis
list.item: is an iterated Phlebotomie.
list.label: Epar,
list.item: ſee Hepar.
list.label: Eparmata
list.item: are Tumors of the Glandules called Parotes, behind the Ears.
list.label: Ephaebeum
list.item: is the place from the Hypogaſtrium, or lower part of the Abdomen, to the Secret Parts.
list.label: Ephelſcis
list.item: is that Bloody ſubſtance which is brought up in ſpitting of Blood: alſo a ſhell or cruſt that is brought over Ulcers.
list.label: Ephelis
list.item: is a dewie Spot, we call it a Freckle, which proceeds moſt commonly from Sun burn; they grow eſpecially in Spring and Summer, and chiefly in thoſe who have very thin Skins; but about Winter they diſappear again: they are about as big as Flea-bites, and often disfigure the whole face.
list.label: Ephemera, or Diaria,
list.item: is a continued Fever which laſts but a day, ariſing from a Commotion and Accenſion of the fine parts of the Blood: if it laſt above a day, it is called Synochus Simplex.
list.label: Ephialtes, or Incubus,
list.item:
the Night-mare, is a depraved Imagination, whereby people aſleep fancie that their Wind-pipe is oppreſſed by ſome ſuperincumbent body, that their breath is ſtop'd, and they are excited to Venerie: this proceeds from a compreſſion of the Cerebellum, when the
Ventricles are too full of moiſture: or, if thoſe who are thus Affected lye upon their backs, then the whole bulk of the Brain lies upon the Cerebellum, whereupon all the Pores and Paſſages being ſtopped by ſo much weight, the Spirits are hindred from Influencing the Nerves, called par vagum, and the Intercoſtal Nerve, which being thus deſtitute of Spirits, the Lungs are oppreſſed, and flag, and cannot perform their Office.
list.label: Ephidroſis
list.item: is Sweating.
list.label: Ephippium, or Sella Equina, or Turſica,
list.item: is part of the Bone Sphenoides, wherein the Pituitarie Glandulae is placed.
list.label: Epiala
list.item: is a continued Fever, wherein the Patient feels both Heat and Cold at once.
list.label: Epialtes,
list.item: the ſame with Ephialtes.
list.label: Epicarpium
list.item: is a Medicine applyed outwardly, like a Plaiſter or a Cataplaſme, applied to the Pulſe or Wriſt of the hand to drive away intermitting Feavers.
list.label: Epicauma
list.item: is a Cruſtie Ulcer that ſometimes happens to the black of the Eye.
list.label: Epiceraſtica
list.item: are Medicines which obtund and temperate ſharp Humours.
list.label: Epicheireſis,
list.item: the ſame with Encheireſis.
list.label: Epicolicae regiones, or Laterales, or Lumbares.
list.item: Gliſſon calls that part Epicolica which lyes upon the parts of the Gut Colon: whence it has its Name.
list.label: Epicraſis
list.item: is a gradual Evacuation of ill Humors in the Bood.
list.label: Epicriſis
list.item: is a judging of a Diſeaſe.
list.label: Epicruſis
list.item: is a percuſſion of the ſoft parts, with light Ferula's, an uſual Cuſtome amongſt the Japaneſes.
list.label: Epicyema
list.item: is a Superfaetation, which rarely happens.
list.label: Epidemius
list.item: is a common Diſeaſe, proceeding from a common Cauſe, ſpreading it ſelf over divers Countries, at divers times; ſuch are the Plague, Malignant Fevers, &c. the reaſon is, that the Nitre of the Air, with other particles that are in it, acquire the Vertue of an Arcenic, or a Sublimate, as we ſee in making Sublimates; for the Particles of which that conſiſts, if they be given ſeverally, are not ſo deſtructive; but taken together, they make a deadly Poyſon.
list.label: Epidermis,
list.item: ſee Cuticula.
list.label: Epedeſis
list.item: is the Injection of a Ligament, to ſtop the Blood.
list.label: Epideſmus
list.item: is a tying of Swathes underneath.
list.label: Epididymis, or Pariſtata, in Latin Supergeminalis,
list.item: and it is a winding Veſſel, making a Figure like the winding of crooked Veſſels that are ſwoln with ill Blood, and is affixed to the back of the Teſticles: its greater Globe is annexed to the Teſticles, conſiſting of one Veſſel or Paſſage above five Ells long: the leſſer Globe is connected to the Veſſel that carries the Seed.
list.label: Epigaſtrium
list.item: is the fore-part of the lowermoſt Belly, whoſe upper part is called Hypochondrium; the middle part Umbilicalis; and the lowermoſt Hypogaſtrium.
list.label: Epigennema
list.item: is that which happens to a Diſeaſe like a Symptome: alſo the order of parts in Generation, which is done ſucceſſively.
list.label: Epigineſis,
list.item: the ſame that Epiginema.
list.label: Epiglottis
list.item: is the Fifth Cartilage of the Larynx, the cover of the opening of the Wind-pipe: it is alſo, called Sublinguium.
list.label: Epigonatis
list.item: is the Whirl-bone of the Knee.
list.label: Epilepſia, or Morbus Caducus,
list.item: becauſe that the perſons Affected fall down on a ſudden: or Herculeus, becauſe it is hard to be cured; alſo Lues Deifica, Sonticus, Comitialis, Sacer, &c. and it is an Interpolated Convulſion of the whole body, which hurts all Animal-Actions, proceeding from an Exploſion of Animal Spirits in the Brain, whereby the perſons Affected are ſuddenly caſt upon the ground. This Exploſion ariſes either from an irritation or pricking in the Spirits: or when ſomething Heterogeneous is intermixed with the Animal Spirits.
list.label: Epilogiſmus
list.item: is the Vote of Phyſitians.
list.label: Epinyctides
list.item: are Pimples that ſend forth matter, and are painful, eſpecially in the Night.
list.label: Epiparoxiſmus
list.item: is when a Patient endures more Fits in a Fever than uſual, which happens in inordinate Fevers.
list.label: Epiphaenomena
list.item: are ſigns which appear afterwards in Diſeaſes.
list.label: Epiphiſis, Appendix, Adnaſcentia, Additamentum,
list.item: ſignifie one Bone that grows to another by ſimple and immediate Contiguity, though not with ſo even a Surface, but with ſome kind of ingreſs of one Bone into the Cavitie of the other, like that Coarticulation wherewith the Bones form the Joynts, but without any Motion.
list.label: Epiplaſma,
list.item: the ſame with Cataplaſma.
list.label: Epiplocele
list.item: is a Rupture when the Cavile falls into the outward Skin of the Cods.
list.label: Epiplocomiſtae
list.item:
are fat big-bellied Men, who have fat huge Cawls; which Writers ſay, has ſometimes hindred Conception in Women; and therefore
they are named Cawl-bearers.
list.label: Epiplomphalum
list.item: is a Navel Rupture, when it juts out by reaſon of a ſwoln Cawl that is fallen down.
list.label: Epiploon, Omentum, or Reticula,
list.item: the Cawl, is a cover ſpread over the Inteſtines, ariſing from the bottom of the Ventricle, and the back of the Gut Colon; to wit, from the doubling of the Peritonaeum; it is ſhaped like a Net, or a Fowlers Bag; and abounds with ſeveral Sanguinary Veſſels. Its uſe is to cheriſh the Stomach, and the Guts with its fat.
list.label: Epiſarcidium,
list.item: the ſame with Anaſarca.
list.label: Epiſemaſia
list.item: is the very time that a Diſeaſe firſt ſeizes a Perſon, and is properly called Significatio.
list.label: Epiſion
list.item: is the place of the Secret Parts, or Aqualiculus.
list.label: Epiſphaerid
list.item: are windings and turnings in the outer ſubſtance of the Brain, that the Sanguiferous Veſſels may paſs more ſecurely.
list.label: Epiſpaſtica,
list.item: the ſame with Attrahentia.
list.label: Epiſtomia
list.item: are the utmoſt gapings and meetings of Veſſels.
list.label: Epiſtropheus, or Cardo,
list.item: is the ſecond Vertebre of the Neck; ſo called from turning, becauſe the Head turns upon it.
list.label: Epithema
list.item: is a Medicine applyed outwardly to the more Noble parts of the body, eſpecially to the Heart and Liver.
list.label: Epneumatoſis,
list.item: the ſame that Expiratio.
list.label: Epomis
list.item: is the upper part of the Shoulder, called alſo Acronium.
list.label: Epomphalum
list.item:
is a Plaiſter, or any ſuch thing applyed
to the Protuberances of the Navel.
list.label: Epſema
list.item: is a Decoction of new Wine till half be boyled away.
list.label: Epulis
list.item: is an Excreſcence in the Gums which reaches the fartheſt Axel-Teeth; ſo that it hinders the opening of the Mouth.
list.label: Epulotica
list.item: the ſame with Cicatrizantia.
list.label: Erodentia
list.item: are Medicines which gnaw and prey upon the Fleſh, with their Acute Particles.
list.label: Erpes,
list.item: ſee Herpes.
list.label: Errhinum,
list.item: barbarouſly called Naſale, is a Medicine which being made like a Pyramid, is put up the Noſtrils, and cleanſes the Brain of Viſcous Humours, eſpecially without ſneezing: and it is either Liquid, Soft, or Solid. The Liquid is made of the juices of Cephalic cleanſing Herbs, Extracted by Wine or other Liquor, to which Spirit of Wine is ſometimes added. Or of a Decoction of-fit Simples, to which are added ſometimes Juices, Honey, Syrup, and Powders too. The ſoft is made of Powders, with Honey, Oyl, or Juices, boiled to a kind of Ointment. The Solid, is given either in form of a Powder, and that has place eſpecially in Medicines which provoke ſneezing; or in form of a Pellet, and it is called Naſale, and is prepared of fit Powders mixed with Viſcid Extractions from Seeds, Gums, Roots, &c. with Wax, or with Turpentine.
list.label: Eryſipelas, Wild-fire,
list.item:
is a ſwelling in the Skin, or any other Fleſhie or Membraneous part, red, broad, not ſpreading high, nor beating, but attended with a pricking ſort of a pain, ariſing from a ſharp, and frequently a Sulphureous Blood. I take the cauſe of it not to be the Blood, but a
ſerous ſweating, which is ſharp and ſulphureous, and flows from the Fibres themſelves.
list.label: Eryſipelatodes
list.item: is a ſwelling like an Eryſipelas, or a baſtard Eryſipelas.
list.label: Erythremata
list.item: are red ſpots like Flea-bites, common in Peſtilential Fevers.
list.label: Erythroides
list.item: is a red Membrane of the Teſticles, the firſt of the proper Tunlcs.
list.label: Eſchara
list.item: is a cruſt or ſhell brought over an Ulcer, or ralſed with a Seering Iron.
list.label: Eſcharoticum
list.item: is a Seering Iron, Fire, or the like, which burns the Skin and Fleſh into a cruſtie Subſtance.
list.label: Eſſentia,
list.item: Eſſence, in acurate ſpeaking ſignifies the Balſamic part of any thing ſeparated from the thicker matter, ſo that when ever this is done by means of Extraction, the Balſamic part is called Eſſence by way of Eminence; otherwiſe ſometimes, thickned juices are called Eſſences. But 'tis better to call theſe by their own Name, to avoid Confuſion. Some call Compounds of Oyl and Sugar, Eſſences: but it is an abuſe of the word.
list.label: Eſſentia Quinta, Quinteſſence,
list.item: is a Medicine made of the entire Energetical and Active Particles of its Ingredients.
list.label: Eſſere, Sora, & Sare,
list.item: they are little Puſhes or Wheals, ſomething red and hard, which quickly Infect the whole Body with a violent itching, as if one were ſtung with Bees, or Waſps, or Flies, or Nettles; yet they vaniſh after a little time, and leave the Skin as ſmooth and well-coloured as before. This Diſeaſe differs from an Epinyctis in this, that an Epinyctis Sweats out Matter; but an Eſſere does not.
list.label: Eſthiomenos
list.item: is a Winding Inflamation that conſumes the parts: it proceeds from this, that the little Pappie Subſtance of the Skin, keeps a certain ſharp Humour in it, which for want of Perſpiration, corrupts and gnaws not onely the Skin with its Acrimonie, but the parts which are under it.
list.label: Ethmoides
list.item: is the Bone which reſembles a Sieve, placed above the inner part of the Noſe, and full of little holes to receive the Serous and Pituitous Humours from the ſoft Pappie Proceſſes of the Brain.
list.label: Evacuatio, Evacuation,
list.item: is either of the Blood, when it abounds too much, as in a Plethora, where opening a Vein is requiſite. Or of ill Humours in the Blood, and the Primae Viae, as they call them, which is done by Purging or Vomiting.
list.label: Euchroa
list.item: is a good colour and temper of the Skin.
list.label: Euchymia
list.item: is an excellent temper of the Blood.
list.label: Eucraſia
list.item: is an excellent temper of the parts of the Body.
list.label: Euectica,
list.item: the ſame with Gymnaſtica, or that part of Phyſick which teaches how to acquire a good Habit of Body.
list.label: Euelces,
list.item: one that is troubled with Ulcers, eaſie to be cured.
list.label: Euexia
list.item: is a good ſound Habit of Body.
list.label: Eugeos
list.item: is the Womb; ſo called from its Analogie to fruitful Ground; the Hymen is alſo ſo called.
list.label: Euodes
list.item: is a ſweet ſmell of Excrements.
list.label: Euoſma,
list.item: the ſame with Euodes.
list.label: Eupathia
list.item: is an eaſineſs in ſuffering.
list.label: Euphoria,
list.item: the ſame.
list.label: Eupncea
list.item: is a right natural Reſpiration.
list.label: Eurythmus
list.item: is an excellent natural Pulſe.
list.label: Euſarcus,
list.item: one that is well fleſhed.
list.label: Euſema
list.item: is a Criſis excellently well judged.
list.label: Euſtomachus
list.item: is a good Stomach; as alſo Meat convenient for it.
list.label: Euthanaſia
list.item: is a ſoft eaſie paſſage out of the World.
list.label: Euthyporos
list.item: is a ſtrait Gate.
list.label: Euthropia
list.item: is a due Nouriſhment of the Body.
list.label: Exacerbatio,
list.item: ſee Paroxyſmus.
list.label: Exaltatio, or Sublimatio,
list.item: is an Operation whereby a thing being changed in its natural qualifications, is elevated to an higher degree of Vertue and Subſtance; or it is a Subtilizing of things by gradually Diſſolving them, and Exalting them into a purer and higher degree of their own qualities: and it is done either by Circulation, or Ablution.
list.label: Exanaſtomoſis
list.item: is an opening of the Extremitie of Veſſels.
list.label: Exanthema
list.item: is a certain Effloreſcenae upon the Skin of the Head, like thoſe which appear in the skin of the whole Body; it is deſcribed two ways by Senertus; one is, that at leaſt it changes the colour of the Skin, as in continued Malignant Fevers; wherein the skin is ſpotted as with Fleabites; the other is, when certain little ſwellings break out in the Skin, which may be called Papillae.
list.label: Exarthrema,
list.item: the ſame with Luxatio.
list.label: Exceptio
list.item:
is the Incorporation or Mixture of dry
Powders with ſome moiſture or other; thus Electuaries are made, Powders and Pulps are mixed with Honey, or Syrup: and the powder of Pills with Syrup, Honey, Wine or Juice.
list.label: Excrementa, Excrements
list.item: are whatſoever is ſeparated from the Aliments after Concoction, and is to be thrown out of the Body; as the moiſture in the Mouth, Spittle, Snot, Milk, Bile, Sweat, the Wax of the Ears, the Excrements of the Belly and Bladder.
list.label: Exelciſmus
list.item: is a bringing of the Bones from the ſurface downward.
list.label: Exercitatio
list.item: is a vehement and voluntary Motion of Humane Body, attended with an Alteration in Breathing, undertook either for preſerving, or acquiring Health.
list.label: Excercitium
list.item:
is a Motion whereby the Body is agitated in order to Health; and it is Threefold.
1. What proceeds onely from things Extrinſic; as in Riding, Navigation, &c.
2. What proceeds partly from other things, partly from thoſe who are moved, as in Gladiators, and Wreſtlers.
3. What comes from thoſe onely who exerciſe, as in walking, and the Ball; and beſt of all in Handball: the end of Exerciſe is Threefold likewiſe; either Heat, Sweat, or Breath, and this is ſufficient.
list.label: Exomphalos
list.item: is a Protuberance of the Navel, common to Infants.
list.label: Exophthalmia
list.item: is a protuberance of the Eye, out of its natural Poſition.
list.label: Exoſtoſis
list.item: is a Protuberance of the Bones out of their Natural place.
list.label: Expiratio
list.item:
is an Alternate Contraction of the
Cheſt, whereby the Air, together with Fuliginous Vapours is expelled by the Wind-pipe; the cauſe of Expiration does not ſeem to conſiſt in the contraction of the Cheſt, but in the Relaxation of the Tunic of the upper part of the Gullet, and the Wind-pipe; for take that away, and you take away the Motion of the Cheſt, and Abdomen.
list.label: Exploſio
list.item: is an action of the Spirits, whereby the Nerves are ſuddenly Contracted; the reaſon is, That ſome Heterogeneous Particles are mixed with the Animal Spirits, or that they are driven into a confuſion, like Gun-powder out of a Gun.
list.label: Expulſio,
list.item: the ſame with vis Expultrix.
list.label: Expultrix vis,
list.item: according to the Ancients, was that facultie which expell'd the Excrements: but we need not have recourſe to thoſe blind Faculties, ſince we know that this is performed by the Animal Spirits, which cauſe the Periſtaltic Motion of the Guts.
list.label: Exſtaſis
list.item: is a depravation of the Judgment and Imagination, familiar to Mad and Melancholy Perſons.
list.label: Extaſis,
list.item: the ſame that Exſtaſis.
list.label: Extirpatio
list.item: is the cutting of a part, by reaſon of a Cancre, or Blaſting; it is beſt to cut it off Two, Three, or more Fingers breadths from the Joynt, unleſs the Mortification have reached the upper parts of the Arms, or Thigh; for here we are forced to chuſe the Joynt it ſelf: it is a ſurer way to make the Exciſion in a ſound part, though it be more painful.
list.label: Extractio
list.item:
is a Separating of the ſubtle parts of a mixed Body, from the more groſs: for Example,
when the ſtrength of any Medicine is Extracted by Spirit of Wine, that which is left after the Evaporation of the Menſtruum is called the Extract.
list.label: Extractum
list.item: is that pure, unmixed, and efficacious Subſtance, which by the help of ſome Liquor is ſeparated from the duller and more unactive parts.
list.label: Exulceratio
list.item: is a Solution of continued parts, proceeding from ſome gnawing Matter, and in ſoft parts of the Body, attended with a loſs of their quantity; it differs from an Abſceſſus in this, that an Abſceſſus is occaſioned by a Criſis. An Exulceration is either great, little, broad, ſhort, narrow, ſtrait, tranſverſe, winding, equal, inequal, deep, &c.

list.head: F.
list.label: Facies Hyppocratica
list.item: is when the Noſtrils are ſharp, the Eyes hollow, the Temples low, the Laps of the Ears contracted, and the Lobes Inverſed, the Skin about the Forehead hard, and dry; the Complexion pale, livid, of a leaden Colour, or Black.
list.label: Facultas
list.item: is an action in Man, which is performed, either by the Body alone, or by both Body and Mind: Faculties are either Natural, which depends upon the Cerebellum: or Animal, which depend upon the Brain. The Ancients made three Faculties, Natural, Vital, and Animal: but the Vital belongs to the Natural.
list.label: Faeces,
list.item: ſee Excrementa.
list.label: Falx
list.item:
is a doubling of the Dura Mater, like a
Sickle, annexed below to the Third Cavitie whereby the Brain is divided into the right and left Hemiſphere.
list.label: Fames, Hunger,
list.item: is either Natural, which is a deſire of Food, when an Animal from a Vellification of a Nerve of the par vagum, and the Intercoſtal in the Stomach, which proceeds from an Acid Humour, carried thither by the Caeliac Arteries, or Glandulous Tunic, is excited to ſeek for Food as a Remedy to allay that Vellication; or it is praeternatural, which is either depraved, as longing in Women with Child; or it is a Canine Appetite, want of Appetite, &c.
list.label: Fames Canina,
list.item: ſee Cynedes Orexis.
list.label: Farciminalis Tunica,
list.item: the ſame that Allantoides.
list.label: Faſcia,
list.item: a Swathe, is a long Band, moderately broad, which Chyrurgeons uſe: Swathes are wound up; long, and all of a breadth; others are cut, which are indeed of one piece of Linnen, but that cut either at the ends, or middle: others ſewed together, which conſiſts of Swathes and Thongs of ſeveral ends, and like ſeveral Swathes. Others are longer, ſome ſhorter; and others broader, ſome narrower.
list.label: Faſciatio
list.item: is a binding of Swathes about a Limb that is to be Cured.
list.label: Faſciculus,
list.item: ſee Manipulus.
list.label: Faſtidium Cibi,
list.item: the ſame that Anorexia.
list.label: Fauces and Frumen,
list.item: the ſame that Pharynx.
list.label: Favus,
list.item: ſee in Achor.
list.label: Febris a Fever,
list.item:
is an inordinate Motion, and too greatan Efferveſcence of the Blood, attended
with Cold firſt, and afterwards with Heat, Thirſt, and other Symptoms, wherewith the Animal Oeconomie is variouſly diſturbed. Fevers in general are divided into Intermittent, Continued, Continent, and Symptomatical. Scotus in his Magick aſſures us, That the Blood in a Fever has Worms in it.
list.label: Feculae
list.item: are Duſt that ſubſides in the ſqueezing of certain Vegetables, as in Brionie, Ramp, &c.
list.label: Fell,
list.item: ſee Bullis.
list.label: Femur, and Femen,
list.item: the Thigh, the part from the Buttocks to the Knee; it is ſo called from bearing, becauſe it holds up, and ſuſtains an Animal; it conſiſts but of one Bone, but that the greateſt and longeſt in the whole Body, whoſe External and fore part is gibbous or riſing; but the Internal hinder part flat and bending. Grammarians make Femen to be the hinder fleſhy part; and Femur the former outward part.
list.label: Fermentatio
list.item: is an Inteſtine Motion of Particles, or of the Principles of any Body, tending to Perfection, or a Change: and it is either Natural, which comes of its own accord, as in Natural Actions; or Artificial, which we make, as we ſee in Beer, Wine, Bread, &c.
list.label: Ferulae
list.item:
are little light chips or planes, which are made of different Matter, according to the nature and neceſſities of the places to which they are applyed, as of Barks of Trees, of the Bark of the Herb Sagapene, in Latin Ferula; whence they have their Name: they are made of Firr, Paper glewed together, Leather, &c. which are applyed to Bones that have been looſened, or disjoynted,
after they are ſet again.
list.label: Fibra Auris,
list.item: the ſame with Lobus Auris.
list.label: Fibrae, Fibres,
list.item: are little, round, oblong Veſſels; and are either Muſculous or Nervous: the Nervous are ſuch as have no Valves, and by which the Spirits flow conveniently from the Nerves to the ſeveral parts: the Muſculous Fibres receive the Blood from the Arteries, and diſcharge themſelves into the Veins, and have a great many Valves, they are called long, round, or oblique from their Scituation; ſome ſmall threads interwoven with Trees and Leaves are called Fibres too: and ſo are the ſmall threads which ſtick to their Roots.
list.label: Fibula,
list.item:
the Ancients mention them; for if there be a Wound in the Fleſh, ſays Celſus, that gapes, and cannot eaſily be cloſed, it is improper to ſew it, you muſt apply a Fibula; but becauſe this way of cloſing the gaping of Wounds, by Fibula's was ſo uſual amongſt the Ancients; they have not been at all ſollicitous in deſcribing either their Matter or Form. Guido tells us, That they made theſe Fibula's of Iron Circles as it were, or Semi-circles crooked backward on both ſides, the hooks whereof being faſtned on both ſides to the gaping Wound, anſwered exactly one another; but ſince this muſt be an unſupportable pain to the poor Patient, it is hardly credible, that they meant any ſuch thing by their Fibula's. The Opinion of Fallopius is more probable, who tells us, That is was onely a ſowing up the Wound with a Needle and Thread, which is commonly uſed at this day. Sanctorius writes thus, We need not Diſcourſe much of Fibula's, ſince the
uſe of them is almoſt out of dores; and though the Ancients have not deſcribed them, yet they forbear not to acquaint us how to uſe them; as Argenterius falſly imagines. For not onely Phyſicians but ſome of the Ancients knew the form of them, ſince Cern. Celſus has informed us. That Fibula's as well as Sutures were made of a Needle-full of ſoft untwiſted ſilk or thread, wherewith they ſowed the gaping Lips of the Wound together. Some call Acia, or this needle-full of Thred, Vinculum, Ligatura, Colligatio, Obligatio, Ligamentum; all which ſignifie tying or binding. Whoever would be farther informed in this particular, may conſult the Incomparable Rhodius in his Diſcourſe about Acia.
list.label: Fibula
list.item: is the leſſer Bone of the Shank, it ſeems to joyn the Muſcles of the Leg like a Button, or Claſp, in Latin Fibula; it is the hinder bone betwixt the Knee and the Foot, ſmaller than the other Bone, called Tibia, and faſtned outwardly to it; as the Bone called Radius in the Arm is to the Cubit: its round head does not extend as far as the Knee upward, but downward, it goes farther than the other Bone called Tibia, and therefore is altogether as long a Bone as the Tibia. They part in the middle, becauſe the Muſcles of the Feet are placed there; in which interval, a ſlender broad Ligament joyns them together lengthways. It is joyned likewiſe to the Tibia with a common Ligament above and below; as it tends acutely downwards it has an Appendix belonging to it, which growing thicker and thicker, makes a Proceſs, called Malleolus Externas.
list.label: Ficus
list.item: are Excreſcencies about the Fundament and other parts, like Figs; if they grow big, then they are called Ficus, or Sycoſes.
list.label: Filtratio
list.item: is the Percolating any Liquor through a woollen Cloth, or courſe Paper.
list.label: Filtram
list.item: is a woollen Cloth, or blotting Paper, through which Liquors are ſtrained to Clarifie: as through a Manca Hippocratis, a Wine-ſack which draws Wine from the dregs.
list.label: Fiſſura oſſis
list.item: is a fracture of a Bone lengthways.
list.label: Fiſtula
list.item: is a ſtrait long Cavity, or a winding, narrow and callous Ulcer, of difficult Cure; proceeding for the moſt from an Apoſteme. Fiſtula's differ from winding Ulcers in this, that Fiſtula's are callous and hard, but Ulcers are not.
list.label: Fiſtula Lachrymalis
list.item: is when the Punctum Lachrymale, the little hole in the bone of the Noſe, through which the Liquid Matter paſſes to the Noſtrils, is grown hard and callous, from an Ulcer of a Caruncula, Glandules placed at the greater corners of the Eye, by which means there happens a continual Defluxion of Tears.
list.label: Fiſtula Pulmonis,
list.item: the ſame that Aſpera Arteria.
list.label: Fiſtula Sacra,
list.item: is that part of the Back-bone which is Perforated.
list.label: Fiſtula Urinaria,
list.item: the ſame with Urethra.
list.label: Flatus
list.item: are Efferveſcencies excited in the Body from wind let in, or from Flatulent Meats, or from the Bile and Pancreatic juice mixed together, whence wind and noiſe.
list.label: Flores Chymici
list.item:
are the Subtiler parts of the Body
ſeparated from the groſſer by Sublimation, in a dry Form.
list.label: Fluor Albus, or Fluor Uterinus,
list.item: is a continual Evacuation of corrupt Humors from the Womb, or the Pores in the Vagina.
list.label: Fluor Muliebris,
list.item: ſee Fluor Albus.
list.label: Fluor Uterinus,
list.item: the ſame.
list.label: Fluxio,
list.item: the ſame with Catarrhus.
list.label: Fluxus Chyloſus,
list.item: the ſame with Caeliaca paſſio.
list.label: Fluxus Hepaticus
list.item: is a kind of Dyſentery, wherein black ſhining blood, and too long roſted as it were, is driven out of the Guts by the Fundament: it is ſometimes taken for a Dyſentery wherein ſerous ſharp Blood is evacuated.
list.label: Focile Majus
list.item: is the greater Bone of the Cubit called Ulna; or the greater bone of the Leg called Tibia.
list.label: Focile Minus
list.item: is the leſſer Bone of the Cubit called Radius; or the leſſer bone of the Leg, called Fibula.
list.label: Focus
list.item: is ſome place in the Miſenterie and other parts, whence they formerly deduced the Original of Fevers.
list.label: Fodina
list.item: is the leſs Labyrinth in the bone of the Ears.
list.label: Faecula
list.item: ſignifies a Powder which ſubſides to the bottom in certain ſtrainings of Vegetables; for it is prepared of ſome green, waſhed, and pared Roots beat together, with a little water, then ſtrained, that there may ſubſide a white ſort of Powder which is to be dryed lightly.
list.label: Faetor oris,
list.item: a ſtinking Breath, procceds from the filth about the Teeth, and Gums: ſometimes from the Lungs, and a Conſumptive or Scorbutic Blood.
list.label: Folliculus Fellis
list.item: is a little Bladder faſtned to the Concave-part of the Liver, which receives the Bile, which in proper time empties it ſelf into the Gut Duodenum, by a Ductus, or Paſſage called Cheledochus.
list.label: Fomentum,
list.item: that which applyed to the Body cheriſhes and warms it; and it is Twofold, either wet, or dry; the latter is a Decoction applyed to ſeveral parts of the body for to cheriſh it, by the help of a linnen, or wollen Cloth, a Spunge, Bladder, &c.
list.label: Fontanellae, Iſſues,
list.item: are little Ulcers which Chyrurgions make in ſound parts of the Body, to Evacuate bad Humors, Cure Diſeaſes, or prevent them. Iſſues are made either with an Actual or a Potential Seering-Iron, with a Lance, and a pair of Sciſſers: You muſt always obſerve to make Iſſues betwixt two Muſcles.
list.label: Fonticuli,
list.item: the ſame.
list.label: Forceps
list.item: is an Inſtrument wherewith dead and corrupt parts, (alſo things beſides, or againſt Nature) are ſeiſed, cut off, or pulled out; they are of ſeveral ſhapes, as long, crooked, with Teeth, with Beeks, in faſhion of an half Moon, ſuch as will open the Mouth, or the Womb; and by which you may ſee into either of them; which according to the difference of their ſhape, are of different uſe.
list.label: Forfex
list.item: is an Inſtrument to pull out Teeth with.
list.label: Formula
list.item: is a Phyſitians Preſcription, which the Apothecaries prepare accordingly.
list.label: Fornix
list.item:
is the Callous Subſtance of the Brain;
ſo called, becauſe it ſeems to ſuſtain the Cavities of the Ventricles, and the bulk of the impending Brain, like an Arch or Vault.
list.label: Fotus,
list.item: the ſame with Fomentum.
list.label: Fovea Cordis,
list.item: the ſame with Anticardium.
list.label: Fractura Oſſis,
list.item: the breaking of a Bone, is a Solution of the Continuum in the hard parts of the Body, which is done by a hard External Inſtrument, forcibly impell'd upon the part; the differences whereof are taken from the Form, the Part, and the Accidents of it.
list.label: Fraenulum
list.item: is a Membraneous Ligament under the Tongue; in new-born Children, it ſometimes ſpreads over the whole under ſide of the Tongue, that the Midwife ſometimes is forced to pull it aſunder with her Nails (which yet ought not to be allow'd of) or the Chyrurgion with his Penknife.
list.label: Froenulum, or Froenum penis,
list.item: is a Membrane which tyes the fore-skin to the Nut of the Yard.
list.label: Frons,
list.item: the forehead is the upper part of the Face.
list.label: Frontale
list.item: is an External Medicine, frequently applyed to the Forehead, for a pain or heat in the Head: it is made for the moſt part of Herbs, Flowers, Seeds, Meal, moiſtned with Vinegar of Roſes.
list.label: Fumigatio Chymica
list.item: is an eroſion of Metal by ſmoak, or Vapour.
list.label: Functio,
list.item: the ſame that Aclio.
list.label: Funda Galeni
list.item: is a Swathe divided into Four parts; uſeful in Accidents that happen to the Jawbone.
list.label: Fungus
list.item: is ſoft ſpongie Fleſh which grows upon Wounds.
list.label: Funiculus, Inteſtinum, Laqueus, or Ductus Umbilicalis, the Navel-ſtring,
list.item: is a Membraneous Channel or Conduct in a Faetus which reaches from the Navel to the Placenta in the Womb; it contains Two Arteries, one Vein, and the Urinarie paſſage in the Faetus.
list.label: Furcale os,
list.item: the ſame with Furcula.
list.label: Furcula Superior
list.item: is the upper bone of the Sternum, or Breaſt-bone, others call it Jugulum.
list.label: Furcella,
list.item: the ſame that Furcula.
list.label: Furfuratio
list.item: is when Dandriff falls from the Head in Combing; it comes for the moſt part from that skin which is under the Hair; alſo from the Beard, and Eye-brows.
list.label: Furnuss,
list.item: a Furnace, is a place where a Fire is conveniently kept for Chymical uſes: and it is either open or covered.
list.label: Furor
list.item: the ſame with Manea.
list.label: Furor Uterinus
list.item:
is an unſeemly Diſtemper, which is wont to ſeize upon Maids; eſpecially thoſe of riper Years, and ſometimes Widows too. They who are troubled with it, throw off the Veil of common Modeſty, and Decency, and Delight onely in laſcivious, obſcene Diſcourſes: they covet a man greedily, and even furiouſly, and omit no inviting Temptations that may induce them to ſatisfie their deſires. The cauſe ſeems to be in the Seminal juice, which being Exalted to the higheſt degree of Maturity, drives the Maids into a kind of Fury; which is conſpicuous every year in ſome Bruits; as in Cats, Bulls, Bucks, Does, Harts.
There is another Diſtemper akin to this, which the Ancients called, the Fervour of the Womb, or the Matrix, when the whole ſubſtance and body of the Womb is extream hot, accompanied with a pain and heavineſs of the Loyns; a roughneſs by the growth of Hair, Loathing, and a ſuppreſſion of the Urine, and Excrements: and the Woman all the while covets to be laid with, but by reaſon of pain is ſtill afraid of it.
list.label: Furunculus
list.item: a Boyl, is an acute ſwelling, as big as a Pigeons Egg, attended with an Inflamation, and Pain, eſpecially when it begins to Corrupt, and Putrifie: when it is opened, and the Matter let out, part of the Fleſh underneath is turned into Corruption, of a whitiſh, and reddiſh Colour, which ſome call the Ventricle of the Furunculus: there is no danger in it, though you apply no Remedy to it; for it ripens of it ſelf, and burſts; but the pain makes it more Elegible to apply a Remedie, becauſe that frees the Patient ſooner from his trouble.
list.label: Fuſio
list.item: is a melting with heat.

list.head: G.
list.label: GAllactophori,
list.item: are Ductus's which carry Milk, convey the Chyle (as ſome Modern Authors have fancied) a ſtreight way from the Guts to the Glandules of the Breaſts: yet the Arteries were more properly ſo called, becauſe they carry the Chyle along with the Blood to the Breaſts, wherein Milk is reſerved for the uſe of the Faetus.
list.label: Galactopoietice Facultas
list.item: is nothing but an Aptitude to ſequeſter Milk in the Breaſts: of the ſeParating of Milk. See in the Word Lac.
list.label: Galenica Medicina,
list.item: is that Phyſick which is built upon the Principles of Galen, and therefore they are Galeniſts who embrace the Foundation of their Art, which are fetched from Galen and the Philoſophers, proved by Reaſon, and confirmed by Experience.
list.label: Galea
list.item: is a pain in the Head, ſo called from the likeneſs of the place, becauſe it takes in the whole Head, like an Helmet; in Latin Galea.
list.label: Galea
list.item: is likewiſe when the Head of the Faetus is clothed with part of the Membrane called Amneos, as it comes into the World.
list.label: Galreda, or Gelatina, Gellie,
list.item: is a Thickned, Viſcous, and Lucid Juicie Subſtance; it is commonly made of the Cartilaginous parts of Animals boiled, as of Calves Feet, &c.
list.label: Ganglion
list.item: is an Humour in the Tendinous and Nervous parts, procecding from a Fall, Stroke, or otherwiſe; it reſiſts if ſtirred, if preſſed upon its ſide is not diverted, nor can be turned round.
list.label: Gangraena,
list.item: a Gangrene, is a Cadaverous Corruption of a part, attended with a beginning of Stink, Blackneſs, and Mortification.
list.label: Gargareon,
list.item: See Cion.
list.label: Gargariſma,
list.item: a Gargariſme, is a Liquid Medicine which cleanſes the Mouth, and the Adjacent parts by Gargling, without ſwallowing; and it is either a Decoction, wherein convenient Syrups are diſſolved, or diſtilled Waters mixed with Syrups, and ſometimes with Mineral Spirits.
list.label: Gaſtrocnemium
list.item: is the Calf of the Leg, whence its Muſcles are called Gastrocnemii, from their ſwelling like a belly.
list.label: Gaſtrocnemii Muſculi,
list.item: ſee Gaſtrocnemium.
list.label: Gaſtroepiploica
list.item: is the Vein and Arterie which goes to to the Ventricle and the Cawl.
list.label: Gastrorhaphia
list.item: is a Connexion or a Suture in the wounds of the Abdomen.
list.label: Gaudium
list.item: is a cheerfulneſs proceeding from the apprehenſion of ſome good obtained, or to be obtained.
list.label: Gelatina
list.item: is almoſt the ſame with Galreda, but that is of a more general ſignification, and is taken for any Pellucide Glutinous Juice, which uſed firſt to be made of the juice of Fruits, as of Apples, &c. as the Gellie of Quinces, &c.
list.label: Gena Mala
list.item: is part of the Face from the Noſe to the Ears. Alſo the Chin, the Jaw-bone, which is either upper or lower.
list.label: Generatio
list.item:
is a natural Action, whereby an Animal begets another like it of the ſame Species, of convenient Seed, in Generation; the firſt thing we ſee is a red Speck, which is clothed with a little bladder, next a little Heart, whence Veins and Arteries flow, at the Extremitie whereof you ſee the Viſcera, the Bowels, &c. afterward the whole Faetus is formed and cloathed with Membranes; before Generation the Seed of the Male being caſt into the Womb, enters and prepares its Pores, afterwards ſweats out a Viſcous Subſtance, like the white of an Egg, which moves the Egg out of the Teſticles and Tubes; for the Womans Eggs are impregnated by the influence of the Seed, are
emitted out of the Teſticles, and received by the Fallopian Tubes.
list.label: Geniogloſſum
list.item: is a pair of Muſcles proceeding inwardly from the Chin under another pair called Geniohyoyides, and are faſtned in the Baſis of the bone Hyoides.
list.label: Geniohyoides
list.item: are Muſcles reaching from the internal and lower Seat of the Chin to the Baſis of the Bone Hyoides, which is placed at the Baſis of the Tongue.
list.label: Gercomia
list.item: is a part of that part of Phyſick called Hygieina, or Preſervation of health, which teaches the way of living for old Men.
list.label: Gingipedium,
list.item: the ſame with Scorbutus.
list.label: Gingiva,
list.item: the Gums, is a hard ſpurious ſort of Fleſh, which ſurrounds the Teeth like a Rampart, and in people that want Teeth helps to the chewing their meat, which being either eat out, relaxed, or too dry, the Teeth ſhake or fall out.
list.label: Ginglymus
list.item: is a Conjunction of Bones, when the Head of one is received into the Cavitie of another, and again the head of this into the Cavity of that.
list.label: Glacialis Humor,
list.item: ſee Humoris Oculi.
list.label: Glandula,
list.item:
a Glandule, is a Subſtance of a peculiar nature, fleſhie, white, or gray, and Friable; and it is two-fold, adventitious, as thoſe Kernels which are ſometimes under the Arm-holes, and in the Neck, the Kings Evil; a ſwelling in the Larynx and middle of the Wind-pipe, &c. or perpetual and natural, as the Thymus, Pancreas, Glandula, Pinealis, &c. the perpetual is again Two-fold, either Conglobated in one entire piece, which ſends
the ſeparated Humour into the Veins, as the pituitarie Glandule, the Pinealis, the Glandules of the Meſenterie, of the Groins, &c. or Conglomerated in a cluſter, which convey the juice by their own Channels into ſome notable Cavities of the body, as the Pancreas, the Glandules of the Breaſt, the Salival Glandules, &c.
list.label: Glandula Guidonis
list.item: is a Tumor like a Glandulae, ſoft, ſingle, Movable, without Roots, and ſeparate from the adjacent parts.
