are Excretions of Blood every Month from the Womb, and not from its Neck or Paſſage called Vagina. The cauſe thereof conſiſts in a fermentative Matter, generated in the Subſtance of the Womb; or a ſeminal Matter, infuſed into the Blood from the Teſticles, or Ovaria in a Woman, which being mixed with the maſs of the Blood, ferments it into ſuch a motion, that it is forced to diſcharge it ſelf every Month. They begin uſually when young Maids grow ripe, at twelve or fourteen, but
ceaſe naturally in Women with Child, paſt Children, and thoſe that give ſuck.
list.label: Menſtrua alba,
list.item: ſee Fluor albus.
list.label: Menſtruum Mulierum,
list.item: ſee Menſes.
list.label: Menſtruum
list.item: is that which is to be diſtilled, or a Liqour which corrodes Metals, and diſſolves Stones, as Vinegar, Aqua fortis, Spirit of Wine, &c. It may be taken alſo for the Caput mortuum, which is left after Diſtillation.
list.label: Mentagra
list.item: is a ſort of wild Tetter or Ringworm, which was not known in Claudius's days.
list.label: Meſaraeum,
list.item: the ſame that Meſenterium; whence its Veſſels are called as well Meſaraick, as Meſenterick.
list.label: Meſaraica vaſa,
list.item: ſee in Meſaraeum.
list.label: Meſenteria vaſa,
list.item: ſee Meſaraeon.
list.label: Meſenterium
list.item: is the Membrane of the Peritonaeum doubled, enriched with Glandules, Nerves, Arteries, Veins, Chyliferous and Lymphatick Veſſels; it is in the middle of the Abdomen, and contains the Inteſtines in a wonderful manner. It has a great Glandule in the middle called Pancreas Aſellis; about which are ſeveral other leſs Glandules, to which the milky Veſſels of the firſt rank tend from the Inteſtines, and Lymphatick Veſſels from the Liver and other Parts; from theſe Glandules again the milky Veſſels of the ſecond rank aſcend to the Veſſel that carries the Maſs of Chyle, and diſcharge themſelves into it.
list.label: Meſeraeum,
list.item: ſee Meſaraeum and Meſenterium.
list.label: Meſocolon
list.item: is that part of the Meſentery which is continued to the great Guts.
list.label: Meſonuctium
list.item: is the middle of the Night.
list.label: Meſopleurii
list.item: are the intercoſtal Muſcles, twenty two on each ſide, eleven external, and as many internal.
list.label: Metabole
list.item: is a change of Time, Air, or Diſeaſes.
list.label: Metacarpus and Metacarpium
list.item: is the back of the Hand, made of four oblong little Bones, which expand the Palm of the Hand, and they are called Poſt-Brachialia.
list.label: Metacondyli
list.item: are the utmoſt Bones of the Fingers.
list.label: Metalepticus
list.item: is a Metaleptick Motion of the Muſcles.
list.label: Metallum, Mettal,
list.item: is a ſolid, rigid Subſtance, found in Mountains and ſubterraneous Cavities. The ſeveral ſorts of them are comprehended in this Verſe. Sol, Mars, Luna, Venus, Saturnus, Jupiter, Hermes.
list.label: Gold
list.item: is the moſt ſolid Metal, the Tincture whereof is highly extolled by the Chymiſts.
list.label: Metallurgus, or Metallicus,
list.item: is one who ſearches after Metalls, as the Chymiſts.
list.label: Metapedium,
list.item: the ſame in the Foot, that Metacarpus is in the Hand.
list.label: Metaphrenum
list.item: is that part of the Back which comes after the Diaphragme.
list.label: Metaptoſis
list.item: is the degenerating of one Diſeaſe into another, as of a Quartane Ague into a Tertian; and on the contrary, of an Apoplexy into a Palſy, &c.
list.label: Metaſtaſis
list.item:
is when a Diſeaſe goes from one part to another; which happens to Apoplectick People, when the Matter which affects the
Brain is tranſlated to the Nerves.
list.label: Metaſyncriſis
list.item: is the Operation of the Medicine externally applied, which fetches out the Humours from their cloſeſt Receſſes.
list.label: Metatarſus
list.item: are the five little Bones of the Foot, connected to the Bones of the firſt part of the Foot, which immediately ſucceeds the Leg.
list.label: Methodica Medicina
list.item: is that which was invented by Themiſon Laodiceus, and improved by Theſſalus Trallianus, who ſaid that the Art might be learned in ſix Months time.
list.label: Methodus
list.item: is a part of Phyſick whereby Remedies are found out by Indications for the Reſtauration of Health.
list.label: Metopum
list.item: is the Fore-head.
list.label: Metrenchyta
list.item: is an Inſtrument wherewith Liquors are injected into the Womb.
list.label: Miaſma
list.item: is a contagious Infection in the Blood and Spirits, as in the Plague and Scurvy.
list.label: Microcoſmus, Man
list.item: is called the little World as a Compendium of the greater.
list.label: Microphthalmus
list.item: is one who has little Eyes from his Birth.
list.label: Miliaris herpes,
list.item: ſee Herpes.
list.label: Miſerere mei, or Chordapſus,
list.item: is a moſt vehement Pain in the Guts, proceeding from an Inflammation of them, or Involution and the periſtaltick Motion inverſed; whence the Excrements are diſcharged by the Mouth. It is called alſo Volvulus.
list.label: Mitella
list.item: is a Swathe that holds up the Arm when it is hurt or wounded.
list.label: Miva
list.item: is the Fleſh or Pulp of a Quince boiled up with Sugar into a thick Conſiſtence.
list.label: Mixtura
list.item: is a ſolid or liquid Subſtance mixed together of ſeveral Medicines. Mixtures are very different according to the ſcope of the Phyſician; they are taken eſpecially in Drops or Spoonfuls, and ſometimes in Draughts. They are made either of Liquors only, ſuch as are diſtilled Waters, Spirits, and Oils, any way mixed together, as Waters with Waters, Oil with Oil, Waters with Spirits, &c. or of Liquors with convenient Syrups, Pouders, Conſections, Opiates, all of them together, or only ſome.
list.label: Mna, or Mina, an Attick Mna
list.item: contains an hundred Drams, or twelve Ounces and an half; the Roman, ninety ſix Drams, or twelve Ounces; the Alexandrian, an hundred and ſixty Drams, or twenty Ounces.
list.label: Modiolus, Trepanum, or Anabaptiſton,
list.item:
is an Inſtrument which they uſe in profound Corruptions, Contuſions, Cuts and Fractures of Bones, not eaſily, tho to be, applied; unleſs, 1. The Chips and Prominences of the Bones prick, 2. When the upper Table is entire, but depreſſed, and the lower broken. 3. When the extravaſated Blood would choak a Man with Corruption. The manner of perforating is thus: When the Hairs are ſhaven off, the Skin is to be cut to the Pericranium, avoiding as prudently as may be the Muſcles of the Temples and the Sutures, and for this time the Wound is to be bound up, unleſs there be ſo little Blood ſpilt, that the Membrane, called Pericranium, may at the ſame time be pulled off from the Scull:
Then after a few Hours you may ſtop the Ears of the Patient, and take one of theſe Inſtruments called a Maſculine Modiolus, whoſe point is to be fixed in the Skull, but ſo far off the Fracture, that it touch it not, much leſs the Suture, with its Teeth; tho ſome never avoid the Sutures, and aſſure us that they have perforated them as ſucceſsfully as any other part: Then hold the Inſtrument faſt with the left-hand, and turn it round with the right, till you have cut out a pretty deep Circle: After this take a Feminine Modiolus (which has no point in the middle) and turn it round as before: In the mean time take away the Duſt that proceeds from the Perforation, and moiſten the Inſtrument in Oil and Water to make it cool and ſlippery: The Blood that appears with ſhew that you are now gone as deep as the ſecond Table, i. e. beyond the Scull to the Meninx, and then you muſt preſs very gently, leſt the Membrane of the Brain be unadviſedly hurt; when the Bone begins to wag, put ſomething in betwixt the ſides of the Wound, looſen it, and take it out with a pair of Chirurgeons Pincers.
list.label: Mola, Patella, or Rotula,
list.item: is a round and broad Bone, at the joynting of the Thigh and Leg, where the Knee, excepting this Bone, is begirt with a Membranous Ligament.
list.label: Mola carnea,
list.item: is a fleſhy, and ſometimes a ſpungy Subſtance without Bones, or Bowels; it is often black like concreted Blood; and ſometimes extream hard, preternaturally brought into the World inſtead of a Faetus.
list.label: Molares, or Maxillares Dentes;
list.item: ſee Dentes.
list.label: Mollientia;
list.item: ſee Emollientia.
list.label: Melopes, Vibices, Enchymoma, Sugillationes,
list.item: all ſignify the ſame thing; red Spots like thoſe which remain in the Skin after beating, in malignant and peſtilential Fevers.
list.label: Molynſis,
list.item: the ſame that Miaſma.
list.label: Monocolum
list.item: is the Gut Caecum.
list.label: Monohemera
list.item: are Diſeaſes that are cured in one day.
list.label: Monopagia,
list.item: ſee Monopegia.
list.label: Menopegia
list.item: is a ſharp Pain in the Head, afflicting one ſingle place.
list.label: Mons Veneris
list.item: is the upper part of a Woman's Secrets, ſomething higher than the reſt.
list.label: Morbilli, the Meazles,
list.item: are red Spots which proceed from an aerial Contagion in the Blood, they neither ſwell nor are ſuppurated, and differ only in degree from the Small-pox.
list.label: Morbus, a Diſeaſe,
list.item:
is ſuch a Conſtitution of Body as renders us inapt for the due performance of our Actions: Or, it is an ill Conſtitution in a Man which hurts any of our Faculties, according to Sylvius de le Boc. Diſeaſes are two-fold, either from an ill Conformation, or an Indiſpoſition: An ill Conformation is ſix-fold, for it sonſiſts in Number, Magnitude, Figure, Cavity, Surface and Situation: Indiſpoſition is either occult or manifeſt; the Occult is poyſoned, contagious, and peſtilent; the Manifeſt s either ſimple, as hot, cold, moiſt, dry, &c. or compound, when more Qualities than one are peccant at once, as cold and moiſt, hot and moiſt, &c. There's a Diſeaſe by Idiipothia, peculiar to ones ſelf, by Protopathia, when one
has it firſt, by Deuteropathia, at ſecond hand, and by Sympathy. Alſo Diſeaſes are ſimple or compound, gentle or malignant, ſhort, long, acute, continued, intermittent, hereditary, native, Pituitous, bilious, melancholy, Summer, Winter, Autumnal, Epidemick, &c.
list.label: Morbus Regius,
list.item: the ſame that Icterus.
list.label: Moretum
list.item: is a ſort of Drink which our Women uſe much when they think they have conceived, for they are perſwaded that it ſpoils a falſe Conception and ſtrengthens a true one: It is ſo called from the Mulberries they put in it.
list.label: Moria, Dulneſs or Folly, or Stupidity,
list.item: is a defect of Judgment and Underſtanding; it proceeds chiefly from lack of Imagination and Memory.
list.label: Moroſis,
list.item: the ſame that Moria.
list.label: Morphaea,
list.item: the ſame that Alphus.
list.label: Morſelli,
list.item: the ſame that Morſuli.
list.label: Morſuli, Tabellae,
list.item: they are Medicines of a ſquare Figure for the moſt part, made of Powders and the like mixed with Sugar diſſolved and poured upon a wooden, ſtone, or brazen Table, to be conſolidated.
list.label: Morſus canis rabidi,
list.item: the ſame that Cynanthropia.
list.label: Mortariola,
list.item: are the Caverns wherein the Teeth are lodged.
list.label: Morum,
list.item: the ſame that Pladaroſis.
list.label: Motos
list.item: is a peice of Linnen teezed like Wool, which is put into Ulcers, and ſtops a Flux of Blood.
list.label: Motus Periſtalticus,
list.item: ſee Periſtalticus.
list.label: Muccus,
list.item: the ſame that Mucus.
list.label: Mucago
list.item: is a viſcous Extraction, made of Seeds, Gums, Roots, &c. with Water.
list.label: Mucilago,
list.item: the ſame that Mucago.
list.label: Mucro cordis, or Apex,
list.item: is the lower pointed end of the Heart.
list.label: Mucronatum os,
list.item: ſee Enſiformis Cartilago.
list.label: Mucus,
list.item: we call it Snot, is a liquid, thick, and viſcous Excrement, which flows from the Proceſſus Papillares by the Os Cribriforme to the Noſtrils and Palate.
list.label: Muliebria,
list.item: ſee Cunnus.
list.label: Muſcae caput,
list.item: the ſame that Myocephalum.
list.label: Muſculus, a Muſcle,
list.item:
is an organical part furniſhed with two Tendons, and a fibrous or fleſhy Belly or middle part: Its Office is to move the Members that are contiguous to it. This Motion or Contraction is performed by the flowing of the Animal Spirits from the Brain to the Tendons by the Nerves, and thence to the middle of the Muſcles, where they contract them, and when that is done, recede to the Muſcles again. The Antients divided the Body of a Muſcle into the Head, Belly, and Tail; in which diviſion they called the Extremity of the Muſcle, connected to that part towards which the Contraction was made, the Head; the end or part of the Muſcle, inſerted into that part which was to be moved, the Tail; and laſtly the intermediate part of the Muſcle, which is more ſwell'd with Fleſh, they called the Belly; and then in the performance of Motion they ſuppoſed the Muſcle was ſwell'd about the Head and Belly, and conſequently ſhortned in its length, ſo that it drew the Member, to which it was faſtned, near to it.
But how this was done they ſay not. Muſcles are deſtined either to the uſe of Cavities, or Limbs, and are diverſly denominated from their Shapes, Places where they are, and Actions they perform.
list.label: Mycteres
list.item: are the Noſtrils, or the Receptacles of pituitous Humors, which diſtil out of the Brain by the Proceſſus Papillares, the Extremities of the Olfactory Nerves.
list.label: Mydeſis
list.item: is Corruption or Rottenneſs from too much moiſture.
list.label: Mydriaſis
list.item: is a too great Dilatation of the Pupil of the Eye which makes the Sight dim.
list.label: Myelos
list.item: the Marrow of the Bones, or of the Brain, or Spinal Marrow.
list.label: Myle,
list.item: the ſame that Molagenu.
list.label: Mylogloſſum
list.item: is a pair of Muſcles which ariſe about the back ſide of the grinding Teeth, and are inſerted into the Ligament of the Tongue, and are ſaid to turn the Tongue upwards.
list.label: Mylphae
list.item: ſignify the falling off of the Hairs of the Eye-lids: Alſo Medicines againſt the falling off of Hair.
list.label: Myocephalum
list.item: is the falling of the Tunica uvea juſt begun, like the Head of a Fly, whence it has its Name.
list.label: Myodes platyſma
list.item: is a broad muſculous Expanſion in the Neck, proceeding there from a ſort of a fat Membrane.
list.label: Myologia
list.item: is a Deſcription of Muſcles.
list.label: Myopia,
list.item: is a certain Dimneſs of ſight in diſtant Objects, and yet a Perſpicacity in things near at hand. Purblindneſs.
list.label: Myopiaſis,
list.item: the ſame that Myopia.
list.label: Myops
list.item: is one that is Purblind; which is occaſioned by this, that the Sun-beams, entring in too great a quantity, repreſent the Object confuſedly in the Brain.
list.label: Myrach,
list.item: is an Arabian Word, and ſignifies the ſame that Epigaſtrium.
list.label: Myracopum
list.item: is an Ointment that takes away Wearineſs.
list.label: Myrmecia
list.item: is a ſort of Wart; they are harder and lower than thoſe fleſhy Tumors called Thymi, take deeper Root, and occaſion greater Pain, broad below, ſmall at top, and emit leſs Blood. They are ſcarce ever bigger than a ſort of Pulſe called Lupines. They breed in the Palms of the Hand, or the ſole of the Foot.
list.label: Myrinx,
list.item: the ſame that Tympanum.
list.label: Myron,
list.item: the ſame that Ʋnguentum.
list.label: Myropola,
list.item: is one that ſells Ointments.
list.label: Myrtum
list.item: is a little piece of Fleſh in a Womans Secrets, about the Cleft, proceeding from a Corrugation of the Vagina.
list.label: Myſtax
list.item: is the upper Lip and the Hairs upon it.
list.label: Myurus
list.item: is a mutilated Pulſe, increaſing or decreaſing gradually.
list.label: Myxa
list.item: is Snot, a pituitous Humour, which deſcends from the Extremity of the olfactory Nerves to the Noſtrils.

list.head: N.
list.label: NAevi,
list.item: Moles, are certain native Spots, and are two-fold, either plain, or protuberant, different in ſhape and colour. They happen to Child-bearing Women from a falſe Imagination, Drunkenneſs, Extaſy, &c.
list.label: Narcoſts
list.item: is a privation of Senſe, as in a Palſy, or in taking of Opium, &c.
list.label: Nacrotica
list.item: are Medicines that ſtupify, and allay Pain.
list.label: Naſcalia,
list.item: the ſame that Errhina.
list.label: Naſcalia,
list.item: are little globular Bodies which are put into the Neck of the Matrix, made of the ſame ſubſtance as Peſſaria: ſee Peſſaria.
list.label: Nata,
list.item: the ſame that Natta.
list.label: Nates cerebri
list.item: are two round Prominences, behind the Beds of the Optick Nerves, which grow to the upper part of the Marrowy Subſtance, they are ſmall in Men, and larger in Brutes.
list.label: Natta
list.item: is a great ſoft Tumor, without Pain and Colour, which grows eſpecially in the Back, yet ſometimes in the Shoulders; its Root is ſlender, yet it encreaſes ſo prodigiouſly that it will grow as big as a Melon, or a Gourd; it is made of fat Matter; and therefore ought to be reckoned amongſt the Steatomata. See Steatomata.
list.label: Natura,
list.item: the ſame that Cunnus.
list.label: Naturalis facultas, a natural Faculty,
list.item:
is an Action depending chiefly upon the Cerebellum, whereby the Body, without our notice, is nouriſhed, encreaſed, and preſerved by the Blood
and Animal Spirits; upon which likewiſe all Excretions, Digeſtions, and Generations depend.
list.label: Naviculare os,
list.item: called alſo Cymbiforme, is the third Bone in each Foot, in that part of it which immediately ſucceeds the Leg.
list.label: Necroſis
list.item: is a black and blew Mark in any part.
list.label: Nectar
list.item: is the drink of the Gods, as Ambroſia is their drink. But with Phyſicians it ſignifies rather a Medicinal Drink, but with a moſt delicious colour, taſte and ſmell.
list.label: Nemomena,
list.item: ſee Nomas.
list.label: Nepenthes, Opiate Laudunum,
list.item: a Medicine worthy indeed of Praiſe. It ſignifies as much as without Pain and Trouble, and by reaſon of the incomparably admired Effects it produces, highly deſerves the Name of Laudunum (a Word importing Praiſe.) Nepenthes they ſay was Helen's Remedy, wherewith ſhe expelled all Sorrow from her Heart, and waxed merry and cheerful.
list.label: Nephelae
list.item: are ſmall white Spots upon the Eyes. Alſo little Clouds as it were that ſwim in the middle of Urine; likewiſe little white Spots in the ſurface of the Nails like little Clouds.
list.label: Nephritica
list.item: are Medicines againſt the Diſeaſes of the Reins.
list.label: Nephriticus
list.item: is one who is troubled with a Diſeaſe in the Reins.
list.label: Nephritis
list.item: is a Pain in the Reins, proceeding either from an ill Diſpoſition, or an Inflammation, or from the Stone and Gravel, accompanied with Vomiting and Stretching of the Thigh.
list.label: Nephros
list.item:
is a Kidney, on each ſide of the Abdomen one, placed about the Loins under the Liver and Spleen; it is ſhaped like a Kidney Bean:
Its Subſtance is made up of a great company of little Conduits. On both ſides it receives the Serum from the Glandules which border upon the Arteries, and carries it to the little Bodies in the Reins called Carunculae Papillares (which ſee) that ſo it may be diſcharged by the Pelvis, the Baſin, the Ureters, the Bladder, &c.
list.label: Nervus, a Nerve,
list.item: is a fibrous, round, long, white, porous Subſtance like an Indian Cane, which conveys the Animal Spirits to make the parts of the Body moveable and ſenſible. Ten pair of Nerves proceed from the oblongated Marrow within the Scull: As the Odoratory, and Opthalmick Nerve, that which moves the Eyes; the Pathetick, the Guſtatory, or that which perceives Taſtes; the Nerve called Timidus or fearful, that which ſerves the Organ of Hearing; the Parvagum, that which moves the Tongue, and the Muſcles of the Neck. The Ancients only acknowledg Seven pair within the Scull. Below the Scull they reckon Thirty pair; ſeven from the Spinal Marrow in the Neck; twelve from the ſame in the Back; five from the Loins, and ſix from the Os Sacrum: All the Nerves below the Scull proceed from the Spinal Marrow, which paſs through the holes in the ſides of the Vertebres, and are deſigned for the uſe of the Limbs and great Cavities. A Nerve, a Tendon, and a Ligament are impertinently taken for one and the ſame thing by Chirurgeons.
list.label: Neurodes
list.item:
is a ſort of lingring Fever, ſo called by the moſt Learned Willis; becauſe that the nervous Juice, departing from its own right natural
Craſis, becomes the occaſion of an Atrophae.
list.label: Neurologia
list.item: is an elegant Deſcription of the Nerves, which Willis has performed beyond any Man whatſoever.
list.label: Neuron,
list.item: the ſame that Nervus.
list.label: Neurotica
list.item: are Remedies againſt the Diſeaſes of the Nerves.
list.label: Neurotomia
list.item: is an Anatomical Section of Nerves; alſo a pricking of Nerves.
list.label: Neurotomus
list.item: is one who is troubled with a pricking of the Nerves. Or one who diſſects them Anatomically.
list.label: Neuritica,
list.item: the ſame that Neurotica.
list.label: Nidroſa Dyſpepſia;
list.item: ſee Dyſpepſia.
list.label: Nidus,
list.item: the ſame that Focus.
list.label: Noctambulo, or Noctambulus,
list.item: is one who walks in his Sleep, opens Doors and Windows, and goes over the higheſt and moſt dangerous Places without perceiving it: The Cauſe of it is hardly to be given, unleſs Sleep be divided into Total and Partial; the Total is common ordinary Sleep, but the Partial takes place in this caſe, becauſe that Objects are ſeen indeed, and are offered to the common Senſory, but penetrate not to the place of Imagination, ſo that they may be perceived.
list.label: Nodulus, Nodus,
list.item: is a Bag of ſuitable Ingredients as the Diſeaſe requires, put into Beer or Wine, the Tincture whereof the Patient is to drink.
list.label: Nodus,
list.item: the ſame that Ganglion and Nodulus.
list.label: Noli me tangere
list.item:
is a ſort of Canker in the Face, eſpecially above the Chin. There ariſes a Tumour or Ulcer about the Mouth and Noſe, like
an exulcerated Canker, which grows ſlowly at the beginning, like a little Pimple; it remains a whole Year, otherwiſe is leſs troubleſome than a Canker, which gnaws and eats more in one Day than a Noli me tangere doth in a Month.
list.label: Nomas
list.item: is a putrid Ulcer that feeds upon the parts.
list.label: Noſocomium
list.item: is an Hoſpital for poor ſick People, where they are attended, and cured, if poſſible.
list.label: Noſologia,
list.item: the ſame that Pathalogia.
list.label: Noſos,
list.item: the ſame that Morbus.
list.label: Notae maternae,
list.item: the ſame that Naevius.
list.label: Nothae coſtae
list.item: are the five loweſt Ribs on each Side, called Baſtard Ribs, ſo called becauſe they do do not join with the Breaſt-Bone as other Ribs, nor are as the others Boney but Cartilaginous. Diſeaſes are likewiſe called Nothi, or Baſtard, which exceed the ordinary and common Rule; as tertain, quartane, or quotidian Baſtard Agues; a Baſtard Plurify. &c.
list.label: Nothis
list.item: is the Back, the back part of the Cheſt.
list.label: Novacula
list.item: is a Chirurgeons Knife, the ſhape whereof differs according to the difference of Operations: And therefore can hardly be deſcribed.
list.label: Nubeculae
list.item: are little light Particles which mutually, but looſely, cloſe with one another, and ſwim upon the Urine.
list.label: Nucha
list.item: is the hinder part, or nap of the Neck, called Cervix.
list.label: Nucioſitas,
list.item: the ſame that Myopia.
list.label: Numero,
list.item: not only Fruits and Seeds are meaſured by Number, but likewiſe the parts of Animals, as Yolks of Eggs. It is commonly noted thus, No or Num.
list.label: Nutrimentum,
list.item: the ſame that Alimentum.
list.label: Nutritio
list.item: is a natural Increaſe, whereby that which continually decays of any corporeal Subſtance, is repaired by convenient Nouriſhment.
list.label: Nux
list.item: is a ſort of Pain in the Head, which afflicts a place about as big as a Nut; as an Ovum, a Clavus, and other ſorts.
list.label: Nychthemerum
list.item: is four and twenty hours ſpace.
list.label: Nyctalopia
list.item: is two-fold: the firſt is a Dimneſs of Sight in the Night, or in dark Places, without any Impediment in the Light: The other is a Dimneſs in the Light, and clear Sight in the Night, or in Shades.
list.label: Nymphae
list.item: are little pieces of Fleſh in a Woman's Secrets. So called becauſe they ſtand near the Water that comes out of the Bladder. Alſo the hollowneſs or void ſpace in the nether Lip.
list.label: Nymphomania,
list.item: the ſame that Furor Ʋterinus.
list.label: Nymphotomia
list.item: is a cutting off the Nymphae, the too great Protuberance whereof in marriageable Virgins ſometimes hinders the Enjoyment, or at leaſt renders it difficult. The Egyptians cut them frequently.

list.head: O.
list.label: OBelaea
list.item: is the Sagittalis Suture in the Scull (ſee Sagittalis) which touches the Coronalis Suture forward, and the Lamdoides backward; for it is made of the mutual Conjunction of the Bones of the Forehead.
list.label: Oblatae Laxativae & Purgantes
list.item: are made of Meal with Sugar and purging Ingredients.
list.label: Oblivio, Forgetfulneſs,
list.item: is a loſs of the Ideas of Things once perceived out of the Brain. Which happens when things make but a light Impreſſion upon the Brain; as a light Motion is ſcarce perceived, ſo a light Impreſſion eaſily decays.
list.label: Obolus
list.item: is half a Scruple; it weighs ten Grains. Phyſitians mark it thus ∽, but now the Hollanders do not uſe this Character.
list.label: Obſtructio
list.item: is a ſhutting up of the Paſſages of the Body either by Contraction, or by ſome forreign Body that has entered within them.
list.label: Occiput
list.item: is the hinder part of the Scull.
list.label: Ochema
list.item: is a Liquor or Vehicle wherewith Medicines are mixed.
list.label: Ochthodes
list.item: are Ulcers whoſe ſides are callous, or of the nature of Warts, but not malignant.
list.label: Oculares dentes,
list.item: the Eye-Teeth: The ſame that Cynodontes.
list.label: Oculus, the Eye,
list.item:
is the external Organ of Sight; it is compounded of ſix Muſcles, to wit of two Direct, and as many Tranſverſe, to which a ſeventh is added in Brutes. It has ſeven Tunics, the Adnata, Innominata, Cornea, Ʋvea,
Retiformis, Chryſtallina, and Vitrea. It has alſo the Optick Nerve, the Iris, and the Pupilla. See them ſingly in their proper places.
list.label: Oculi
list.item: are the forerunners of Flowers, which are likewiſe called Gemmae, Buds.
list.label: Odaxiſmus
list.item: is the itching of the Gums, when Children breed Teeth.
list.label: Odontagra,
list.item: ſee Forfex.
list.label: Odonthalgia
list.item: is the Teeth-ach; which is cauſed by black rotten Teeth, or an Efferveſcence of fixed and acid Salt; and therefore it is called the Gout in the Teeth. Cold alſo will cauſe it.
list.label: Odontiaſis,
list.item: the ſame that Dentitio, and Odontophyia.
list.label: Odontica
list.item: are Medicines againſt Pains in the Teeth.
list.label: Odontoides,
list.item: that which is like a Tooth; as the Tooth of the ſecond Vertebre, and of other Bones.
list.label: Odontophyja,
list.item: breeding of Teeth.
list.label: Odoramentum
list.item: is a Medicine applyed for its Smell. It is compounded of Laudunum, Storax, Benzoin, Musk, Civet, &c.
list.label: Odoratus, the Smell,
list.item: is a Sence whereby odoriferous Effluviums are offered and repreſented to the common Senſory, from the Motion and Irritation of Nerves, implanted in the Membranes of the Noſe.
list.label: Oeconomia
list.item: is the management of Family-Concerns.
list.label: Oedema
list.item:
is ſometimes taken in a large Sence by Hippocrates, for any Tumor, but ſtrictly for a white, ſoft, inſenſible Tumor proceeding from
pituitous Matter heaped up together. It has no Pulſe, and yields eaſily to the Fingers. It may proceed likewiſe in ſome meaſure from the Lympha or nutritious Juice extravaſated and turned into a Gelly.
list.label: Oenoides
list.item: is diluted Wine, or a Liquor Analogous to Wine.
list.label: Oenomel
list.item: is Wine and Honey.
list.label: Oeſophagaeus
list.item: is a Muſcle that cloſes the Gullet, called Sphincter.
list.label: Oeſophagus,
list.item: the Gullet, is a membranaceous Pipe reaching from the Palate to the Stomach, whereby the Meat, chawed in the Mouth and mixed with the Juice there, paſſes to the Ventricle: It has three Tunics; the outermoſt or membranaceous Tunic, which comes from the Peritonaeum, or inner rine of the Belly, and clothes the Ventricle. The innermoſt is Muſculous; the whole Oeſophagus ſeems to conſiſt of two Muſcles, which with their oppoſite Fibres croſſing one another make four Parallelograms. The Third is altogether Nervous, which is covered on the inſide with an hairy ſort of Coat, and which may paſs for a fourth Tunic.
list.label: Oeſypus,
list.item: the Filth and Greaſineſs of Sheep, proceeding of Sweat, and cleaving faſt to their Wooll. Therefore they are miſtaken who take it to ſignify the little Clods of Dung that ſtick to their Wooll.
list.label: Olecranum, or Ancon,
list.item: is the greater Proceſs of the firſt Bone of the Cubit called Ʋlna. Alſo the upper part of the Shoulder.
list.label: Olecranus,
list.item: the ſame that Anconaeus.
list.label: Olfactus,
list.item: the ſame that Odoratus.
list.label: Oligophoros
list.item: is a ſmall Wine, with few Spirits.
list.label: Oligotrophia
list.item: is a Decreaſe of Nutrition.
list.label: Oligotrophus
list.item: is Meat that nouriſhes little, to which is oppoſed Polytrophus, that which affords much Nouriſhment.
list.label: Omentum, Reticulum,
list.item: the Cawle, is a double Membrane ſpread upon the Inteſtines, interwoven with Fat and Veſſels like a Fiſher's Net, enriched alſo with two or three Glandules, annexed to the Stomach, the Gut Colon, and the Pancreas, and uſeful to cheriſh the Inteſtines with its warmth: It hath ſome milky and Lymphatic Veſſels, as alſo a great many Ductus's and little Bags of Fat, concerning which ſee our Reformed Anatomy.
list.label: Omoplata, and Homoplata,
list.item: the ſame that Scapula.
list.label: Omphalocele
list.item: is a Rupture about the Navel, to wit, when the Cawle or Inteſtines are protuberant in that part: Which happens from a Relaxation, or burſting of the Peritonaeum, the inner rine of the Belly.
list.label: Omphalos,
list.item: ſee Ʋmbilicus.
list.label: Onyx,
list.item: ſee Ʋnguis.
list.label: Ophiaſis
list.item: is when the Hairs grow thin and fall off here and there, ſo that they leave the Head ſpotted like a Serpent.
list.label: Opthalmia
list.item: is an Inflammation of the Tunics of the Eyes, proceeding from arterious Blood, collected and extravaſated there, becauſe it cannot return by the Veins.
list.label: Opiata, or Electuarium,
list.item:
is a Medicine taken inwardly, of a conſiſtence like to thoſe Opiates
in the Shops, (Triacle or Mithridate) and is made up into ſeveral Doſes of ſeveral Ingredients mixed with Honey or Syrup.
list.label: Opiatum
list.item: is a Medicine in form of an Electuary with Opiate mixed in it: As Triacle, Mithridate, Dias-Cordium, &c.
list.label: Opiologia
list.item: is a Deſcription of Opium.
list.label: Opiſthotonus, or Tetanus,
list.item: is a kind of Cramp, or ſtretching of the Muſcle of the Neck backwards; which proceeds ſometimes from a Palſy of the Muſcles in the Neck, whereupon the Antagoniſts or oppoſite Muſcles move the intermediate parts too much; or from a ſharp and ſerous Matter in the Tendons; or from the Animal Spirits which enter the Fleſhy Pipes more than is uſual and will not eaſily recede, ſo that the parts are ſwelled and wrinkled up.
list.label: Opium
list.item: is the condenſed Juice of Poppies; the pureſt Opium is made of white Drops.
list.label: Opticus Nervus, or Viſorius, the Optic Nerve
list.item: is that which carries the viſible Species from the Eye to the common Senſory. The Nerves of both Eyes proceed from the Thalami of the Optic Nerves, afterwards theſe Nerves come together, and as they enter the Scull ſeparate again. Optica are Medicines againſt Diſtempers of the Eyes.
list.label: Orchis
list.item:
is a Teſticle, whoſe Subſtance in Men is nothing elſe but a Contexture of very little Veſſels which make the Seed: But it is quite otherwiſe in Women; where they are made of ſeveral Membranes and little Fibres looſely united to one another, betwixt which ſeveral white Bodies are found, which are there either
naturally or preternaturally: The Teſticles of Women breed Eggs, and therefore they are rightly called Ovaria. They are alſo called Teſtes, Colei.
list.label: Orchotomus
list.item: is a Gelder: One who gelds Animals that they cannot copulate.
list.label: Orexis
list.item: is a Natural Appetite of Meat, which proceeds from an acid Ferment in the Ventricles that comes from the Caeliac Arteries, with which the nervous Tunic of the Stomach and its Nerves are extraordinarily moved to covet Nouriſhment.
list.label: Organum
list.item: is a part which requires a right and determinate and ſenſible Conformation to its conſtitution and the performance of its Actions; as an Arm, Muſcle, Heart, &c.
list.label: Orgaſmus
list.item: is an Impetus and quick Motion of Blood or Spirits; as when the Animal Spirits ruſh violently upon the Nerves.
list.label: Oroboidcs
list.item: is a ſubſiding in Urine, like to a kind of Pulſe called Vetches.
list.label: Orthocolon
list.item: is a preternatural Rectitude of a Joint.
list.label: Orthopnaea
list.item: is an ill Reſpiration, when the Perſon affected cannot breathe but with his Neck erect.
list.label: Os, a Bone,
list.item:
is an hard, dry, and cold Subſtance, conſiſting eſpecially of earthy and ſaline Particles, deſigned for the upholding of the Body, to render its Motion eaſy, and for a Fence for ſeveral parts. Some make their Number 249, others commonly 304, and others as many as the Days of the Year. Yet the number of them is uncertain, becauſe the Bones of Infants
differ from thoſe of Adult Perſons. Alſo becauſe the Bones called Seſamoidea (ſee them in their proper place) and the Teeth are not determined to a certain number in old Men and Adult Perſons. They are of different Shapes, ſome are round, others plain, acute, obtuſe, hollow, ſpungy, ſolid, oblong, triangular, &c. A Nut-Shell is alſo called Oſſiculum.
list.label: Oſcitatio, Yawning,
list.item: is a certain light convulſive Motion of Muſcles which open the lower Jaw of the Face. Some look upon it as a light Motion whereby Excrementitious and Halituous Matter, which irritates the neighbouring parts, is expelled.
list.label: Oſcula
list.item: are the openings of Veſſels at the end.
list.label: Oſculum uteri
list.item: is the Cavity where Conception is made and the Mans Yard enters; it is ſo ſmall in Maids that it can only receive the bigneſs of a ſmall Pen we uſe for Writing Tables, and you cannot thruſt your leaſt Finger into it by any means; the Courſes flow out of it. It ſticks out in the Vagina, and is like the Mouth of a Tench, or, as Galen will rather have it, like the Nut of a Man's Yard; it has a tranſverſe cleft; in Virgins 'tis very ſmall, but grows bigger in Women who have had many Children; if it be too much ſtretched, or exulcerated, covered over with a Scarr, or too moiſt, Barrenneſs follows thereupon.
list.label: Oſteologia
list.item: is a Deſcription of Bones.
list.label: Oſteon,
list.item: ſee Os.
list.label: Oſtocopi,
list.item: are Pains in the Bones, or rather in the Membranes and Nerves about the Bones: For Bones as ſuch are inſenſible.
list.label: Otalgia
list.item: is a Pain in the Ears, whenceſoever it proceeds.
list.label: Otenchyta
list.item: an auricular Clyſter. Celſus calls it, Oegin. A little Syringe or Squirt which injects Medicines into the Ears.
list.label: Otica
list.item: are Medicines againſt Diſtempers in the Ears.
list.label: Ovarium
list.item: is a Womans Teſticle.
list.label: Oviductus,
list.item: the ſame that Tuba Fallopiana.
list.label: Ovum
list.item: is a ſort of pain in the Head affecting a place about the bigneſs of an Egg.
list.label: Oxelaeum
list.item: is a mixture of Vinegar with Oyl.
list.label: Oxycratum
list.item: is a mixture of Vinegar with Water, called Puſca or Poſca.
list.label: Oxydercica
list.item: are Medicines which quicken the Sight.
list.label: Oxygala
list.item: is ſowre Milk.
list.label: Oxymel
list.item: is a compoſition of Vinegar and Honey, like a Syrup.
list.label: Oxyregmia
list.item: is an acid ſowre Belch from the Stomach.
list.label: Oxyrhodinum
list.item: is Vinegar of Roſes, mixed with Roſe Water, or ſo.
list.label: ὈΣY NO'ΣHMA,
list.item: the ſame that Morbus acutus.
list.label: Ozoena
list.item: is an Ulcer in the inſide of the Noſtrils that ſmells ill.

list.head: P.
list.label: PAchuntica
list.item: are Medicines of a thickning nature, but withal cold, and full of thick and boughy parts, which if they are mix'd with a thin Juice, by joyning and ſtifning the Parts one with another, make a more Denſe and firm Compoſition as Bole-armoniack, Mill-duſt, Water-lillies, Almonds, Poppies, &c.
list.label: Paedotropica
list.item: is a part of Hygrena that concerns the Management of Boys.
list.label: Palatum
list.item: the Palate is the upper part of the Mouth, which becauſe it ſomewhat reſembles the upper part of an Houſe, is thence called the Roof of the Mouth.
list.label: Palliatio, or Cura Palativa,
list.item: is a Medicine which helps (as much as is poſſible) incurable Diſeaſes by the Application of preſent Remedies.
list.label: Palindrome
list.item: is a Diſeaſe into which one relapſes.
list.label: Palma
list.item: is the inſide of a Man's Hand, which we call the Palm.
list.label: Palmus
list.item: is a Shivering, or palpitation of the Heart, cauſed by a Convulſion, or Irritation of the Nerves; the cauſe whereof conſiſts in the Blood or nervous Juice, or in the Water in the Membrane that covers the Heart.
list.label: Palpebrae
list.item: are the Coverings of the Eyes, made up of a Skin, a fleſhy Membrane, Muſcles, a Tunick, and another little Skin called Tarſus, with Hair upon the uppermoſt Skin: They are either the upper or the under Eye-lids.
list.label: Palpitatio cordis naturalis,
list.item: the natural Palpitation of the Heart, is in the Syſtole thereof, whilſt the Cone and the Sides are preſs'd together, the Baſis and the Roots of the Veſſels, being blown up with the Blood that gathers there, grows big and ſwoln. It oft proceeds from an extraordinary Contraction of the Heart, or a thick and irritating Matter which ſticks in the Heart.
list.label: Panacaea
list.item: is a general ſort of Phyſick for all Diſeaſes indifferently; but I queſtion if there be any ſuch thing. Many People brag much of Tobacco, Tincture of the Sun, the Philoſophers-ſtone, vitriolated Tartar, &c.
list.label: Panaritium,
list.item: vid. Paronychia.
list.label: Pancaenus,
list.item: vid. Pandemius.
list.label: Panchymagoga
list.item: are purgative Medicines that expel all corrupt Humours.
list.label: Pancreas, the Sweet-bread, Pancration, Pancreon, Callicreas, Callicreon, & Lactes,
list.item: are all ſynonimous. It is a conglomerated Glandule in the Abdomen, placed behind the Ventricle, and faſtened to the Gut Duodenum, and reaches as far as the Liver and the Spleen; the Uſe and Office thereof is to convey a volatile, Inſipid, and Lymphatick Juice, or as others will have it (for 'tis a diſputable Point) a ſomething acid Juice, by its own Ductus to the Gut Duodenum, in order to a farther Fermentation and Volatiliſation of the Chyle, and to attemperate and allay the Qualities of the Gall: It is the biggeſt Glandule in the whole Body, but bigger in a Dog than a Man.
list.label: Pandalea,
list.item: as the modern Phyſicians call it, is the ſame with a ſolid Electuary, but that it remains intire, for the Sugar being rightly boiled is let grow hard; the Patient takes a piece of it like a Lambative; it only in the ſhape differs from Rolls and Morſels.
list.label: Pandemius
list.item: is a Diſeaſe which is rife in ſome places or other.
list.label: Pandiculatio
list.item: is a certain Dilatation and convulſive Diſtenſion of the Muſcles, by which the Vapours that annoy them are caſt off.
list.label: Panicus
list.item: is a ſudden Fear or Conſternation.
list.label: Panniculus Carnoſus
list.item: is a fat ſort of Membrane, in ſome parts thick and muſculous; in other parts thin, with many Ductus's of Fat in it; it covers the whole Body.
list.label: Panus
list.item: is a ſort of Botch or Sore under the Arm-pits, Jaws, Ears, and Groins, to wit, in the Glandulous Parts. It is alſo taken for Phygethus.
list.label: Papillae Inteſtinorum
list.item: are little Glandules wherewith the in-moſt Tunick of the Entrails is full, they ſoak in the percolated Chyle, and diſpenſe it to the lacteal Veins.
list.label: Papilla
list.item: is a red Excreſcency in the middle of the Breaſt, in the Pores whereof are received all the milky Tubes or Pipes, proceeding from the Glandules of the Breaſts.
list.label: Papillarum proceſſus
list.item: are the Extremities of the Olfactory Nerves, which convey the ſlimy, viſcous Humours by the Fibres, which perforate the Os cribriforme to the Noſtrils and Palate.
list.label: Papulae, vid. Puſtulae,
list.item: alſo a kind of ſmall Pox. See Exanthemata.
list.label: Paracelſiſtica Med.
Paracenteſis, or Punctio,
list.item: is a Perforation of the Cheſt and Abdomen through a cuſpidate Channel: It hapens in the Breaſt when it is ſtuff'd with putrified Matter, or Water, and then there's a pricking in the ſide between the fifth and ſixth Vertebre. It happens in the Abdomen, when it is ſwell'd by a Dropſy near the white Seam in the Abdomen, in the Muſcles that either aſcend right or oblique. If a Man be ſtrong and has taken a Purge, and alſo his Lungs, and the reſt of his Entrails be uncorrupted, when the Navel doth protuberate, don't look another way, for there you muſt make the Inciſion; don't let Purulency and Water come out both together, for that were to kill the Patient, but one after the other, as in ſeven days a pound, or a pound and an half as the Patient can endure it: After the Operation is finiſhed, draw the Wound up with an aſtringent Plaiſter: If the inward Veſſels and Paſſages be broke through this pricking, it's to no purpoſe to endeavour the Cure.
list.label: Paracheteuſis,
list.item: vid. Derivatio.
list.label: Paracmaſtica
list.item: is a daily declining Feaver, alſo declining Age.
list.label: Paracme,
list.item: vid. in Acme.
list.label: Parachynanche
list.item: is an Inflammation with a continual Feaver and difficulty of Breathing, excited in the outward Muſcles of the Larynx.
list.label: Paralyſis
list.item:
is an Aboition of voluntary Motion, or Senſe, or both, either in all the Body, or only ſome part. It comes by either an Obſtruction, Obſciſſion, Contuſion, or preſſing of the Nerves,
or by an Indiſpoſition, or ill Conformity of the Muſcles.
list.label: Parameſus
list.item: is the next Finger to the middle one, called the Ring-finger.
list.label: Paraphimoſis
list.item: is a fault of the Yard, when the Praeputium's too ſhort; alſo a Narrowneſs and Contraction of the Womb.
list.label: Paeraphrenitis
list.item: is Madneſs accompanied with a continual Feaver through the Inflammation of the Midriff, with difficulty of breathing as the Ancients dream'd. But Dr. Willis has confuted this Opinion of it, and ſays the matter of it lies in the Cerebellum, whereby the Animal Spi-Spirits cannot flow, and thence the Midriff and Lungs are troubled.
list.label: Paraphroſyne
list.item: is a ſlight ſort of Doting in the Imagination and Judgment.
list.label: Paraphlegia
list.item: is a Palſy which ſeizeth all the parts of the Body below the Head, through an Obſtruction of the ſpinal Marrow.
list.label: Paraplexia,
Pararythmus
list.item: is a preternatural Breathing.
list.label: Paraſtatae,
list.item: vid. Epididymis.
list.label: Paraſananche
list.item: is an Inflammation of the Muſcles of the upper part of the Aeſophagus with a continued Feaver.
list.label: Paremptoſis
list.item: is a falling, as when Blood ſlides from the Heart into the great Artery.
list.label: Parencephalos,
Perenchymata
list.item: are Entrails by which the Blood paſſes for better Fermentation and Perfection, as the Lungs, Liver, Heart, and Spleen, &c. Sometimes Parenchyma is taken in a large Sence for all the Entrails.
list.label: Pariſthmia, or Amygdalae,
list.item: are two Glandules tied together by a broad ſlender Production, they have one common Cavity large and oval, opening into the Mouth; the Uſe they ſerve for is, to tranſmit a certain ſlimy or pituitous Matter into the Jaws and Mouth: They are called alſo Tonſillae.
list.label: Paronychia
list.item: is a preternatural Swelling in the Fingers end very troubleſome; it riſes from a ſharp, malign Humour; which can gnaw the Tendons Nerves, the Membrane about the Bone, and the very Bone it ſelf.
list.label: Parotides
list.item: are Glandules behind the Ears, alſo a preternatural Swelling of thoſe Glandules.
list.label: Paroxyſmus a Fit,
list.item: is part of the Period of Diſeaſes, whereby they encreaſe and grow worſe. It is either Ordinate, which returns at certain times, as in a Tertian Ague; or Inordinate, that has no certain time, but comes ſometimes one day, ſometims another, as the Erratick Ague.
list.label: Pars, a part,
list.item: is a Piece of the whole ſerving each for their proper Uſes. The Parts are either ſenſible or inſenſible, ſpermatick or bloody, ſimilar, or the contrary; organical or inorganical, principal or inſervient.
list.label: Partus
list.item: is the bringing forth of a Mature Faetus, or Young, in natural Births. The Faetus having broken the Membranes, turns his Head forward, and inclining it towards the neck of the Womb, ſtrives to get forth; the uſual manner is after nine Months; yet I have known ſome at Amſterdam born at ſeven Months, who have lived to fifty or ſixty.
list.label: Partus Caeſareus
list.item: is when Children are forc'd for want of Paſſage to be cut out.
list.label: Partus difficilis,
Parylis
list.item: is an Inflammation, Rottenneſs, or Excreſcency beſides the Gums.
list.label: Paſſio,
list.item: vid. Pathema.
list.label: Paſtillum
list.item: is a ſweet Ball compos'd of ſweet Duſt, Wax, the Gum-Storax, and India-Balſam with a little Goats-flower and Turpentine; it ſerves for Swelling.
list.label: Patella,
list.item: vid. Mola Genu.
list.label: Pathema
list.item: is all preternatural Conturbation wherewith our Body is moleſted.
list.label: Patheticus
list.item: is the Nerve of the fourth pair within the Scull, as Dr. Willis ſaith, tho Fallopius reckons it one of the eighth pair.
list.label: Pathognomonicum
list.item: is a proper ſeparable Sign, which agrees only to ſuch a thing, and to all of that kind, and tells the Eſſence of its Subject, and alſo laſts from the beginning to the • nd; as in a true Pluriſy, there's always a continual Fever, hard Breathing, and Stitches, and a Cough.
list.label: Pathologia
list.item: is a part of Phyſick that teacheth us the preternatural Conſtitution of a Man's Body.
list.label: Pathos,
list.item: vid. Pathema.
list.label: Pectoralia pectoral Medicines,
list.item: are ſuch, as either by attenuating, or thinking, or allaying, render the Matter which cauſes coughing fit to be expectorated.
list.label: Pectus
list.item: is the fore-moſt part of the Thorax reaching from the Neck-bone down to the Midriff.
list.label: Pedicularis Morbus,
list.item: vid. Phthiziaſis.
list.label: Pedium,
list.item: vid. Tarſus.
list.label: Pelicanatio Chymica,
list.item: vid. Circulatio Chymica.
list.label: Pelidnus
list.item: is a black and blew Colour in the Face, frequent in Melancholick Men.
list.label: Pelvis
list.item: is the place at the bottom of the Belly, wherein the Bladder and Womb are contain'd.
list.label: Pelvis Aurium,
list.item: vid. Cochlea.
list.label: Pelvis Cerebrs,
list.item: vid. Choana.
list.label: Pelvis Renum
list.item: is a membranous Veſſel or Receptacle in either Vein, which receives the Urine and pours it into the Bladder.
list.label: Pemphigodes Febris
list.item: is a Spotted Fever; ſome ſay a windy, a flatulent Fever.
list.label: Penis
list.item: is the Yard, made up of two nervous Bodies, the Channel, Nut, Skin and Foreskin, &c.
list.label: Penis Muliebris,
list.item: vid. Clytoris.
list.label: Pepanſis
list.item: is a rectifying and bringing to order of the vitiated and corrupt Humours.
list.label: Pepaſmus
list.item: is a Concoction, or rather a Fermentation, or ripening of preternatural Humours; which is twofold, One tends to an end, as in an Inflammation; the Other hath no Fermentation, as when it cannot conquer the Diſeaſe.
list.label: Pepaſticum
list.item: is a Medicine that allays and digeſts the Crudities.
list.label: Pepſis
list.item: is the Concoction or Fermentation of the Humours and Meat in a Man's natural Conſtitution, as when Meat is turn'd into Chyle, and that into Blood.
list.label: Peracutiſſimus Morbus,
list.item: vid. Acutus M.
list.label: Peracutus,
list.item: vid. Acutus.
list.label: Perfecta Criſis,
list.item: vid. Criſis.
list.label: Periamma
list.item: is a Medicine which being tied about the Neck, is believ'd to expel Diſeaſes, eſpecially the Plague.
list.label: Periaptum,
list.item: vid. Periamma.
list.label: Pericardium
list.item: is a Membrane which ſurrounds the whole Subſtance of the Heart, and contains a Liquor in it to refrigerate the Heart.
list.label: Pericholus
list.item: very Cholerick.
list.label: Pericranium
list.item: is a Membrane which infolds the Scull.
list.label: Perinaeum
list.item: is the ligamentous Seam betwixt the Cod and the Fundament.
list.label: Periodus Morborum
list.item: is the ſpace betwixt the coming of fits of Sickneſs in intermitting Diſeaſes.
list.label: Periodus Sanguinis
list.item: is a continued Circulation of the Blood through the Body, which is thus. The Blood is carried out of the Arteries by Fibres, either of the Fleſh or of the Entrails, or the membranous parts to the Mouths of the greater Veins. Now we ſay that thoſe Fibres are terminated at the Mouths of the Veins, and implanted in them, as we ſee many other little Channels in the Veins; ſo the Blood, paſſing through theſe out of the Arteries, is preſently ſent to the Veins, that it may be carried back again to the right Ventricle of the Heart; and thence by an arterious Vein to the Lungs, in which after the Blood has been accended by ſome nitrous Particles, breathed in thither by the Air, it goes into the veinous Artery, thence into the left Ventricle of the Heart; which again empties it ſelf into the Aorta or great Artery; ſo that the Body may be nouriſhed and enliven'd, it goes into every part of it.
list.label: Perioſteum
list.item: is a thin Membrane that incloſes immediately the Bones, except a few.
list.label: Peripheria
list.item: is the Circumference of the Body, or any Entrail thereof.
list.label: Periphimoſis,
list.item: vid. Phimoſis.
list.label: Peripneumonia
list.item: is an Inflammation of the Lungs accompanied with a ſharp Fever, hard Breathing, a Cough, and an heavy Pain.
list.label: Periſiſtole
list.item: is the time of Reſt between the Contraction and Dilatation of the Heart.
list.label: Periſtalticus Motus
list.item: is a Crawling as it were of the Entrails, whereby the Excrements are voided. Alſo the motion of the Veſſels whereby Humours, as Water, Chyle, the Blood, &c. aſcend and deſcend.
list.label: Periſtromata
list.item: are the ſick Mans Bed-clothes; alſo the Tunicks about the Entrails.
list.label: Peritonaeum
list.item: is a Membrane which cloaths the whole Abdomen on the inſide, and its Entrails on the outſide: It conſiſts of two Tunicks.
list.label: Perittoma
list.item: is an Excrement in the Body, leſt after Digeſtion: Alſo the Reliques of Diſeaſes.
list.label: Pernio
list.item: is a preternatural Swelling caus'd by the Winter Cold, eſpecially in the Hands and Feet, which at laſt breaks out.
list.label: Perona
list.item: is alſo called Fibula, becauſe it joyns the Muſcles of the Leg, whence the firſt and ſecond Muſcle in the Leg is called Peronaeus. It is the leſs and ſlenderer Bone, which is faſtened outwardly to the greater Bone of the Leg, called Tibia.
list.label: Peronaeus,
list.item: vid. Perona.
list.label: Perperacutus,
list.item: vid. Acutus.
list.label: Paſſarium
list.item: is an oblong Medicine, which being made like the middle Finger, is thruſt up into the neck of the Womb, and is good againſt ſeveral Diſeaſes incident to it.
list.label: Peſſulus,
list.item: the ſame.
list.label: Peſſus,
list.item: the ſame.
list.label: Peſtis the Plague,
list.item: is an epidemick contagious Diſeaſe, ariſing from a poyſonous and too much exalted Nitre in the Air, which ſecretly takes a Man, extinguiſheth the Spirits, clods the Blood, deads the ſound parts, and is accompanied with Botches, Boils, and a train of other dreadful Symptomes.
list.label: Peſtaloides
list.item: is a ſort of Urine which ſeems to have little Leaves or Scales in it.
list.label: Petechialis
list.item: is a malignant Fever, call'd alſo Pulicaris, becauſe it makes the Skin look as tho it were Flea-bitten.
list.label: Petia
list.item: is Stuff that certain Phyſicians Bags are made of.
list.label: Petigo,
list.item: vid. Lichen.
list.label: Petroſum Os
list.item: is the inſide of the Bones of the Temples, ſo called from the Hardneſs thereof.
list.label: Phacia,
list.item: vid. Lenticula.
list.label: Phacos
list.item: is a Spot in the Face like a Nit, whence it is called Lenticula and Lentigo.
list.label: Phacotos
list.item: is a Chirurgical Inſtrument.
list.label: Phenomaena
list.item: are preternatural Appearances in the Body.
list.label: Phagadena
list.item: is an exulcerate Cancer.
list.label: Phalacroſis
list.item: is a falling off of the Hair.
list.label: Phalangoſis
list.item: is a fault of the Eye-lids, when there are two rows of Hair, or when the Hair grows inward and offends the Eyes.
list.label: Phalanx
list.item: is the Order and rank obſerved in the Finger-Bones.
list.label: Phantaſia
list.item:
is an internal Senſe or Imagination, whereby any thing is repreſented to the Mind, or impreſſed in it. It ſeems to be a certain Undulation, or waving of the Animal
Spirits in the middle of the Brain, which are afterwards expanded towards its Circumference.
list.label: Phantaſma
list.item: is the ſame with Phantaſia.
list.label: Pharmacum
list.item: is any ſort of Medicine againſt a Diſeaſe.
list.label: Pharmaceutica
list.item: the ſame that Pharmaca.
list.label: Pharmacia
list.item: is an art of collecting, chuſing, and compounding Medicines: The Apothecary's Art.
list.label: Pharmacopaea
list.item: is the Doctrine, or a Deſcription of things phyſical in order to cure.
list.label: Pharmacopaeus
list.item: is a Man that underſtands to make up Medicines; he is called the Right-hand of a Phyſician, and a Surgeon the left.
list.label: Pharyngetrum
list.item: is ſometimes uſed for the Pharinx, ſometimes for the Bone Hyades.
list.label: Pharyngotomia,
list.item: vid. Laryngotomia.
list.label: Pharynx
list.item: is the upper part of the Gullet, conſiſting of three pair of Muſcles.
list.label: Philtrum
list.item: is the hollow dividing the upper Lip; alſo a Love-cup.
list.label: Phimoſis,
list.item: the ſame that Paraphimoſis; alſo the Inverſion of the Eye-lids through an Inflammation.
list.label: Phleborragia
list.item: is the breaking of a Vein.
list.label: Phlebotomia
list.item: opening of a Vein.
list.label: Phebotomus
list.item: the Blood-letter; alſo an Inſtrument called a Phleme.
list.label: Phlegma
list.item:
is a ſlimy Excrement of the Blood, caus'd often by too much nitrous Air: It is likewiſe a watery diſtilled Liquor, oppoſite to ſpirituous Liquor; alſo thoſe Clouds which appear upon diſtilled Waters. Hippocrates uſes it
often for an Inflammation: It is alſo the Diſeaſe of Hens, called the Pip, and is ſometimes taken for a viſcous Excretion.
list.label: Phlegmagoga
list.item: are Medicines to drive away the Phlegme.
list.label: Phlegmaſia
list.item: an Inflammation, Heat or Burning.
list.label: Phlegmatici
list.item: thoſe that are much troubled with Phlegme.
list.label: Phlegmone
list.item: is a Tumour of the Blood in the Fleſh or Muſcles, cauſing Heat, Redneſs, Beating and Pain.
list.label: Phlegmonodes
list.item: is an Inflammation like the former.
list.label: Phlogoſis
list.item: the ſame that Phlegmone.
list.label: Phlyctaena
list.item: is a Pimple in the Skin; alſo a little Ulcer in the corneous Tunick of the Eye.
list.label: Phlyctenodes
list.item: are hot watery Puſtules, like the former.
list.label: Phaenygmus
list.item: is a Medicine that makes the Skin red.
list.label: Phrenes,
list.item: vid. Diaphragma.
list.label: Phreneſis
list.item: the ſame with Phrenitis.
list.label: Phrentiaſis
list.item: the ſame.
list.label: Phrenetici Nervi
list.item: are thoſe which belong to the Midriff.
list.label: Phrenetis
list.item: is a Dotage with a continual Fever, often accompanied with Madneſs and Anger, proceeding from too much Heat in the Animal Spirits, not from the Inflammation of the Brain, as the Antients thought. Willis thus defines it, namely, an Inflammation of the whole ſenſitive Soul and Animal Spirits.
list.label: Phricodes
list.item: is a dreadful Fever, whereby beſides the Heat, Men fancy terrible things.
list.label: Phtharticum
list.item: is a corrupting Medicine.
list.label: Phthiraſis
list.item: is the louſy Diſeaſe; alſo a skaly Scab of the Eye-brows.
list.label: Phthiſicus,
list.item: a Man in a Conſumption.
list.label: Phthiſis
list.item: a Conſumption of the whole Body, riſing from an Ulcer in the Lungs, accompanied with a ſlow continued Fever, ſmelling Breath and a Cough.
list.label: Phthoe,
list.item: the ſame.
list.label: Phygethlon
list.item: is a Swelling proceeding from an Inflammation of the Glandules, wherein Nature expels ſomething; as in the Plague about the Groins.
list.label: Phyma
list.item: is a Swelling: There are five ſorts, Verrucae, Calli, Vari Farunculi, & Hydroa, or Deſadationes. Of which in their order. Others reckon it a Tumour in the Glandules only, which quickly ſuppurates.
list.label: Phymatodes,
list.item: like the former.
list.label: Phyſema
list.item: an Inflammation in any part of the Body, as a Tympany; alſo the Roſine of the Pine.
list.label: Phyſeſis,
list.item: the ſame.
list.label: Phyſiognomica
list.item: are Signs whereby we conjecture ſomething by the Countenance.
list.label: Phyſiognomia
list.item: is the Art of knowing Natures.
list.label: Phyſiologia
list.item: is a part of Phyſick, that teaches the Conſtitution of the Body, ſo far as it is ſound.
list.label: Phyſocele,
list.item: vid. Pneumatocele.
list.label: Phyſodes
list.item: that which is very flatulent.
list.label: Pia Mater,
list.item: vid. Mater tenuis.
list.label: Pica,
list.item: vid. Citta.
list.label: Picatio,
list.item: vid. Iropaciſinus.
list.label: Picra,
list.item: vid. Hiera picra.
list.label: Pichrocholus
list.item: a Man troubled with a black Bile.
list.label: Pilula
list.item: is a ſolid Medicine, made like a little Ball of Powder, Gums, Extracts, &c. mixed with a glutinous Liquor.
list.label: Pili, the Hairs,
list.item: are round, oblong, ſlender Bodies, conſiſting of much Sulphur and Earth; and of different Colours according to the difference of the Conſtitution: They grow out at the Pores of the Skin, that the vapours may may more eaſily exhale through them, as through ſo many little Tubes or Pipes. I have diſcovered through my Microſcope ſeveral little Knots or Valves in them.
list.label: Pinealis Glandula,
list.item: vid. Conarium.
list.label: Pinguedo,
list.item: vid. Adeps.
list.label: Pinna Auris
list.item: is the upper and broader part of the Ear, called the Wing.
list.label: Pittacium
list.item: is a little Cloth ſpread with a Medicine, and applied to the part affected.
list.label: Pituita,
list.item: vid. Phlegma.
list.label: Pituitaria Glandula,
list.item: vid. Glandula pituitaria.
list.label: Pityriaſis,
list.item: vid. Fupfurratio.
list.label: Pityroides
list.item: a ſetling in the Urine like Bran.
list.label: Placenta Ʋterina
list.item:
is a red Subſtance, like the Liver, full of Glandulous Kernels: It has an Artery and a Vein from the Navel-ſtring, and perhaps lymphatick Veſſels from the neighbouring parts; outwardly ſticks to the Womb, to either ſide indifferently, yet more commonly to the middle; within it is covered with the Chorrium. It has its nouriſhing Moiſture from the Poroſities of the Womb, (as it happens with the Papillae of the Guts which drink in the Chyle and communicate it to the milky Veſſels) which through the Navel-vein feeds the Young. The ſuperfluous
part whereof the Arteries lodg in the Ammion, that the Young may be nouriſhed by its Mouth. The Placenta together with the Membranes is expelled after the Birth, and are called Secundinae, Secundines.
list.label: Pladaroſis
list.item: are little ſoft Tumors which grow under the Eye-lids.
list.label: Plagula,
list.item: vid. Splenia.
list.label: Planta Noctis,
list.item: vid. Sudamina & Hydroa.
list.label: Plaſtica Virtus
list.item: is that which can form or faſhion any thing; it's an old ſaying and a ſure Refuge of Ignorance, for what the Ancients could not explain they called a plaſtick Virtue.
list.label: Platiſma
list.item: is a broad Linnen-cloth put upon Sores.
list.label: Platyſma Myodes,
list.item: vid. Myodes.
list.label: Plectrum,
list.item: vid. Cion.
list.label: Plenitudo
list.item: is when a Man has too much Blood: The ſame that Plethora.
list.label: Plerotica
list.item: are Medicines that breed Fleſh and fill up Wounds.
list.label: Plethora,
list.item: when there's more good Blood than's requiſite. It happens either to the Veſſels, when they are ſtretcht out and cannot hold all; or to the Strength, for ſometimes tho the Veſſels be not over full, the Strength is over loaded.
list.label: Plethoricus,
list.item: a Man troubled with a Plethora.
list.label: Pleura
list.item: is a Membrane that incloſes the Breaſts and its Entrails.
list.label: Pleuritis
list.item:
a Pleuriſy, is a Inflammation of the Membrane Pleura, and the intercoſtal Muſcles, attended with a continual Fever and Stitches in the Side, difficulty of Breathing, and ſometimes ſpitting Blood, and it's either a true Pleuriſy,
this which we have deſcribed, or a baſtard Pleuriſy.
list.label: Pleuritis Notha
list.item: a baſtard Pleuriſy, that differs in ſome things from the other.
list.label: Plexus choroides
list.item: ſeems to hang over the pineal Glandule, as it were over a Button. It is an admirable Contexture of ſmall Arteries in the Brain like a Net.
list.label: Plexus nervoſus
list.item: is when two or three Nerves meet together and jut out.
list.label: Plexus reticularis,
list.item: vid. Choroides.
list.label: Plica
list.item: is an epidemical Diſeaſe in Polonia, when their Hairs grow together like a Cow's Tail; beſides, they are crook'd-back'd, have looſe Joynts, it wrenches their Limbs and looſens them, breeds Lice, with other Symptoms.
list.label: Pleumaceola,
list.item: vid. Splenia.
list.label: Pneumatocele
list.item: is a windy Rupture, when the Skin of the Cods is diſtended with Wind.
list.label: Pneumatodes
list.item: is a ſhort Breathing.
list.label: Pneumatoſis
list.item: is the Generation of Animal Spirits, which is performed in the barky Subſtance of the Brain; the little Arteries there are emptied, and the Spirits diſtil, which after they are come as far as the middle of the Brain, they actuate and Invigorate all the Nerves.
list.label: Pneumatomphalus
list.item: is a ſwelling in the Navel, got by Wind.
list.label: Pneumon,
list.item: the Lungs.
list.label: Pnigalium,
list.item: vid. Epialtes.
list.label: Pnigmus,
list.item: Strangling or Choaking.
list.label: Podagra,
list.item: vid. Arthritis, the Gout in the Feet.
list.label: Pollutio nocturna
list.item: is an involuntary Pollution in the Night, cauſed by lecherous Dreams.
list.label: Polychronius
list.item: is a Diſeaſe that holds a Man many Years or Months.
list.label: Polygophora
list.item: are Drinks or Wines full of excellent Spirits.
list.label: Polypus
list.item: is a Swelling in the hollow of the Noſtrils, and is twofold; either like a Tent, and goes by the general name of Sarcoma; or ſuch a one that has a great many diſtinct Branches or Feet, which extend either to the outſide of the Noſe or the inſide of the Mouth: Their Colour is white, oftentimes reddiſh, and ſometimes black and livid. Excreſcencies of this nature happen not only in the Noſtrils, but ſometimes in the Heart and in the Cavities of the thicker Membrane of the Brain.
list.label: Polytarcia,
list.item: Corpulency.
list.label: Pompholigodes,
list.item: Urine with many Bubbles upon it, which are frequent if the Body be puft up or pained.
list.label: Pomum Adami
list.item: is a Protuberance in the foreſide of the Throat; ſo called, becauſe 'tis commonly thought a piece of the Apple ſtuck in his Throat as part of his Puniſhment, and hence derived to his Poſterity.
list.label: Pondo
list.item: a Pound-weight. Joh. Rhodius writes, That of all the Roman Weights and Meaſures, a Pound was the chief and Standard of the Reſt.
list.label: Poplitea Vena,
list.item: a Vein that conſiſts of a double crural Branch, which being covered with Skin, reaches down the Back of the Leg even to the Heel.
list.label: Pori, Pores,
list.item: are little unperceptible Holes in the Skin, through which Sweat and other vaporous Effluviums perſpire through the Body.
list.label: Porocele
list.item: is a Rupture proceeding from callous Matter, or the Stone.
list.label: Poromphalus
list.item: is a brawny piece of Fleſh, or a Stone protuberant in the Navel.
list.label: Poroſis
list.item: is the breeding of callous Matter.
list.label: Porotica
list.item: are Medicines which by drying, thickening, and aſtringent Qualities turn part of the Nouriſhment into brawny callous Matter.
list.label: Porus bilarius, or Hepaticus,
list.item: is a Channel which tranſmits the Bile from the Liver, by the common Ductus or Paſſage, into the Gut Duodenum, which Bile is ſegregated in the Liver, by the Intervention of ſome ſmall Glandules.
list.label: Porrigo,
list.item: vid. Furfurratio.
list.label: Portae Vena,
list.item: vid. Vena.
list.label: Poſca,
list.item: vid. Oxycratum.
list.label: Poſtbrachiale,
list.item: vid. Metaca pus.
list.label: Potio,
list.item: vid. Hauſtus.
list.label: Praecipitatio
list.item: is a certain Subſiding and Reviviſcence of very ſmall Particles diſſolved in a convenient Liquor, by the Infuſion of another Liquor.
list.label: Praecordia
list.item: are all the Entrails in the Cheſt, or Thorax.
list.label: Praefocatio Ʋterina,
list.item: vid. Hyſterica paſſio.
list.label: Praeparantia Med.
list.item: vid. Digerentia.
list.label: Praeparantia vaſa,
list.item: the preparing Veſſels, are Veins and Arteries which go to the Teſticles and Epididymes (which ſee;) ſo called by the Ancients, thinking that they prepared the Seed: The Vein has ſeveral Branches and Anaſtomoſes; the Artery goes ſtreight on, but for two, or at the moſt three Diviſions, or Branches.
list.label: Praeputium
list.item: is the fore-Skin, alſo the Prominency of the Clytoris.
list.label: Praeſepia
list.item: the holes of either Jaw, wherein are contained the Teeth.
list.label: Praeſervatoria Indicatio
list.item: is a way whereby we prevent Diſeaſes.
list.label: Pregma,
list.item: vid. Bregma.
list.label: Presbytia
list.item: is a dimneſs of Sight in things nigh at hand, tho a Man ſee tolerably well things at a diſtance: Uſual with old Men.
list.label: Priapiſmus
list.item: is a continual Erection of the Yard without Luſt: Alſo the Yard it ſelf.
list.label: Primores Dentes
list.item: the fore-Teeth, wherewith we chaw our Meat, and which we ſhow in laughing.
list.label: Principes dies,
list.item: vid. Critici dies.
list.label: Principia,
list.item: vid. Elementa.
list.label: Probole,
list.item: vid. Apophiſia.
list.label: Procatarctica
list.item: is the pre-exiſtent Cauſe of a Diſeaſe, which co-operates with others that are ſubſequent; whether it be external or internal, as Anger, or Heat in the Air, which beget ill Juice in the Blood, and cauſe a Feaver.
list.label: Procatarxis,
list.item: the ſame.
list.label: Proceſſus,
list.item: vid. Apophyſis.
list.label: Proceſſus Peritonaei
list.item: are as it were two oblong Pipes or Channels, reaching to the Skin of the Cods through the Holes of the Tendons of the oblique and tranſverſe Muſcles, in which Productions, or Didymi, as the Ancients call'd them, the ſeminary Veſſels deſcend and return towards the Stones they grow under and cover them.
list.label: Procidentia Ani,
list.item: is a falling of the Gut Rectum by reaſon of too much looſeneſs through the Fundament.
list.label: Procidentia uteri,
list.item: is a relaxing of the inner Tunick of the Vagina of the Womb, which falls through the Privities, and was cut off by Phyſicians: Formerly, and even ſtill ſome think the Womb may fall down, but the Ligaments of the Womb hinder any ſuch fall.
list.label: Procondyli
list.item: are the Bones of the Fingers next the back of the Hand.
list.label: Prodromus
list.item: is a Diſeaſe that comes before a greater, as the ſtraitneſs of the Breaſt predicts a Conſumption, or the Rickets.
list.label: Productio,
list.item: vid. Apophyſis.
list.label: Proegumena
list.item: is an antecedent internal Cauſe of a Diſeaſe in the Body occaſioned by another, and ſo cauſing the Diſeaſe, that if it be taken away, the Diſeaſe may ſtill continue; as a Plethora, or ill Juice in the Blood, produced by an ill way of Diet, whence proceeds an Obſtruction of Veſſels and Paſſages, and a Conſtipation of the Entrails.
list.label: Prognoſis & Signa prognoſtica
list.item: are Signs whereby we know what will become of the Patient.
list.label: Projectura,
list.item: vid. Apophyſis.
list.label: Prolabia
list.item: the outmoſt prominent parts of the Lips.
list.label: Prolapſus uteri,
list.item: vid. Ʋteri prolapſus.
list.label: Prolepticus
list.item: is a Diſeaſe always anticipating; ſo as if the Ague come to day at four of the Clock, then to Morrow one Hour ſooner, and ſo on.
list.label: Prophaſis
list.item: is a Fore-knowledg in Diſeaſes; alſo an Occaſion or antecedent Cauſe.
list.label: Prophylactica
list.item:
is a part of that part of Phyſick called Hygieina, (or what reſpects the Preſervation
of Health) which gives notice of future but imminent Diſeaſes.
list.label: Prophylaxis,
list.item: the ſame.
list.label: Propoma
list.item: is a Drink made of Wine and Honey, or Sugar.
list.label: Propotiſma
list.item: is the taking a Doſe.
list.label: Proptoſis
list.item: is the falling down of ſome part, as of the Eye, the Caule, &c.
list.label: Proſpheromena
list.item: are Meats or Medicines taken inwardly.
list.label: Proſphyſis
list.item: is a Coalition, or growing together, as when two Fingers are connected to each other.
list.label: Proſtatae, Adſtantes, or Corpora glanduloſa,
list.item: are two Glandules under the ſeminal Bladders, near the Paſſage of the Seed, which (as may be gueſſed) Lubricitates the common Paſſage of the Seed and Urine, and is a Vehicle to the ſeminal Matter, and are ſaid to provoke the Titillation in Coition: Their Moiſture being conveyed by certain little Tubes, which terminate in the Paſſage near where the Seed is ejected, is emitted at the ſame time with it: The Learned Bartholine has obſerved ſome ſuch thing in Women.
list.label: Proſtethis
list.item: is the fore-ſide of the Breaſt; alſo a fleſhy part in the Hollows of the Feet and Hands, and betwixt the Fingers.
list.label: Proſteſis
list.item: a part of Surgery which fills up what is wanting; as we ſee in hollow and fiſtulous Ulcers fill'd up with Fleſh by Chirurgery.
list.label: Protopathia
list.item: is a primary Diſeaſe, not caus'd by another.
list.label: Protuberantia,
list.item: vid. Apophyſis.
list.label: Provocatorii Dies,
list.item: ſee Critici Dies, and Intercalares.
list.label: Pruna,
list.item: ſee Carbunculus.
list.label: Pruritus, the Itch,
list.item: is a dry Unevenneſs of the Skin cauſed by Saline fixed Particles, pricking the Skin, and kept in by others more retentive which cannot exhale.
list.label: Pſammiſmus,
list.item: a Bath of dry and warm Sand, wherewith the Feet of Men in the Dropſy are dryed.
list.label: Pſammodea
list.item: are ſandy and gravelly Matter in the Urine.
list.label: Pſammos,
list.item: a Gravel which breeds in Mens Bodies, and is voided in Fits of the Stone.
list.label: Pſilothron
list.item: is a Medicine wherewith Hairs are either taken out of the Body, or thinned, if they be extreme rough.
list.label: Pſoas
list.item: are Muſcles of the Loins, which proceed from about the two lowermoſt Vertebres of the Thorax, and the three uppermoſt Vertebres of the Loins or Flank: They deſcend obliquely upon the Rotator minor of the Thigh, and bend the Thigh.
list.label: Pſora
list.item: is a wild Scab that makes the Skin Scaly.
list.label: Pſoriaſis
list.item: is a dry itching Scab of the Cods, which is often accompanied with an Exulceration.
list.label: Pſorica
list.item: are Medicines againſt the Scab.
list.label: Pſorophthalmia
list.item: is an itching Scab of the Eyes.
list.label: Pſyctica
list.item: are cooling Medicines.
list.label: Pſydracia,
list.item:
according to Paulus and Alexander, are little Ulcers of the Skin of the Head, like thoſe which are wont to burn the Skin. Celſus
ſays, they are an hard ſort of Puſtle ſomething whitiſh, and acute, out of which is ſqueezed a moiſt Matter.
list.label: Pſydraces,
list.item: according to others, are little Puſtles or Pimples, which break out upon the Skin, like Bubbles, by reaſon of the Winter cold.
list.label: Pſylothrum,
list.item: ſee Pſilothron.
list.label: Ptarmica, or Sternuta loria,
list.item: are thoſe things which being endowed with a more piercing Acrimony than their Errhinaceous Medicines, do ſo extreamly irritate and ſhrivel up the Membranes of the Brain, that it ſends forth the pituitous Humour at the Noſtrils in an extraordinary Meaſure.
list.label: Pterna,
list.item: ſee Calx.
list.label: Pterygium
list.item: is the Wing or round Riſing of the Noſe or Eye, or the Proceſs of the Bone Sphenoides which is like a Wing. Alſo a membranous Excreſcence above the horney Tunic of the Eye, called Ʋnguis and Ʋngula, growing for the moſt part from the inner corner towards the Apple of the Eye, and often obſcuring it: Alſo the Nymphae of a Womans ſecret Parts.
list.label: Pterygoides
list.item: are the Proceſſes and Muſcles of the Wedg-like Bone.
list.label: Pteryſtaphylini
list.item: are Muſcles of the peice of Fleſh in the Roof of the Mouth called Gargareon, which proceed from the Wing-like Proceſſes, and are terminated in the ſides of the Ʋvula, or Gargareon.
list.label: Ptyloſis
list.item: is when the Brims of the Eye-lids being grown thick the Hairs of the Eye-Brows fall off.
list.label: Ptiſana,
list.item:
Ptiſan, is a Decoction of Barley
husked, Liquoriſh, Raiſins.
list.label: Ptyaliſmus
list.item: is a too great Spitting.
list.label: Ptyalon
list.item: is Spit, or that Matter which is brought up from the Lungs by Coughing; for Saliva (which we Engliſh Spittle too) properly ſignifies the Moiſture which is excerned by the Ductus Salivales.
list.label: Ptyſma,
list.item: ſee Ptyalon.
list.label: Pugillus
list.item: is an handful of any Herbs. Others interpret it as much as may be taken up with three Fingers.
list.label: Pulmones, the Lungs,
list.item: are Organs of Reſpiration. The Famous Malpighius makes the Subſtance of the Lungs (excepting the Nerves, a few Veſſels, and the Branches of the Wind-Pipe) to be nothing but an Heap of little Bladders, the contexture whereof is ſo ordered, that there's a Paſſage into them from the Wind-Pipe, and into one another; till they all open into the Membrane which clothes the Lungs. The uſe of the Lungs is to breathe withal, and to mix and accend the Blood with the Nitre they ſuck in.
list.label: Pulpa
list.item: is the fleſhy part of Fruits, Roots, or other Bodies, which is extracted by Infuſion or Boyling, and paſſing through a Sive: As the Pulp of Tamarinds, Caſſia, Althaea, Dates, &c.
list.label: Pulſus, the Pulſe,
list.item:
is the immediate Index of the Heart, by the mediation whereof the Blood is diffuſed through the whole Body, and is differently affected thereby according to the different Influx of the Animal Spirits; the Motion whereof is chiefly to be attributed to the circular and direct Fibres. Others affirm it to be the Dilatation and Contraction of the Heart and Blood.
A Pulſe is either natural or preternatural; of the former we have ſpoken already; the latter is ſuch as is different according to the different Circumſtances of the Fibres and Animal Spirits, to wit, ſtrong, weak, ſwift, ſlow, equal, unequal, intermittent, &c.
list.label: Pulvilli,
list.item: the ſame with Splenia.
list.label: Pulvis,
list.item: ſee Species.
list.label: Punctum lachrymale,
list.item: ſee Lachrymale punctum.
list.label: Punctum ſaliens,
list.item: in the growth of an Egg you ſee a little Speck, or Cloud as it were, in the innermoſt Tunic of it, called Amnios, which growing gradually thicker, acquires a kind of ſlimy Matter, in the middle whereof you ſee firſt this Punctum ſaliens (a little Speck that ſeems to leap;) afterward the rude Body of an Embrio, juſt like a ſhapeleſs kind of Maggot; which tends every Day more and more to Perfection.
list.label: Pupilla, or Pupula,
list.item: is the opening of the Tunic of the Eye, called Ʋvea or Choroides; it is round in Man, and is wont to be contracted or dilated like a Muſcle, according to the different Influx of the Animal Spirits.
list.label: Pupula,
list.item: ſee Pupilla.
list.label: Purgantia,
list.item: Purging Medicines are thoſe, which by reaſon of a peculiar diſpoſition of their parts irritate the fleſhy Fibres of the Ventricle, which become ſwoln and conſequently contracted at the right end, ſo that the whole Subſtance of the Stomach is drawn up together and inclined towards the Pylorus, whence follows an Excretion downwards.
list.label: Purgatio, Purging,
list.item:
is an Excretory Motion quick and frequent, proceeding from a quick and
orderly Contraction of the carneous Fibres of the Stomach and Inteſtines; whereby the Chyle, and Excrements, and corrupted Humors, either bred or ſent there from other parts, are protruded from part to part, till they be quite excluded the Body.
list.label: Pus,
list.item: ſee Pyon.
list.label: Puſtulae, Pimples,
list.item: are the Recrements of ill Blood that ſhoot forth in the Skin, and for want of Perſpiration, or too viſcous a Matter, ſtick there and cauſe an unequal Surface.
list.label: Putrefactio Chymica,
list.item: is the Diſſolution of a concrete Body, by natural Rottenneſs, in a moiſt Heat which corrupts the very Subſtance of it, and penetrates its moſt intimate Parts.
list.label: Pyon, or Pus,
list.item: is putrified Blood concocted into white Matter.
list.label: Pycnoſis,
list.item: ſee Pycnotica.
list.label: Pycnotica,
list.item: ſee Incraſſantia.
list.label: Pyelos,
list.item: ſee Choana.
list.label: Pylorus, or Janitor,
list.item: is the right Orifice of the Ventricle, which ſends the Meat out of the Stomach.
list.label: Pyoſis
list.item: is a Collection of Pus in any pa •• of the Body.
list.label: Pyramidales Muſculi
list.item:
are placed in the Abdomen, and lye upon the loweſt Tendons of the right Muſcles.
