They are not parts of the right Muſcles, as Veſalius and Columbus are of opinion, but diſtinct, as Falopius proves, tho with ſome pertinent ſome impertinent Arguments. The peculiar Membrane wherewith they are clothed, and the order of their Fibres, ſhew them to be different from the right Muſcles. They proceed
from the external Os Pubis, and the higher they climb the narrower they grow, and end about the Navel in the white Seam; ſometimes they are wanting, or the left is leſs than the right, or the right than the left.
list.label: Pyramidalia
list.item: are Veſſels which prepare the Seed, of which in their proper place. Alſo Muſcles of the Noſtrils and of the Abdomen called Pyramidales, or of a Pyramidical Figure. Alſo two Strings of Marrow about the Baſis of the oblongated Marrow.
list.label: Pyretologia,
list.item: is a Deſcription of Fevers: Of which Dr. Willis has writ moſt accurately.
list.label: Pyrotechnia,
list.item: the ſame that Chymia.
list.label: Pyrotica, or Ʋrentia,
list.item: are Medicines virtually hot, which being applied to Human Bodies, grow extreamly hot; becauſe that having Particles and Pores ſo ordered, that Vapors and Humors inſinuating into them, the ſubtile Matter finds ſuch Paſſages, that it being moved extream violently, forces certain earthy, hard, and acute Particles, which ſlote in the Paſſages, upon the neighbouring parts with great Impetuoſity, and ſo excites an Heat which corrupts, or changes differently, according to the diverſity of its Motion, and the Particles which are moved. Such are things that cauſe Redneſs, that bliſter, that ripen or rot, that cloſe up and bring Wounds to a Cruſt, and that pull Hairs out of the Body.
list.label: Pyulcus
list.item: is an Inſtrument wherewith Pus, or corrupted Matter, is evacuated.
list.label: Pyxis
list.item: is the Cavity of the Hip-Bone, which is called Acctabulum.

list.head: Q.
list.label: QƲadrans,
list.item: Phyſitians reckon a Weight of three Ounces, that is the fourth part of a Roman Pound.
list.label: Qualitas
list.item: is a Diſpoſition or Contexture of little Particles, whence our Bodies may be any way denominated of ſuch a Quality. Quality is manifeſt, hidden, poyſonous, contagious, Peſtilent, &c.
list.label: Quartana febris intermittens, a Quartan Ague,
list.item: which the Ancients called Saturn's Daughter. It is at this Day a Scandal to Phyſicians, becauſe it is ſo hard to be cured by thoſe who follow the old way. It is a preternatural Efferveſcence of the Blood, which attaques a Man every fourth Day, and then leaves him. It is cauſed by an acid auſtere Blood, and nutritious Juice hindred in its Aſſimilation.
list.label: Quartarium,
list.item: the ſame that Quadrans.
list.label: Quid pro Quo
list.item: is when a Medicine of one Nature and Quality is ſubſtituted for another, which is not to be done without the conſent of Phyſicians.
list.label: Quinta Eſſentia,
list.item: ſee Eſſentia quinta.
list.label: Quotidiana febris intermittens, an intermitting Quotidian Ague,
list.item: is that which returns every Day, and proceeds from crude Blood and an ill Aſſimilation of Chyle.

list.head: R.
list.label: RAbdoides,
list.item: the ſame that Sutura Sagittalis.
list.label: Rabies Hydrophobica,
list.item: ſee Hydrophobia.
list.label: Rachitae and Rachiaei
list.item: are Muſcles belonging to the Back.
list.label: Rachitis,
list.item: ſee Rhachitis.
list.label: Radicales dies,
list.item: ſee Critici dies.
list.label: Radius
list.item: is the leſs Bone of the Cubit, called Focile minus; it is more oblique than the great Bone called Ʋlna, and is diſtant a little from it in the middle, where there occurs a ſmall Ligament: Above the Ʋlna receives the Radius, and below the Radius receives it. The upper part of the Radius is jointed with the outward Proceſs of the Arm by Diarthroſis (which ſee); the lower by way of Appendix with the wriſt Bone at the middle Finger. Its upper end is ſmall, and the lower thick. It is alſo the greater Bone of the Leg.
list.label: Ramex,
list.item: ſee Hernia.
list.label: Ranula,
list.item: ſee Hypogloſſum.
list.label: Raphe,
list.item: ſee Sutura.
list.label: Rarefacientia,
list.item: rarifying Remedies, are ſuch as by diſſipating a little the Vapours and Humors make the Pores of Bodies larger.
list.label: Raſetta,
list.item: the ſame that Carpus.
list.label: Raſpatorium, or Scalprum Raſorium,
list.item: is a Chirurgeons Inſtrument to ſcrape or ſhave filthy and ſcaly Bones with.
list.label: Raucedo,
list.item: the ſame that Branchus.
list.label: Recidivus morbus, a Relapſe,
list.item: is when the morbifick Matter, that was left in the firſt Diſtemper, begins to work and ferment again.
list.label: Rectificatio
list.item: is a repeated diſtillation of Liquors, to exalt and purify them the more.
list.label: Reduvia
list.item: is a certain light Cleft or Chap in the Skin at the Roots of the Nails.
list.label: Refrigeratorium
list.item: is a wooden Veſſel, full of Water with a ſtreight or ſpiral Pipe in it of Tin or Lead, which diſtilled Water is to flow through to cool it.
list.label: Regius morbus,
list.item: ſee Icterus.
list.label: Relaxantia,
list.item: ſee Chalaſtica.
list.label: Relaxatio
list.item: is a Dilatation of Parts or Veſſels.
list.label: Reminiſcentia, Remembrance,
list.item: is a Perception whereby the Ideas of things before perceived, and impreſſed upon the Mind by Senſation or other Perception, are again offered and repreſented to the Soul, by the Mediation of Animal Spirits, in the common Senſory; either by their former Footſteps and Images impreſſed upon the Brain, or by ſome Words or other Signs which awakened and ſtirred them up. Or Reminiſcence is an arbitrary drawing out of things, which were before impreſſed upon the Brain, for its own uſe.
list.label: Remiſſio Febrium, a remitting of Fevers,
list.item: is a boyling down of hot and over-boyling Blood, which is Abſolute in intermittent Fevers, and but Partial in continued ones.
list.label: Renes, the Reins or Kidneys;
list.item:
there are two of them in the Abdomen, placed under the Liver and Spleen; the right Kidney is lower in a Man than the left: They are chiefly made up of little
Channels, or Conduits, which ariſe from the Glandules that lye about the Extremities of the Arteries, whence they receive the Serum, which paſſes on to the Carunculae Papillares, or little pieces of pappy Fleſh, to the Pelvis, (or Baſin) to the Ureters, the Bladder, and ſo out of Doors.
list.label: Renes ſuccenturiati,
list.item: ſee Capſulae atrabilariae.
list.label: Repellentia
list.item: are ſuch things as by ſtopping the Heat and Afflux of Humors, and by ſhutting up the Pores with their cold or binding Qualities, decreaſe the ſwelling of a part, and drive the Humors another way.
list.label: Res naturales,
list.item: Natural Things are three; Health, the Cauſes of Health, and its Effects. Others reckon ſeven, as the Elements, Temperaments, Humors, Spirits, Parts, Faculties, Actions; but Elements and Temperaments belong to natural Philoſophy; Humors, Spirits and Parts are reckoned amongſt the Cauſes of Health, which conſiſt of a good Temperature and a due Conformation; Faculties and Actions are comprehended under the Effects of Health.
list.label: Res non naturales,
list.item: Things that are not Natural are Six: Air, Meat and Drink, Motion and Reſt, Sleep and Waking, the Affections of the Mind, Things that are let out of, and Things retained in the Body. They are ſo called, becauſe that if they exceed their due Bounds, they often occaſion Diſeaſes.
list.label: Res preter Naturam,
list.item: things beſide Nature are Diſeaſes, their Cauſes, their Symptoms and Effects.
list.label: Reſolventia,
list.item: diſſolving Remedies are ſuch as are apt to diſſipate or ſcatter Particles, that are driven into the Body or any part of it, with their own ſpirituous and ſulphureous Particles.
list.label: Reſpiratio, Breathing,
list.item: is an alternate Dilatation and Contraction of the Cheſt, whereby the nitrous Air is taken in by the Wind-Pipe for the accenſion of the Blood, and by and by is driven out again with other vaporous Effluviums. The Cauſe of Reſpiration does not ſeem to conſiſt in the Dilatation and Contraction of the Thorax, as is commonly thought, but in the Contraction of the Tunic which covers the upper part of the Oeſophagus and the Wind-Pipe as far as its Cloſeſt Receſſes.
list.label: Rete mirabile,
list.item: the wonderful Net, in the Brain, is ſo called by reaſon of its admirable Structure; it conſiſts of ſeveral ſmall Arteries; it is under the Baſis of the Brain, and comprehends the pituitary Glandule, by the ſides of the Bone Ophenoides: The Uſe of it is, that the Blood may caſt off its ſerous parts into the pituitary Glandule, that it may afford finer and purer Spirits: Secondly, leſt the Blood by ruſhing too ſuddenly upon the Brain, ſhould in ſome meaſure ſuppreſs it; it is not ſo found in a Man and an Horſe, which perform noble things.
list.label: Reticularis plexus,
list.item: the ſame that Choroides.
list.label: Reticulum,
list.item: the ſame that Omentum.
list.label: Retiformis plexus,
list.item: ſee Plexus retiformis.
list.label: Retiformis tunica
list.item:
is a certain Expanſion of the inner Subſtance of the Optic Nerve in the Eye, which is to the Eye like a whited Wall in a dark
Chamber, which receives and repreſents the viſible Species that are let in by a hole in a darkened Room.
list.label: Retina tunica,
list.item: ſee Retiformis and Amphibleſtroides.
list.label: Retorta, a Retort,
list.item: is a Chymical Veſſel, made of Glaſs, Stone, or Iron; of a round Figure, to the ſide whereof there is faſtened a bended, retorted, and hollow Beak or Noſe, whereby the things that are to be diſtilled are put in and out.
list.label: Reverberatio chymica
list.item: is a Burning, whereby Bodies are calcined by an actual Fire in a Furnace called Reverberium.
list.label: Reverberium
list.item: is a Chymical Oven or Furnace, wherein Bodies that are to be burned or diſtilled are calcined.
list.label: Revulſoria,
list.item: V. S. is whereby the Blood that guſhes upon one part is diverted a contrary way, by the opening of a Vein in a remote and convenient place.
list.label: Rhachitis
list.item: is the Spinal Marrow, which ſee in its proper place: Alſo a Diſeaſe common amongſt the Engliſh, which is an unequal Nouriſhing of parts accompanied with Looſeneſs of parts, Softneſs, Weakneſs, Faintneſs, Drowzyneſs, a great ſwelling Head, with Leanneſs below the Head, with Protuberances about the Joints, Crookedneſs of Bones, Straitneſs of the Breaſt, Swelling of the Abdomen, Stretching of the Hypochondres, a Cough, &c. The Engliſh call it the Rickets: But becauſe the occaſion of it often lyes in the Spinal Marrow, the Famous Gliſſon calls it appoſitely enough Rhachitis.
list.label: Rhagades, the Latines ſay Soiſſurae, Eiſſurae, Rimae, Chinks, Clefts,
list.item: which as they happen in other parts of the Body, Hands, Feet, Lips, the entrance of the Womb; ſo they may happen in the Fundament, in the Extremity of the Gut Rectum, and in the Sphincter or Muſcle which cloſes the Fundament. Rhagades in the Fundament are certain oblong little Ulcers, without Swelling, like thoſe which are ſometimes occaſioned in the Hands by great Cold. Some are ſuperficial, others deep: Some are not hard nor callous, others are: Some are moiſt and ſend forth Matter, others dry and cancrous.
list.label: Rhegma
list.item: is a Breaking or Burſting of any part, as of a Bone, the inner Rine of the Belly, the Eye, &c.
list.label: Rheuma, Rheum,
list.item: is a Defluxion of Humor from the Head upon the parts beneath, as upon the Eyes, or Noſe.
list.label: Rheumatiſmus
list.item: is a wandring Pain in the Body, often accompanied with a ſmall Fever, Swelling, Inflammation, &c.
list.label: Rhexis,
list.item: the ſame that Rhegma.
list.label: Rhinenchytes
list.item: is a little Syringe to inject Medicines into the Noſtrils.
list.label: Rhodinum
list.item: is Roſe-Vinegar, or any thing made of Roſes.
list.label: Rhomboides
list.item:
is a pair of Muſcles proceeding from the three lowermoſt Vertebres of the Neck, and as many upper Spinal Proceſſes of the Vertebres of the Back: By and by they deſcend, and being fleſhy at the beginning and end, go as far as the Baſis of the Shoulder-blade,
which they move backward and obliquely upward.
list.label: Rhyptica
list.item: are ſcouring Medicines which cleanſe away Filth.
list.label: Rhythmus
list.item: is a certain proportion of Pulſes, Time, Life, Age, &c.
list.label: Rhythidoſis
list.item: is a Wrinkling of any part.
list.label: Rigor
list.item: is a Vibration and Concuſſion of the Skin and Muſcles of the whole Body, accompanied with Chilneſs.
list.label: Rima pudendi, or Fiſſura magna,
list.item: is ſo called, becauſe it reaches from the lower part of the Os Pubis almoſt as far as the Fundament, ſo that the ſpace betwixt the one and the other, which is called Perinaeum, or Interforamineum, is ſcarce a Fingers breadth. By frequent Coition it grows larger. The uſe of it is for Generation, Excretion of Urine and other Excrements, and for the bearing of Young.
list.label: Riſus Sardonius
list.item: is a Contraction of each Jaw.
list.label: Rob,
list.item: ſee Apochyliſma.
list.label: Robub,
list.item: the ſame.
list.label: Roriferus ductus,
list.item: the ſame that Ductus chyliferus.
list.label: Ros,
list.item: in the account of the Ancients, was the firſt Moiſture that falls from the Extremities of Veſſels, and is diſperſed upon the Subſtance of the Members. Ros, ſays Galen, is a third ſort of Moiſture whereby the parts of our Body are nouriſhed, and is contained in all the parts of an Animal, like a certain Dew ſprinkled upon them: This is the Opinion of the Ancients.
list.label: Roſa,
list.item: the ſame that Eryſipelas.
list.label: Roſtriformis proceſſus,
list.item: ſee Coracoides.
list.label: Rotator major & minor,
list.item: are two Apophyſes in the upper part of the Thigh-Bone, called Trichanteres, in which the Tendons of many Muſcles are terminated.
list.label: Rotula,
list.item: the ſame that Mola genu.
list.label: Rotulae,
list.item: ſee Tabellae.
list.label: Rubrica,
list.item: ſee Impetigo.
list.label: Ructatio, Belching,
list.item: is a depraved Motion of the Stomach, occaſioned by an Efferveſcence there, whereby Vapours and flatulent Matter are ſent out at the Mouth. And it is either acid, or ſtinking, or ſavours like ſomething burnt or roaſted.
list.label: Ructus,
list.item: ſee Bombus and Ructatio.
list.label: Rugitus
list.item: is an Efferveſcence of Chyle and Excrements in the Blood, whereby Wind and ſeveral other Motions are excited in the Guts, and rowl up and down the Excrements, when there's no eaſy Vent nor upwards nor downwards.
list.label: Ruptio,
list.item: ſee Rhegma.
list.label: Ryas
list.item: is a too plentiful and preternatural falling of Tears.

list.head: S.
list.label: SAccus
list.item: is the Gut called Rectum.
list.label: Sacculus Chyliferus, or Roriferus,
list.item: is the lower part of the Paſſage of the Chyle, into which are inſerted all the Lacteal Veins of the ſecond ſort, and a great number of the Lymphatic Veſſels.
list.label: Sacculus Cordis,
list.item: ſee Pericardium.
list.label: Sacculi Medicinales,
list.item: are▪ when ſeveral Simples, according to the Nature of the Diſeaſe, are compounded and beaten together, and tied up in a little Bag, to be applyed to the part affected. The Bag is to be ſewed or quilted down in ſeveral places, that the Ingredients run not altogether in a Lump.
list.label: Sacer Ignis,
list.item: ſee Herpes Exedens.
list.label: Sacer Morbus,
list.item: ſee Epilepſia.
list.label: Sacrum Os, the Holy Bone,
list.item: conſiſts of the ſix lower Vertebres, to which are joyned the Oſſa Coccygis, or Hip Bones; in the hinder part of the Abdomen it makes that Cavity which is called Pelvis or the Baſon.
list.label: Sagittalis Sutura, or Veruculata,
list.item: is that Suture of the Scull, which begins at the Coronal or Crown Suture, and ends in the Lambdoidal Suture.
list.label: Saliva & Salivum, Spittle,
list.item:
is an inſipid Liquor, which being ſeparated in the Maxillar Glandules or Glandules of the Jaws, and by proper Paſſages flowing into the Mouth, ſerves to moiſten its Mouth and Gullet, and aſſiſts to the chewing of Meat, and in ſome meaſure to
the Digeſtion and Fermentation of it in the Stomach.
list.label: Salivatio, Salivation,
list.item: is an Evacuation of Spittle by Salivating Medicines, of which ſort principally are Mercurial Preparations. Salivation is ſometimes taken for a preternatural Increaſe of Spittle.
list.label: Salvatella,
list.item: is that Vein which from the Veins of the Arm is terminated in the little Finger.
list.label: Sanguificatio,
list.item: ſee Haematoſis.
list.label: Sanguis, Blood,
list.item: is a red florid Liquor contained in the Veins and Arteries, and conſiſts of all thoſe parts of the Chyle which paſs through the Papillae, the little ſoft riſings of the Inteſtines. This is that which gives Nouriſhment, Life and Strength to all the parts of the Body. The Microſcope diſcovers that the parts of the Blood are round or globular naturally, but that in Fevers 'tis full of Worms.
list.label: Sanies,
list.item: is a thick and bloody Pus, or Matter.
list.label: Sanitas,
list.item: ſee Hygieia.
list.label: Sapa,
list.item: ſee Apochyliſma.
list.label: Saphaena
list.item: is the Vein of the Leg, or Crural Vein.
list.label: Saphatum
list.item: is a dry Scurf in the Head, ſee Achor.
list.label: Saponea
list.item: is a Lambitive made of Almonds.
list.label: Sapor,
list.item: ſee Guſtus.
list.label: Sarcocele
list.item: is a Rupture, which conſiſts in a fleſhy Excreſcence of the Teſticles.
list.label: Sarcoma
list.item: is a fleſhy Excreſcence.
list.label: Sarcomphalum
list.item: is a fleſhy Excreſcence of the Navel.
list.label: Sarcophagum,
list.item: ſee Cathaereticum.
list.label: Sarcoſis,
list.item: ſee Sarcoma.
list.label: Sarcotica
list.item:
are thoſe Medicines which fill up
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
Wounds with Fleſh, ſuch as by their moderate Heat and cleanſing qualities keep Wounds and Ulcers free from Filth and preſerve the natural temper of the Parts, ſo that the Aliment eaſily ſupplies the Solution of the Parts.
list.label: Sare,
list.item: ſee Eſſere.
list.label: Satyriaſis, ſive Priapiſmus,
list.item: is an immoderate deſire of Venery, which upon Coition vaniſhes. 'Tis taken ſometimes for the Leproſy, becauſe in that Diſeaſe the Skin acquires the Roughneſs of a Satyr: 'Tis likewiſe uſed for the Swelling of the Glandules behind the Ears.
list.label: Satyriaſmus,
list.item: ſee Satyriaſis.
list.label: Scabies, the Itch:
list.item: 'Tis of two ſorts, moiſt and dry; the Moiſt is an inequality or roughneſs of the Skin with moiſt and purulent Puſtles, accompanied with a conſtant Itching; the Dry Itch is fourfold Pruritus, Impetigo, Pſora, and Lepra, which ſee.
list.label: Scalenum,
list.item: is that pair of Muſcles which extend the Neck. They are perforated to make way for the Veins and Arteries, and the Nerves of the hinder part of the Neck as they go to the Arm.
list.label: Scalpellum Ʋmbilicarium,
list.item: is the Knife with which the Midwife cuts off the Navels of Children.
list.label: Scalprum Chirurgicum,
list.item: a Lancet.
list.label: Scalprum Raſorium,
list.item: ſee Raſpatorium.
list.label: Scamnum Hypocratis, Hypocrates's Bench,
list.item: is an Inſtrument of ſix Ells long, 'tis uſed in ſetting of Bones.
list.label: Scapha,
list.item: is the Inner Rim of the Ear.
list.label: Scaphoides,
list.item:
is the Third Os Tarſi in the Foot, 'tis joyned to the Ancle-Bone and the three hinder
Bones: 'Tis called alſo Os Naviculare from ſome reſemblance it has of a Boat.
list.label: Scapula,
list.item: ſee Homoplata.
list.label: Scarificatio, Scarification,
list.item: 'tis an Inciſion of the Skin with a Pen-knife or Lancet: This is done either with or without Cupping-Glaſſes; without Cupping-Glaſſes if there be any Mortification or Gangrene, becauſe the Separation is by all means to be haſtned; with Cupping-Glaſſes, if there be a neceſſity of taking away Blood.
list.label: Sceletum, a Skeleton,
list.item: is when the Bones are dryed and put together according to Art in their natural Order and Poſition.
list.label: Scelotyrbe,
list.item: is a wandring Pain in the Legs, proceeding chiefly from the Scurvey. Hence the Water proper for this Diſtemper is called Aqua Scelotyrbitis.
list.label: Scheſis,
list.item: is the Diſpoſition of the Body.
list.label: Schetica febris,
list.item: is oppoſed to the Hectic Fever, becauſe it is feated moſtly in the Blood and is eaſily cured, but a Hectic Fever is fixed in the very Habit of the Body, and not to be removed without great difficulty.
list.label: Schiſma,
list.item: a Cut in any part either hard or ſoft.
list.label: Schiatica,
list.item: ſee Arthritis.
list.label: Schirroſis,
list.item: ſee Schirrus.
list.label: Schirrus & Schirroma,
list.item: is a hard, livid Swelling, that reſiſts the touch and is without Pain.
list.label: Scleriaſis,
list.item: is a Hardneſs of any part.
list.label: Scleroma,
list.item: the ſame.
list.label: Scleropthalmia
list.item: is a hard Blearedneſs of the Eyes accompanied with Pain, a ſlow Motion of the Eyes, with redneſs and dryneſs of 'em.
list.label: Sclerotica,
list.item: ſee Cornea.
list.label: Sclerotica, or hardning Medicines,
list.item: are ſuch as unite the parts more firmly amongſt themſelves, and that either by diſſipating the thin and ſoft parts, or elſe ſometimes by retaining them; the firſt by hardning the Matter into a Schirrus by too hot Medicines, the latter is done when the part affected acquires a Hardneſs by cooling and aſtringent Medicines, ſuch are Sengreen, Nightſhade, Porcelan, and Water-Lintels. Therefore theſe Sclerotic Medicines are either healing, or elſe cooling and aſtringent.
list.label: Scleruntica,
list.item: the ſame with Sclerotica.
list.label: Scoliaſis,
list.item: is a Diſtortion of the Back-Bone to one or t'other ſide.
list.label: Scolopomachaerion,
list.item: is a Chirurgions Knife, with which Wounds of the Thorax are widened; 'tis uſed alſo in opening larger Swellings; as alſo in opening the Abdomen.
list.label: Scorbutus, the Scurvy,
list.item: is a Diſeaſe that is Epidemial to the Hollanders. The Symptoms of it are generally, livid Spots on the Hands and Feet, weakneſs of the Legs, ſtinking Breath, looſeneſs of the Teeth, bleeding of the Gums, Convulſions, Pains, running Gout, Cholick, &c. This is of two kinds, either Salino-Sulphureus, when the Sulphur is predominant to Salt; or Sulphureo-Salinus, when the Salt is predominant to the Sulphur; this is likewiſe either in the Blood or nervous Juice.
list.label: Scriptulus,
list.item: ſee Scrupulus.
list.label: Scotoma,
list.item: the ſame with Scotomia.
list.label: Scotomia, Dizzineſs or Swimming of the Head,
list.item:
is when the Animal Spirits are ſo whirled about
that the External Objects ſeem to run round.
list.label: Scrobiculus Cordis,
list.item: ſee Anticardium.
list.label: Scroptula,
list.item: are preternatural hard Glandules, or preternatural Swellings of the Glandules of the Neck and Ears; they are contained in a proper Tunic.
list.label: Scrotum, the Cod,
list.item: is a Bag which contains the Teſticles of the Male, it conſiſts of a Skin fleſhy Panniculus, the two Tunics Erythrois and Elythrois. In the middle of it is a Line extended in the length, which divides the right part from the left. For more eaſy Diſtention or Contraction 'tis void of Fat.
list.label: Scrotum Cordis,
list.item: ſee Pericardium.
list.label: Scrupulus, a Scruple,
list.item: it is the third part of a Drachm and contains twenty Grains.
list.label: Scutiforme Os,
list.item: ſee Mola Genu.
list.label: Scutiformis Cartilago,
list.item: ſee Enſiformis.
list.label: Scutum,
list.item: ſee Mola Genu.
list.label: Scybala,
list.item: are Sheeps, or Goats, &c. Buttons, or Excrement.
list.label: Scypho,
list.item: is the Infundibulum in the Brain: Likewiſe thoſe Paſſages which convey the Spittle from the Os Cribriforme to the Pallat.
list.label: Sectio Caeſaria,
list.item: ſee Hyſteratomotocia.
list.label: Secundinae,
list.item: the Secundine, or After-Birth, are the three Membranes, Chorion, Alantois, and Amnion, which with the Placenta, are excluded after the Birth.
list.label: Sedimentum Ʋrinae,
list.item: the Sediment of Urine, are parts of the nutritious Juice, which being ſeparated from the Blood, with the Serum, becauſe of their gravity, ſink to the bottom of the Urine.
list.label: Sella Equina, ſeu Turcica,
list.item: it is compounded of four Proceſſes of the Bone Sphenoeides, or Wedg-like Bone; it contains the Pituitarian Glandule, and in Brutes the Rete Mirabile.
list.label: Sella Sphenoeidis,
list.item: the ſame with Sella Equina.
list.label: Sella Turcica,
list.item: the ſame.
list.label: Semeioſis,
list.item: ſee Diagnoſis.
list.label: Semeiotica,
list.item: is that part of Phyſick which treats of the Signs of Health and Sickneſs.
list.label: Semen, Seed,
list.item: is a white, hot, ſpirituous, thick, clammy, ſaltiſh Humor, which is made out of the thinneſt parts of the Blood in the Teſticles and Epididymides, and by proper Paſſages is ejected into the Womb of the Female. There is alſo in the Female a Matter which is called Seed, which proceeds from the Proſtates, and frequently in their Lechery is emitted forth: The uſe of this is to raiſe Titillation, and render the Coition more pleaſant.
list.label: Semicupium,
list.item: is a Bath in which the Patient is only up to the Navel in Water.
list.label: Senſorium Commune, or the Seat of common Senſe,
list.item: is that part of the Brain in which the Nerves from the Organs of all the Senſes are terminated, which is in the beginning of the Medulla Oblongata.
list.label: Senſus, Senſe,
list.item: is when the Motion impreſſed by the outward Objects upon the Fibres of the Nerves is convey'd, by the help of the Animal Spirits in the Nerves, to the common Senſory or Medulla Oblongata.
list.label: Sephyros,
list.item: is a hard Inflammation of the Womb.
list.label: Septa,
list.item: the ſame with Septica.
list.label: Septica, ſive Putrefacientia,
list.item:
are thoſe things
which by a malignant Heat and ſharpneſs rot and corrupt the Fleſh.
list.label: Septum Lucidum,
list.item: is a Partition, upon the account of its thinneſs Diaphanous, which diſtinguiſhes the Ventricles of the Brain.
list.label: Septum Tranſverſum,
list.item: ſee Diaphragma.
list.label: Serpigo,
list.item: ſee Lichen.
list.label: Serapium,
list.item: ſee Syrupus.
list.label: Serra,
list.item: a Saw.
list.label: Serum,
list.item: is a watery, thin, yellowiſh, and ſaltiſh Humor, which conſiſts chiefly of Water, with a moderate quantity of Salt and a little Sulphur: The Uſe of it is to be a Vehicle to the Blood.
list.label: Seſamoeidea Oſſa,
list.item: are 16, 19, 20, and ſometimes more little Bones, ſo called from the likeneſs they have to Seſamum Seeds, which are found in the Joynts of the Hands and Feet.
list.label: Setaceum,
list.item: is when the Skin of the Neck is taken up and run through with a Needle; and the Wound afterward kept open by Briſtles, a Skean of Silk, &c. that ſo the ill Humors may vent themſelves.
list.label: Sextans,
list.item: is the ſixth part of a Pound, containing two Ounces.
list.label: Sialiſmus,
list.item: ſee Ptyaliſmus.
list.label: Sialochus,
list.item: ſee Ptyaliſmus.
list.label: Sialon,
list.item: ſee Sielos & Saliva.
list.label: Sideratio,
list.item: ſee Spacelos.
list.label: Sief Album,
list.item: ſee Collyrium.
list.label: Sigmoides,
list.item: are the Apophyſes of the Bones, repreſenting the Letter C of the ancient Greeks. Alſo the three Valves of the Great Artery that hinder the Blood from returning back to the Heart.
list.label: Signum Morbi,
list.item: the Symptome of a Diſeaſe.
list.label: Siliqua,
list.item: is half a Lupin, of which ſix weigh a Scruple. This is to be underſtood of the Seed contained in it.
list.label: Similares partes,
list.item: Similar Parts, are ſuch as are throughout of the ſame Nature and Texture.
list.label: Simplicia, Simples,
list.item: are Medicines unmixt and uncompounded.
list.label: Sinapiſmus,
list.item: is a Medicine applyed to the Head, and is prepared of Muſtard, wild Radiſh, Salt, and Leven.
list.label: Sinciput,
list.item: the ſides of the Head.
list.label: Singultus,
list.item: ſee Lygmus.
list.label: Sinus Mening is,
list.item: are thoſe Cavities which Galen calls the Ventricles of the Thick Membrane. The firſt and ſecond, or the lateral Sinus's, are ſeated between the Brain and the Cerebellum, and end in the Vertebral Sinus's. The third begins from the Os Cribiforme, and ends in the middle of the former Sinus's. The fourth ariſes from the Pinealis Glandule, and ends in the middle of the lateral Sinus's. The Inſertion of theſe Sinus's is called Torcular Herophili. The Sinus's after they have paſſed through the Skull, are partly continued with the Jugular Veins, and partly deſcend through the whole length of the Spinal Marrow down to the Os Sacrum. The Uſe of them is to ſupply the place of Veins, for they convey the Blood from the Brain and Cerebellum, partly into the Jugular Veins, and partly into the Vertebral Sinus's.
list.label: Sinus Oſſium,
list.item: are thoſe Cavities of the Bones which receive the Heads of other Bones.
list.label: Sircaſis,
list.item: is an Inflammation or rather great Heat of the Brain and its Membranes, occaſion'd by the heat of the Sun: This is frequent in Children, becauſe of the thinneſs of their Skulls.
list.label: Sirones,
list.item: are a ſort of Puſtles which ariſe in the Palms of the Hands and Soles of the Feet, and contain in them a very little ſort of Worms or Lice.
list.label: Sitis, Thirſt,
list.item: is a Defect of the Salival Juice which occaſions the fancy and deſire of Drink.
list.label: Solutio chymica,
list.item: is a reſolving any Body into its Chymical Principles; which are, Spirit, Salt, Sulphur, Water and Earth.
list.label: Solutio continui,
list.item: is a Diſſolution of the Unity and Continuity of the Parts: As in Wounds, Ulcers, Fractures, &c.
list.label: Somnambulo,
list.item: ſee Noctambulo.
list.label: Somnifera, or Sleeping Medicines,
list.item: are ſuch which conſiſting of faetid Sulphureous parts, diſſipate and extinguiſh the Animal Spirits, and hinder their increaſe, whence follows Sleep.
list.label: Somnus, Sleep,
list.item: is a ſtreightning of the Pores of the Brain, cauſed by the Reſt of the Animal Spirits, by which means the outward Senſes reſt from their Operations.
list.label: Somnolentia continua,
list.item: is a conſtant Drouzineſs and Inclination to Sleep; this comes to paſs when the Pores of the outward or Cortical Subſtance of the Brain are quite cloſed up by ſome viſcous Matter, ſo that the Animal Spirits cannot freely paſs.
list.label: Spagyrica Medecina,
list.item: ſee Hermetica.
list.label: Sparadrapum,
list.item:
is a piece of Linnen ting'd of both ſides, either with a thick Ointment, or
Plaiſter, and is made this way; after you have melted your Ointment, or Plaiſter, dip your Linnen in it; extend it and keep it for uſe.
list.label: Sora,
list.item: ſee Eſſere.
list.label: Sparganum,
list.item: ſee Faſcia.
list.label: Sparganoſis,
list.item: is a Diſtention of the Breaſts, occaſioned by too much Milk.
list.label: Spaſma,
list.item: ſee Spaſmns.
list.label: Spaſmodica,
list.item: are Medicines againſt Convulſions.
list.label: Spaſmologia,
list.item: is a Treatiſe of Convulſions.
list.label: Spaſmus,
list.item: is any Convulſive Motion. Cardan makes two ſorts of Convulſive Affections, viz. Tetanus and Spaſmus; by the former he underſtands a conſtant Contraction, whereby the Member becomes rigid and inflexible; by the latter he underſtands ſudden Concuſſions and Motions, which ceaſe and return alternately.
list.label: Spatha,
list.item: is an oblong Inſtrument, broad at the lower end: Its Uſe is to take up Conſerves and Electuaries without fouling the Hands.
list.label: Spathomela,
list.item: is an oblong Inſtrument, made of Silver or Iron, which Chirurgions and Apothecaries uſe.
list.label: Species, or Pouders,
list.item: are thoſe Simples which are deſigned to make Compounds with. So Species of Treacle are thoſe Ingredients of which Treacle is compounded: By the ſame Name are called the Species of ordinary Decoctions. This Name is chiefly given to ſome Aromatick and Purging Pouders: Perhaps becauſe heretofore they were made up into Electuaries, Bolus's, &c.
list.label: Specifica Medicamenta,
list.item: are thoſe Medicines which have a peculiar Virtue againſt ſome one Diſeaſe.
list.label: Specillum,
list.item: a Probe.
list.label: Speculum lucidum,
list.item: ſee Septum Lucidum.
list.label: Speculum Oculi,
list.item: the Apple or Pupil of the Eye: ſee Aranea Tunica Oculi.
list.label: Speculum Oris,
list.item: ſee Dilatatorium.
list.label: Spermaticae Partes,
list.item: are thoſe Arteries and Veins which bring the Blood to and convey it from the Teſticles: Likewiſe thoſe Veſſels through which the Seed paſſes: Likewiſe all whitiſh parts of the Body, which becauſe of their whiteneſs were anciently thought to be made of the Seed: Of this ſort are Nerves, Bones, Membranes, Griſſles, &c.
list.label: Spermatocele,
list.item: a Rupture cauſed by the Contraction of the Veſſel which ejects the Seed, and its falling down into the Scrotum.
list.label: Sphacelodes,
list.item: like to the Apoplexy.
list.label: Sphacelus,
list.item: is a ſudden Extinction of Life and Senſe in every part.
list.label: Sphagitides,
list.item: are the Jugular Veins in the Neck.
list.label: Sphenoeides,
list.item: ſee Sphenois.
list.label: Sphenois,
list.item: ſee Os Cuneiforme.
list.label: Sphenopharyngaeus,
list.item: is a pair of Muſcles ariſing from the Sinus of the inner Wing of the Os Cuneiforme, or Wedg-like Bone, and going obliquely downward, is extended into the ſides of the Gullet; it dilates the Gullet.
list.label: Sphincter,
list.item: is a Muſcle that contracts the Gullet, Anus, Bladder, &c.
list.label: Sphygmica,
list.item: is that part of Phyſick which treats of Pulſes.
list.label: Sphygmus,
list.item: the Pulſe.
list.label: Spina Dorſi
list.item: are the hinder Prominences of the Vertebrae's.
list.label: Spina Ventoſa,
list.item: is an Ulceration in which the Bones are eaten by a malignant Humor without any pain of the Perioſtium, or Membrane that covers the Bone, after that a Swelling being riſen without any Pain, the part affected is quite eaten out with the Ulcer, from whence frequently follows a neceſſity of Amputation.
list.label: Spinalis medulla,
list.item: ſee Medulla ſpinalis.
list.label: Spiritus, Spirits,
list.item: are reckon'd of three ſorts, the Animal Spirits in the Brain, the Vital in the Heart, the Natural in the Liver; but late Authors diſtinguiſh'em only into two kinds, the Animal in the Brain, the Vital and Natural (which are accounted the ſame) in the Maſs of Blood. The Animal Spirits are a very thin Liquor, which diſtilling from the Blood in the outward or Cortical Subſtance of the Brain, are by the proper Ferment of the Brain exalted into Spirits, and thence through the Medullar Subſtance of the Brain, the Corpus Calloſum, and Medulla Oblongata, are derived into the Nerves and Spinal Marrow, and in them perform all the Actions of Senſe and Motion. The Vital or Natural Spirits, are the ſubtileſt parts of the Blood which actuate and ferment it, and make it fit for Nouriſhment.
list.label: Splanchnica,
list.item: are Medicines proper againſt Diſeaſes of the Inteſtines.
list.label: Splanchnon,
list.item: ſee Inteſtina.
list.label: Splen, five Lien, the Spleen,
list.item:
is a Receptacle for the Salt and earthy Excrements of the Blood,
that there, by the aſſiſtance of the Animal Spirits, it may be volatiliz'd, and returning again into the Blood may concur to its farther Fermentation. The Spleen conſiſts of a great number of little Bladders, between which the Glandules are ſcatter'd up and down and ſupply the place of Veins: The Spleen has likewiſe an Artery, Nerves, and Lymphatick Veſſels, firſt diſcovered by Fr. Ruiſch. It's very like the Sole of the Foot, and in Cows is exactly like a Beeves Tongue.
list.label: Splenia,
list.item: are Bolſters made of Linnen, three, four, or five times doubled, even to the thickneſs of the Spleen, they are uſed upon Wounds, Ulcers, and Fractures. The Figure is threefold according to the manner of Application, viz. at length, obliquely, or tranſverſely: They are called alſo Plumaccoli and Plagulae.
list.label: Splenica, Splenical Medicines,
list.item: are ſuch as by attenuating and volatilizing the groſſer parts, remove the Diſtempers and Obſtructions of the Spleen.
list.label: Splenii Muſculi,
list.item: ariſe partly from the five lower Vertebrae's of the Neck, and partly from the points of five of the upper Vertebrae's of the Thorax; the Fibres of theſe Muſcles tend obliquely, and are faſtned to the hinder part of the Head: The Uſe of 'em is to draw the Head backward.
list.label: Spongoeidea Oſſa,
list.item: ſee Cribroformia.
list.label: Sporadici morbi,
list.item: are thoſe Diſeaſes which (different in Nature) ſeize ſeveral People at the ſame time, and in the ſame Countrey.
list.label: Sputum,
list.item: Liquor thicker than ordinary Spittle.
list.label: Squammoſa Sutura,
list.item: ſee Lepidoides.
list.label: Stagma,
list.item: are Juices of Plants mixt together in order to Diſtillation.
list.label: Stalagma,
list.item: is that which is diſtilled from the Stagma.
list.label: Staltica,
list.item: ſee Sarcotica.
list.label: Stapes,
list.item: ſee Incus.
list.label: Staphyle,
list.item: ſee Cion.
list.label: Staphyloma,
list.item: is a Diſeaſe of the Eye, in which the two Tunics of the Eye Cornea and Ʋvea, being broken, fall outward in the ſhape of a Grape.
list.label: Status Morbi,
list.item: ſee Acme.
list.label: Steatocele,
list.item: is a Rupture or Tumor in the Scrotum of a Fatty or Suet-like Conſiſtence.
list.label: Steatoma,
list.item: is a preternatural Swelling, which conſiſts of a Matter almoſt like Suet, of the ſame Colour throughout, ſoft, and tho not eaſily yielding to the touch, yet ſuddenly returns, the Fingers removed, to its proper ſhape and bigneſs.
list.label: Stegnoſis,
list.item: is a Conſtriction and ſtopping up of the Pores.
list.label: Stegnotica,
list.item: ſee Aſtringentia.
list.label: Stercus,
list.item: is that Excrement which is voided by Stool; it conſiſts of thoſe parts of the Aliment and Bile which is unfit for Nouriſhment.
list.label: Sterilitas,
list.item: ſee Agonia.
list.label: Sternum Os, the Breaſt-Bone,
list.item: is joyn'd to the Ribs in the foremoſt part of the Breaſt; it conſiſts of 3 or 4 Bones, and frequently in thoſe that are come to ripeneſs of Age grows into one Bone; to this is joyned in the lower part of it the Cartilago Enſiformis.
list.label: Sternohyoides,
list.item: is that pair of Muſcles which from the uppermoſt part of the Breaſt-Bone, goes outwards and aſcends up to the Baſis of the Os Hyoeides.
list.label: Sternothurocides,
list.item: is a pair of Muſcles of the Cartilago Scutiformis which draw it downward; this ariſes from the uppermoſt and inward part of the Breaſt-Bone, and is inſerted into the lower ſide of the Cartilago Enſiformis.
list.label: Sternutatio, Sneezing,
list.item: is a forcible driving out of the Head ſome ſharp Matter which vellicates and diſturbs the Nerves and Fibres: 'Tis defin'd likewiſe an involuntary Motion of the Brain, which alſo contracts the Muſcles of the Thorax and Abdomen, to the intent that the Matter which vellicates the Noſtrils and Brain may be driven out.
list.label: Stigma,
list.item: a Scar.
list.label: Stoma, the Mouth,
list.item: as alſo the Mouths of any Veſſels.
list.label: Stomachus,
list.item: is properly the left Orifice of the Ventricle, or Stomach, by which Meats are received into it. To this part deſcend Nerves from the par Vagum, and intercoſtal Nerves, and are mix'd and woven with one another.
list.label: Strabiliſmus,
list.item: ſee Strabiſmus.
list.label: Strabiſmus, Squinting,
list.item: is occaſioned by the Relaxation, Contraction, Diſtorſion, too great Length, or too great Shortneſs of the Muſcles which move the Eye.
list.label: Straboſitas,
list.item: ſee Strabiſmus.
list.label: Sternutatorium, five Sternutamentum,
list.item: a Sneezing Medicine, or Snuff.
list.label: Stillicidium Ʋrinae,
list.item: ſee Stranguria.
list.label: Stranguria, the Strangury,
list.item: is a difficulty of Urine, when the Urine comes away by Drops only, accompanied with a conſtant Inclination of making Water.
list.label: Stratificatio,
list.item: is a corroding of Metals by corroſive Pouders. The Operation is performed in this manner: Put firſt in the bottom of the Crucible ſome of the corroding Pouder; then ſome of the Metal you are to corrode beaten into thin Plates; then ſome of the Pouders, and upon them ſome more Plates of your Metal, and ſo on till the Crucible be full; then make Ignemrotae, or a Fire round your Crucible to the top, or elſe place it in a Reverbatory, according as the Operation ſhall require.
list.label: Struma,
list.item: ſee Scrophula.
list.label: Stryphna,
list.item: ſee Aſtringentia.
list.label: Stupefacientia,
list.item: ſee Narcotica.
list.label: Stupea, ſeu Stupa,
list.item: is a piece of Linnen dipt in a Liquor, and applied to the part affected.
list.label: Stupor,
list.item: Numneſs.
list.label: Stylocer athoeides,
list.item: are the Muſcles of the Os Hyoeides which draw upwards: They ariſe from the outward Appendix of the Os Styliforme, and are extended to the Horns or Points of the Os Hyoeides.
list.label: Stylogloſſum,
list.item: is that pair of Muſcles which lift up the Tongue; they ariſe from the Appendix of the Os Styliforme, and are inſerted about the middle of the Tongue.
list.label: Styloeides,
list.item: are Proceſſes of Bone faſhioned backward like a Pencil, faſtened into the Baſis of the Skull it ſelf.
list.label: Stylopharyngaeus,
list.item: is a pair of Muſcles that dilate the Gullet, deſcending from an Appendix of a Bone in faſhion of a Pencil, and which reaches the ſides of the Gullet.
list.label: Stymma,
list.item: is that thick Maſs which remains after the ſteeping of Flowers, Herbs, &c. and preſſing out their Oil.
list.label: Styptica,
list.item: ſee Aſtringentia.
list.label: Subcartilageneum,
list.item: ſee Hypocondrium.
list.label: Subeth Avicennae,
list.item: ſee Coma.
list.label: Sublimatio,
list.item: is a dry Extract, conſiſting of the more ſubtile parts raiſed above the Maſs, and ſticking to the Sides and Neck of the Veſſel.
list.label: Sublaxatio,
list.item: a diſlocation, or putting out of Joint.
list.label: Subſidentia,
list.item: ſee Sedimentum.
list.label: Succago,
list.item: ſee Apochyliſma.
list.label: Succedaneum,
list.item: ſee Antiballomenon.
list.label: Succenturiati Renes,
list.item: ſee Capſulae atrabilariae.
list.label: Succus Pancreaticus,
list.item: ſee Ductus Pancreaticus.
list.label: Sudamina,
list.item: are little Pimples in the Skin, like Millet Grains; this is frequent in Children and Youths, eſpecially thoſe that are of a hot Temper, and uſe much Exerciſe: They break out in the Neck, Shoulders, Breaſt, Arms and Thighs, and moſtly about the Privities.
list.label: Sudationes,
list.item: the ſame with Sudamina.
list.label: Sudor, Sweat,
list.item: is a watry Humor which conſiſts of Water chiefly with a moderate quantity of Salt and Sulphur: This is driven through the Pores of the Skin by the Heat and Fermentation of the Blood, and ſometimes by its Weakneſs and Colliquation.
list.label: Sudorifera,
list.item: ſee Hydrotica.
list.label: Suffimentum,
list.item: the ſame with Suffitus.
list.label: Suffitus,
list.item: is a thickiſh Powder, prepar'd of odoriferous Plants, Gums, &c. which thrown upon Coals produces a pleaſant Smell.
list.label: Suffocatio Ʋterina,
list.item: ſee Hyſterica paſſio.
list.label: Suffumigium,
list.item: ſee Suffitus.
list.label: Suffuſio,
list.item: ſee Hypochyma & Cataracta.
list.label: Sugillata,
list.item: ſee Enchymoma.
list.label: Sugillatio,
list.item: ſee Enchymoma.
list.label: Summitates,
list.item: the tops of Herbs.
list.label: Supercilium,
list.item: ſee Cilium.
list.label: Superfoetatio,
list.item: is when after one Conception another ſucceeds, ſo that both are in the Womb together: Sennertus makes mention of frequent Caſes of this Nature.
list.label: Superpurgatio,
list.item: ſee Hypercatharſis.
list.label: Supplantalia,
list.item: are Plaiſters applyed to the Feet; theſe for the moſt part are made of Leven, Muſtard, wild Radiſh, Salt, Sope, Gun-Powder, &c.
list.label: Suppoſitorium, a Suppoſitory,
list.item: it is compounded of Honey, Salt, and Purging Powders.
list.label: Suppuratio,
list.item: ſee Abſceſſus.
list.label: Sura,
list.item: the ſame with Os Fibulae.
list.label: Sutura Oſſium, a Suture
list.item: is the Juncture of Bones (of the Scull) like the Teeth of Saws meeting together.
list.label: Sutura,
list.item:
is a Connexion of the Sides or Lips of a Wound: This is of two ſorts, Actual, which is done with a Needle of a triangular point, a Pipe, or Cane, and waxed Thread, firſt in the middle of the Wound you muſt ſew it together with a double Thread, and having made a knot, cut it off; the reſt of the Wound muſt be ſewed up with a ſingle Thread; care muſt be taken that the Stitches are not ſet too wide, nor too cloſe, eſpecially not too cloſe, that there may be room for any corrupt Matter bred in the Wound to work out: The other ſort of Suture is much like
the way that Skinners uſe to ſew Skins together; this is proper in Wounds of the Inteſtines, and in Cuts of the Veins and Arteries.
list.label: Sycoſis,
list.item: is an Excreſcence of the Fleſh about the Fundament. 'Tis alſo an Ulcer ſo called from the reſemblance of a Fig; this is of two kinds, one hard and round; the other ſoft and flat: Out of the hard iſſues a very ſmall quantity of glutinous Matter; out of the Moiſt proceeds a greater quantity, and of an ill Smell: Theſe Ulcers grow in thoſe patts only which are covered with Hair; the hard and round chiefly in the Beard, the moiſt for the moſt part in the Scalp.
list.label: Syderatio,
list.item: ſee Apoplexia.
list.label: Symbebecota,
list.item: are Accidents which happen to thoſe that are well, to diſtinguiſh 'em from Symptoms which happen in Diſeaſes.
list.label: Symmetria,
list.item: is a good Temper.
list.label: Sympaſma,
list.item: ſee Phaenigmus.
list.label: Sympepſis,
list.item: is a Coction of thoſe Humors which are growing into an Impoſthume.
list.label: Symphyſis,
list.item: is the Joining of two Bones of which neither has a proper diſtinct Motion: This is either without any Medium, or elſe with it, as with a Cartilage or Griſle, a Ligament or Fleſh.
list.label: Symptoma,
list.item: is a preternatural Diſpoſition of the Body occaſioned by ſome Diſeaſe: This is either a Diſeaſe cauſed by another Diſeaſe; or elſe the Cauſe of a Diſeaſe proceeding from another Diſeaſe; or elſe ſimply a Symptome: This laſt is either ſome Action of the Body hindred or diſturb'd, ſome fault of the Excrement, or change of the natural Temper.
list.label: Synactica,
list.item: are Medicines that contract any part.
list.label: Synaitia,
list.item: ſee Continens cauſa.
list.label: Synanche,
list.item: is a ſort of Squinancy, which quite ſtops the Breath; or a preternatural Inflammation of the Muſcles of the Jaws.
list.label: Synarthroſis,
list.item: is a joyning of Bones by a Griſle.
is the joyning of Bones by a Griſle.
list.label: Synchyſis,
list.item: is a preternatural Confuſion of the Blood or Humors in the Eye.
list.label: Syncope,
list.item: is a ſudden Proſtration or Swouning with a very weak or no Pulſe, and a Depravation of Senſe and Motion.
list.label: Syncritica,
list.item: are relaxing Medicines.
list.label: Syndeſmus,
list.item: ſee Ligamentum.
list.label: Syndrome,
list.item: is a Concurrence of ſeveral Symptoms in the ſame Diſeaſe.
list.label: Synedreuonta,
list.item: are common Symptoms which accompany the Diſeaſe; and yet neither flow from the Nature of the Diſeaſe, nor are neceſſary Concomitants of it; but do notwithſtanding ſignify the Greatneſs, Continuance, &c. of the Diſeaſe.
list.label: Synocha,
list.item: is a continued intermitting Fever; this laſts for many days with a great Heat, ſometimes Putrefaction of the Blood: It is either quotidian, tertian, or quartan.
list.label: Synochos,
list.item: is a continued Fever without any Intermiſſion or Abatement of the Heat, which continues for many days: This is either Simple, or accompanied with Putrefaction.
list.label: Syntaſis,
list.item: is a preternatural Diſtention of the parts.
list.label: Synteretica,
list.item: is that part of Phyſick which gives Rules for the Preſervation of Health.
list.label: Syntexis,
list.item: is a Conſumption and Colliquation of the Body, in which firſt the Fleſh is waſted, and afterward the Subſtance of the more ſolid parts.
list.label: Syntheſis,
list.item: is either the Frame and Structure of the whole Body; or more ſtrictly the Compoſure of the Bones.
list.label: Synulotica,
list.item: ſee Cicatriſantia.
list.label: Syringa, a Syringe,
list.item: is an Inſtrument which is uſed in injecting Liquors into the Fundament, Womb, Ears, &c.
list.label: Syringomata,
list.item: are Chirurgions Knives which they open Fiſtula's with.
list.label: Syringotomia,
list.item: is the Inciſion of the Fiſtula.
list.label: Syringotomus,
list.item: the ſame.
list.label: Syrupus,
list.item: Syrup.
list.label: Syſarcoſis,
list.item: is the connexion of Bones by Fleſh.
list.label: Syſygia,
list.item: is the Natural Temper.
list.label: Syſtema,
list.item: the ſame that Syntheſis.
list.label: Syſtole,
list.item: is the Contraction of the Ventricles of the Heart, whereby the Blood is forcibly driven into the great Artery.

list.head: T.
list.label: TAbella,
list.item: is a ſolid Medicine taken inwardly, made of Powder, and three or four times as much Sugar, diſſolved in a convenient Liquor, boiled to the Conſiſtence of a Syrup, and made into little round Cakes upon a Marble-Stone.
list.label: Tabes,
list.item: ſee Atrophia.
list.label: Tabes dorſalis,
list.item: a Conſumption in the ſpinal Marrow, moſt incident to Lechers, and freſh Bride-grooms; they are without a Fever, eat well, and melt or conſume away: If you ask one in this Diſeaſe an account of himſelf, he will tell you, that there ſeem ſo many Piſmires to fall from his Head down upon his ſpinal Marrow; when he eaſes Nature either by Urine or Stool, there flows thin liquid Seed plentifully; nor can he generate, but when he ſleeps, whether it be with his Wife or no; he has laſcivious Dreams. When he goes or runs any way, but eſpecially up à ſteep place, he grows weak and ſhort breathed, his Head is heavy, and his Ears tingle: So in progreſs of Time being taken with violent Fevers; he dies of a Fever called Lipyria, wherein the external Parts are cold, and the internal burn at the ſame time.
list.label: Tabula,
list.item: ſee Tabella & Morſuli.
list.label: Tabum,
list.item: is a thin ſort of Matter that comes from an ill Ulcer.
list.label: Tactus,
list.item:
the Touch, is a Senſe whereby the tactile Qualities of Bodies are offered to the common Senſory (and there perceived) by
the different motion of Nerves diffuſed through the whole Body, the Skin being intermediate: Or Touch is the Senſe of a thing touched, offered to the common Senſory by the Nerves, the Skin being intermediate, and there perceived.
list.label: Talpa,
list.item: is a Tumor, ſo called, becauſe that as a Mole (in Latine Talpa) creeps under ground; ſo this feeds upon the Scull under the Skin: It may be referred to the Species of Atheromas; which ſee.
list.label: Talparia,
list.item: the ſame that Talpa.
list.label: Talus,
list.item: ſee Aſtragalus.
list.label: Taraxis,
list.item: is a Perturbation of the Humours of the Eye, the Stomach, or the Entrails.
list.label: Tarſus,
list.item: is a cartilaginous Extremity of the Eye-lids, whence the Hairs ſpring, called Cilium. Alſo eight backward Bones of the Foot, ordered like Grates.
list.label: Tecmarſis,
list.item: is a Conjecture at Diſeaſes.
list.label: Telephium,
list.item: is the ſame Ulcer with Chironia, which ſee; it is ſo called from Telephus, who was a long time troubled with this Diſeaſe.
list.label: Temperamentum, Temperament,
list.item: is a Quality that reſults from the Union and Mixture of Elements: See Craſis.
list.label: Temperies,
list.item: ſee Craſis.
list.label: Tempus, the Temple,
list.item: is a lateral part of the Scull in the middle betwixt the Ears and Eyes, where Cephalick Plaiſters are applied for the Tooth-ach, and Head-ach.
list.label: Tendo, a Tendon,
list.item:
is a ſimilar nervous part annexed to Muſcles and Bones, whereby the voluntary Motion of the Members is chiefly
performed: The generality of Chirurgeons ſcarce ever diſtinguiſh betwixt a Tendon and a Nerve.
list.label: Teneſmus, Tenaſmus,
list.item: is a continual Deſire of going to Stool, yet attended with an Inability of doing any thing, but bloody ſlimy Matter.
list.label: Tentigo,
list.item: ſee Priapiſmus.
list.label: Terebrum,
list.item: ſee Modiolus.
list.label: Teredum,
list.item: the ſame that Caries.
list.label: Teretrum,
list.item: ſee Modiolus.
list.label: Tergum,
list.item: ſee Dorſum.
list.label: Terminthus,
list.item: is a ſwelling in the Thighs with a black Pimple at the top, as big as the Fruit of the Turpentine-tree.
list.label: Terra mortua,
list.item: is the earthy part that remains after Elixivation, deſtitute of all active efficacious Qualities.
list.label: Tertiana Febris intermittens, a Tertian Ague,
list.item: is an Efferveſcence of the Blood every third day, which with its various Symptoms, comes exactly at a ſet time. The Cauſe of it is Nitro-ſulphureous Blood; and it is either a true Tertian or a ſpurious.
list.label: Teſtes Muliebres,
list.item: ſee Orchis.
list.label: Teſtes viriles,
list.item: Mens Teſticles, conſiſt of ſeveral ſmall Veſſels wherein the Seed is generated: It is covered on the out-ſide with ſeveral Tunicks.
list.label: Teſtes Cerebri,
list.item: are two backward Prominences of the Brain, called Teſtes, from the likeneſs they have to Teſticles: They are bigger in Men than in Brutes.
list.label: Teſtudo Cerebri,
list.item: ſee Fornix.
list.label: Teſtudo,
list.item: is a ſoft, large Swelling, or not very hard, in the Head, broad, in form of an Arch or Tortoiſe, from which Reſemblance it takes its Name. At the beginning it grows like a Cheſt-nut, afterwards like an Egg, wherein is contained a ſoft Matter clothed with a certain Tunick (whence ſome refer this ſort of Tumour to Meliceres, which ſee) which ſticks ſo cloſe to the Scull, that many times it infects and corrupts it.
list.label: Tetanus,
list.item: is a conſtant Contraction, whereby a Limb grows rigid and inflexible. The Cauſe of it is, ſometimes a Relaxation or Palſy in ſome other Muſcles, which when they are relaxed, the oppoſite Muſcles act too ſtrongly, ſo that they draw the part wholly to themſelves, which ought to conſiſt as it were in an Aequilibrium betwixt both: Yet ſometimes ſuch a permanent Contraction may proceed, from the Tendons being loaded and obſtructed with ſerous Matter, which thereupon grow rigid and ſtiff: This Diſtemper is frequent in the Scurvies, that the Patient can extend neither Joint nor Limb: The Tendons in the Back are ſometimes contracted into a round globular Form, which by reaſon of ſuch an Afflux of Humours upon them, draw the Bones out of their due place, and cauſe an hunched Back, or a ſtooping and bending of it: It is uſually diſtinguiſhed into Ʋniverſal, of which there are three ſorts, Emproſthotonos, Opiſthotonos, and Tetanos, properly ſo called; and Particular, which reſpects a certain Member, or a particular Joint.
list.label: Tetrapharmacum,
list.item: is a Medicine conſiſting of four Ingredients, as Ʋnguentum Baſilicum.
list.label: Theorema,
list.item: ſee Theoria.
list.label: Theoretica,
list.item: ſee Theoria.
list.label: Theoria,
list.item: is the ſpeculative part of Phyſick; whence Theorema, a Speculation, and Theoretica, thoſe things which belong to the ſpeculative part of Phyſick.
list.label: Therapeutica,
list.item: is that part of Phyſick which delivers the Method of Healing.
list.label: Theriaca,
list.item: Triacle, is a Medicine that expels Poyſon.
list.label: Therioma,
list.item: is a wild cruel Ulcer, like Carcinoma, which ſee.
list.label: Thermae,
list.item: are natural Baths.
list.label: Thermantica,
list.item: are healing Medicines.
list.label: Therminthus,
list.item: ſee Terminthus.
list.label: Thermomethron,
list.item: is natural Heat, which is perceived by the Pulſes.
list.label: Thlipſis,
list.item: is a Compreſſion of Veſſels.
list.label: Thorax, or medius Venter, the Cheſt,
list.item: is all that Cavity which is circumſcribed above by the Neck-bones, below by the Diaphragme, before by the Breaſt-bone, behind by the Back-bones, on the ſides by the Ribs; it is of an Oval Figure, contains the Heart and Lungs, and is covered on the inſide with a Membrane called Pleura. Hippocrates and Ariſtotle took all that ſpace from the Neck-bone to the very Secrets, both the middle and lowermoſt Cavity, for the Thorax.
list.label: Thorexis,
list.item: is the drinking of a generous Wine, which warms the Breaſt.
list.label: Thrombus,
list.item: is the Coagulation of Blood or Milk into Clots or Cluſters.
list.label: Thymiama,
list.item: ſee Suffitus.
list.label: Thymus,
list.item: is a Glandule in the Throat, which ſeparates the watery Humour, called Lympha, from the Blood, and empties it by the Lymphatick Veſſels. It is alſo a fleſhy Tumour that hangs upon the Body like a Wart, of a Colour like the Flower of Time, whence it has its Name.
list.label: Thyroarytaenoides,
list.item: is a pair of Muſcles that proceed from the Cartilage called Scutiformis, and extending themſelves forward to the Sides of the Arytaenoides (the fourth and fifth part of the Larynx) ſerve to contract and cloſe the opening of the Larynx.
list.label: Thyroidaeae Glandulae,
list.item: are two, of a viſcous, ſolid, bloody Subſtance, wonderfully adorned with Veſſels of all ſorts, and hard Membranes, almoſt of the bigneſs and ſhape of an Hen's Egg, ſituate about the lower ſeat of the Larynx, at the ſides of the Cartilages of the Thorax, Cricoides, and ſome firſt rings of the Wind-Pipe, upon which Parts they immediately lye; yet ſo as they may be eaſily ſeparated, unleſs where they ſtick ſomething obſtinately, about the beginning and the end; Nature has placed them in thoſe parts, that they may warm them when cold, receive ſuperfluous Moiſture, and contribute to the Ornament of the Neck.
list.label: Thyroides,
list.item: is the Cartilage, called Scutiformis, of the Larynx: Alſo the Hole of the Os pubis.
list.label: Tibia, the Leg,
list.item:
is the part betwixt the Knee and the Ancle. It conſiſts of two Bones: One
outward, called Focile minus; another Inward and larger, which has uſurped the Name of the whole, and is called Tibia, Focile majus others call it, & Canna major. The upper end has a Proceſs which is received by a Cavity in the Thigh, and two oblong Cavities to admit the Heads of the Thigh-bone, the Depth of which Cavities is encreaſed by a Cartilage that is annexed thereunto by Ligaments: This Cartilage is movable, ſoft, ſlippery, moiſtened with an unctuous Humour, thick in its Circumference, and ſmaller towards the Center, whence it is called Lunata, made like an Half-moon; there are rugged ſharp Ligaments before, which Encreaſe the Lunary Cartilages. The fore part, which is acute and long, is called Spina: There is below a prominent and gibbous Proceſs in the inner ſide, nigh the Foot, and is called Malleolus externus; one of the Ankle-bones.
list.label: Tinctura, a Tincture, or Elixir,
list.item: is the Extraction of the Colour, Quality, and Strength of any thing.
list.label: Tinea,
list.item:
if running Sores in the Head full of little Holes, called Achores, continue long, or be too ſlowly or ill cured, they grow into Tineas, cruſty ſtinking Ulcers of the Head, which gnaw and conſume its Skin; therefore it is deſervedly reckoned amongſt the Diſeaſes of Children, but when they are a little grown; for tho Adult Perſons are ſometimes troubled with this Diſeaſe, yet they contracted the Rudiments and Seeds of it in their Infancy. It is called Tinea, which ſignifies a Moth, from thoſe little Worms which eat and conſume Clothes; becauſe
thoſe Ulcers prey upon the Skin of the Head, as thoſe Animals upon Clothes. What the Greeks called this Diſtemper is not ſo obvious.
list.label: Tinnitus Aurium,
list.item: is a certain Buzzing or tingling in the Ears, proceeding from Obſtruction, or ſomething that irritates the Ear, whereby the Air that is ſhut up is continually moved by the beating of the Arteries, and the Drum of the Ear is lightly verberated, whence ariſes a Buzzing and Noiſe.
list.label: Tometica,
list.item: the ſame that Attenuantia.
list.label: Tomotocia,
list.item: the ſame that Hyſterotomia.
list.label: Tonica,
list.item: are thoſe things which being externally applied to and rubb'd into the Limbs, ſtrengthen the Nerves and Tendons.
list.label: Tonotica,
list.item: the ſame that Tonica.
list.label: Tonicus,
list.item: the ſame that Tetanus.
list.label: Tonſillae,
list.item: ſee Pariſthmia.
list.label: Tophus,
list.item: is a ſtony Concretion in any part.
list.label: Topica,
list.item: are Medicines applied outwardly, as a Plaiſter, Cataplaſm, &c.
list.label: Topinaria,
list.item: the ſame that Talpa.
list.label: Torcular Herophili,
list.item: is that place where the four Cavities of the thick Skin of the Brain are joyned.
list.label: Tormina alvi,
list.item: the ſame that Colica Paſſio.
list.label: Toxica,
list.item: are poyſonous Medicaments, wherewith Barbarians uſe to anoint their Arrows.
list.label: Trachea,
list.item: the ſame that aſpera Arteria.
list.label: Trachoma,
list.item: is a Scab, or Aſperity of the inner part of the Eye-lid.
list.label: Trageae,
list.item:
differ not from Powders, but that the Ingredients whereof they are prepared, are
not beat ſo ſmall: And they are applied externally to the Body, either put to or reſolved into Smoak, or they are put into a Linnen Bag, and then into Wine or other Liquor, that they may communicate their Strength and Qualities to it. Yet ſometimes they are compounded of ſome ſort of Antidotes, or Counter-poiſons, and other odoriferous things, and of ſimple Medicines reduced into a Powder, with an Addition of Sugar. In the making theſe, they commonly take one Ounce of Sugar to every Dram of Ingredient, eſpecially thoſe which are bitter and unpleaſant.
list.label: Tragema,
list.item: the ſame that Tragaea.
list.label: Tragus,
list.item: is the extream Brim of the Ear.
list.label: Traulus and Traulotes,
list.item: is a Stammering, or fault in pronouncing the Letters L and R.
list.label: Trauma,
list.item: ſee Troma.
list.label: Traumatica,
list.item: are thoſe things, which being taken in Decoctions and Potions, fetch the ſerous and ſharp Humours out of the Body, and ſo attenuate the Blood, that it may be conveniently driven to the wounded, broken, or bruiſed parts.
list.label: Tremor,
list.item: ſee Tromos.
list.label: Trepanum,
list.item: the ſame that Modiolus.
list.label: Triangulare oſſiculum, the triangular little Bone,
list.item: is that which is placed betwixt the Suture called Lambdoides, and another called Sagittalis; which they ſay conduces too to the Falling-Sickneſs.
list.label: Trichiaſis,
list.item: the ſame that Phalangoſis: Alſo hairy Urine, ſuch as by reaſon of pituitous Humours Hairs ſeem to ſwim in.
list.label: Tricongius,
list.item: is a Meaſure that contains eighteen Sextaries, a Sextary being about a Pint and an half.
list.label: Triens,
list.item: is the Third part of a phyſical Pound, containing three Ounces.
list.label: Tripſis,
list.item: is Contrition, or Contuſion.
list.label: Triſmus,
list.item: is the grinding of the Teeth, or a Convulſion of a Muſcle of the Temples, whereby the Teeth gnaſh whether one will or no.
list.label: Tritaeophyes,
list.item: is an Ague that comes every Third day.
list.label: Tritaeus,
list.item: the ſame that Febris Tertiana intermittens.
list.label: Trituratio,
list.item: is a Pounding, whereby Medicines are reduced to Powder, that they may be the better mixed.
list.label: Trochanter,
list.item: the ſame that Rotator.
list.label: Trochiſci, Trochies,
list.item: are round marked things made of Pouders, mixed with viſcous Extracts and made up into Paſte, and then into round little Bodies, which are to be dried up in the Shade: They are called alſo Paſtilli.
list.label: Trochlea,
list.item: the ſame that Bathmis.
list.label: Trochlearis,
list.item: is the upper, or greater oblique Muſcle of the Eye.
list.label: Troma,
list.item: is a Wound from an external Cauſe.
list.label: Tromboſis,
list.item: is a Coagulation of Milk or Blood in Human Bodies.
list.label: Tromos,
list.item: is a Trembling, or a Depravation of the voluntary Motion of Members.
list.label: Tryſmus,
list.item: ſee Triſmus.
list.label: Tubae Fallopianae,
list.item:
are two ſlender Paſſages, proceeding from the Womb, which when they are a little removed from it, grow gradually wider;
they have large Holes or Orifices, which almoſt lye ſhut, the extream Edges falling flat; yet if they be diligently opened and dilated, they repreſent the extream Orifice of a brazen Pipe. Their Uſe is to receive the Eggs from the Teſticles and carry them into the Womb, according to the excellent R. de Graaf. the Truth whereof is evident from the Inſpection of Rabits diſſected.
list.label: Tubercula,
list.item: the ſame that Phymata.
list.label: Tulus,
list.item: the ſame that Callus.
list.label: Tumor, Swelling,
list.item: is when the parts of humane Bodies are enlarged and extended beyond their due Proportion, ſo that they cannot perform their Operations.
list.label: Tunica,
list.item: the ſame that Membrana.
list.label: Tunica retiformis,
list.item: ſee Retina and Amphiblestroides.
list.label: Turunda,
list.item: the ſame that Turundula.
list.label: Turundula,
list.item: ſignifies a Tent put into Wounds or Ulcers.
list.label: Tuſſis, a Cough,
list.item: is a vehement Efflation of the Breaſt, whereby that which is offenſive to the Organs of Breathing is expelled by the Force of the Air.
list.label: Tympanias,
list.item: the ſame that Tympanites.
list.label: Tympanites, Tympanias, Aqua intercus ſicca, a Tympany,
list.item:
is a fixed, conſtant, equable, hard, reſiſting Tumour of the Abdomen, which, being beat, ſounds: It proceeds from a ſtretching Inflaation of the parts, and of the membranaceous Bowels, whoſe Fibres are too much ſwoln with Animal Spirits, and hindred from receeding by the nervous Juice which obſtructs the
Paſſage; to which Diſtemper there is conſequently added, as the Complement of all, an abundance of flatulent Matter in the places that are empty.
list.label: Tympanum, the Drum of the Ear,
list.item: is a ſmall, thin, orbicular, tranſparent Membrane, ſtretched over the Cavity of the inner part of the Ear, which contains the natural congenite Air: Its Uſe is Hearing. There is alſo a Cavity in the Ear, called Concha.
list.label: Typhodes,
list.item: is a ſymptomatical, continued, burning Fever; as if it were from the Inflammation of the Bowels.
list.label: Typhomania,
list.item: is a Delirium with a Phrenſy, and a Lethargy.
list.label: Typhonia,
list.item: the ſame.
list.label: Typus, or Periodus and Circuitus,
list.item: is an Order of Fevers, conſiſting of Intenſion and Remiſſion, or encreaſing and decreaſing.
list.label: Tyria,
list.item: the fame that Ophiaſis.
list.label: Tyroides,
list.item: ſee Thyroides.
list.label: Tyroſis,
list.item: is when Milk which is eaten curdles into a Subſtance like Cheeſe.

list.head: V.
list.label: VAcuatio,
list.item: ſee Evacuatio.
list.label: Vacui dies,
list.item: are thoſe Days wherein an imperfect and ill Criſis frequently happens; and thoſe are 6, 8, 10, 12, 16, 18. to which ſome add, 22, 23, 25, 29, 30, 32, 33, 35, 38, 39. theſe are called medicinal Days, becauſe Medicines may be given on them.
list.label: Vagina uteri,
list.item: it is called alſo Matrix, Ʋteri Oſtium, Ʋteri Cervix, is that Paſſage in which a Man's Yard is ſheathed as it were in Coition; it is placed in the Hypogaſtrium, and is of an oblong Figure, and of different Magnitude according to the Age of the Woman, and her Uſe of Men; its upper part is as thick as the breadth of a Straw, but the lower twice or thrice as thick again: it is about as broad as the Gut Rectum, nervous and wrinkled within: It is perforated with a great many little Pores, eſpecially in the lower part, about the end of the urinary Paſſage.
list.label: Vaginalis tunica,
list.item: ſee Elythroides.
list.label: Valetudo,
list.item: is either a good or ill Diſpoſition of the Parts of the Body.
list.label: Valvulae,
list.item:
are little thin Membranes in Veſſels or Fibres, like Folding-doors as it were; they have received different Names, according to the Diverſity of their Figuration, as Sigmoides, like the Letter Sigma, Semilunares, like an Halſmoon, &c. They are found in Veins, Arteries, Lymphatick and Lacteal Veſſels, and in muſculous Fibres, which were firſt diſcovered by our
Curioſity, and of which we have diſcourſed in a particular Tract: The Uſe of them is to hinder the Blood and other Liquors, from returning the ſame way they came.
list.label: Valvulae, Valves,
list.item: are alſo found in the Inteſtines, in the ſmall and great Guts, eſpecially in the Jejunum, and about the beginning of the Ileum, which are called Semi-circular from their Figure. Theſe Valves or Folds grow more and more oblique by little and little the nearer you come to the Ileum, and at the beginning of the Ileum they are leſs oblique than farther on. In like manner near the end of the Jejunum, they are gradually more and more diſtant from one another; and ſo in the Ileum too. At the beginning and in the middle of the Jejunum, they are ſcarce diſtant half a Thumbs breadth; in the Ileum a whole Thumbs breadth and more. They yield a little if thruſt with your Finger, and move here and there: At the beginning of the Colon there is a fleſhy and circular Valve, beſides ſeveral others in that Gut. The Uſe of them is to ſtop the Meat a little, that it may be the better fermented, the Chyle diſtributed, the adjacent Parts be cheriſhed with Heat, and laſtly, that it aſcends not again.
list.label: Vaporarium,
list.item: is when the Patient does not ſit in Liquor, but receives Vapours through an Hole, under which there is placed a Pot full of appoſite and boyling hot Ingredients, which cooling, freſh Matter is added.
list.label: Varicoſum corpus,
list.item: is that Contexture of Spermatick Veſſels which enters the Teſticles.
list.label: Variolae,
list.item: the ſmall Pox, conſiſts in a contagious Diſorder of the Blood, contracted from the Air, or otherwiſe; accompanied with a continued wandring Fever, which ſometimes increaſes, ſometimes decreaſes, with a Pain in the Head and Loins, Anixety and Inquietude, and with a breaking forth of Pimples or Wheals, which ſwell and ſuppurate. The famous Willis attributes the Cauſe of this Diſtemper to ſome filthy and fermentative Matter, which is communicated to the Faetus, together with the Nouriſhment, from the Womb; but how this can hold in Adult Perſons, whoſe Blood has undergone ſo many Alterations, I could never yet underſtand from his Writings. It ſeems rather to conſiſt in a depraved Temperature of Air, with a peculiar Diſpoſition of the Blood and the nervous Juice towards this Diſtemper. This poyſonous Quality of the Air firſt infects the nervous Juice (whence proceeds the Pain of the Head and Loins) wherewith the Blood boils and ferments, and parts into little Pieces or Clots, which in the Courſe of Circulation ſtick to the outward Parts, and to the inner Viſcera too; after a while they grow ripe and ſuppurate.
list.label: Varix,
list.item: ſee Cirſos.
list.label: Varus,
list.item: ſee Jonthus.
list.label: Vas breve,
list.item: ſee Breve vas.
list.label: Vaſa, the Veſſels,
list.item: are Cavities through which the Liquors of the Body paſs, as a Vein, an Artery, lymphatick Veſſels, the Ductus that conveys the Chyle, and thoſe of the Spittle.
list.label: Vaſa lactea,
list.item: the Milky Veſſels, in the Meſentery, they which reach from the Guts, eſpecially the ſmall Guts, to the Glandules in the Meſentery, are ſaid to be of the Firſt ſort; and they which reach from thoſe Glandules to the Bag that carries the Chyle, are of the Second ſort. Their Uſe is to convey the Chyle from the Guts to the little Bag that holds the Chyle, and thence to the Ductus, which conveys it along the Thorax. Aſellius was the firſt who diſcovered them, and the dextrous F. Ruiſchius afterwards diſcovered Valves in them.
list.label: Vaſa Lymphatica,
list.item: ſee Venae Lymphaticae.
list.label: Vena, a Vein,
list.item: the Species of them are the Vena cava, the Vena portae, the lymphatick and milky Veins. Arteries are ſometimes taken for Veins. They conſiſt of four Tunicks, a nervous, a glandulous, a muſcular, and a membranaceous one. The Branches of the Vena cava above the Heart, are called Jugular Veins, which go towards the Head; they which go towards the Arms, are called Axillary; that about the Heart Coronary; in the Lungs Pulmonary; in the Liver Hepatick, or Liver-Vein; in the Diaphragme Phrenica; in the Thighs Crural; in the Reins Emulgent; and ſo from its various Ramification, it is variouſly denominated.
list.label: Vena portae,
list.item: is only in the Abdomen, and extends its Roots to the Liver, Spleen, Ventricle, Meſentery, Inteſtines, Pancreas, Cawl, &c. The Office of the Vena cava and portae, is, to convey the Blood that is more than what ſeryes for Nouriſhment, to the Liver, or Heart, or Lungs.
list.label: Venae Lymphaticae,
list.item: the Lymphatick Veins, receive the Lympha from the conglobated Glandules, and diſcharge themſelves either into the Sanguinary Veins, or into the Receptacle of the Chyle.
list.label: Venae lacteae,
list.item: ſee Vaſa lactea.
list.label: Venae ſectio,
list.item: is the Opening of a Vein, which is either for Evacuation, or to derive the Blood to another part, &c. In Bleeding reſpect muſt always be had to the Strength of the Perſon. There never ought to be taken away above a Pound; but the better way is, to take away firſt ſix or eight Ounces, and if Occaſion require, to repeat the Operation. A Vein is to be cut according to the length of the Fibres, and not Acroſs or Traverſe.
list.label: Veneris OEſtrum,
list.item: the ſame that Clitoris.
list.label: Venter infimus,
list.item: ſee Hypogaſtrium.
list.label: Ventoſa,
list.item: ſee Cucurbitula.
list.label: Ventres,
list.item: ſee Cavitates.
list.label: Ventriculus,
list.item: the Stomach, is a membranous Bowel in the Abdomen, under the Diaphragme, betwixt the Liver and the Spleen, conſiſting of four Tunicks; a nervous, fibrous, glandulous, and membranous one: It has two Orifices, one on the Right-hand, called Pylorus or Janitor, whereat the Meat is ſent out into the Guts; another on the Left-hand, at which the Meat enters: Its Office is to concoct or ferment the Meat; it is called alſo Stomachus and Aqualiculus.
list.label: Ventriculi cerebri,
list.item:
the Ventricles of the Brain, are four; the Uſe of them is to receive the ſerous Humours, and to bring them by the Pelvis
to the Pituitary Glandule; or into the Proceſſus mammillares by the Os cribriforme to the Noſtrils. They are nothing but Complications of the Brain, which happened there as 'twere by accident.
list.label: Ventriculi cordis,
list.item: the Ventricles of the Heart, are two; the firſt or Right Ventricle receives the Blood from the Vena cava, and ſends it to the Lungs; the Left receives the Blood from the Lungs, and ſends it through the whole Body by the Arteria Aorta: In the Syſtole or Contraction of the Ventricles the Blood is ſent out: In the Diaſtole or Dilatation it is let into the Heart: Yet others explain it on the contrary, becauſe they underſtand not Greek.
list.label: Vermes,
list.item: ſee Lumbrici.
list.label: Vermiformis proceſſus,
list.item: is the Prominence of the Cerebellum, ſo called from its ſhape.
list.label: Vertebra,
list.item: ſee Spondylus.
list.label: Vertigo,
list.item: ſee Scotomia.
list.label: Verrucae, Warts,
list.item: are a ſort of Tubercula; they are called alſo Porri, becauſe if you look into the tops of them, they ſeem to reſemble the Capillaments, or little Threds of Onyons: They are an hard, high, callous, little Tuberculum, or Swelling, which break out of the Skin, and breed in any part of the Body.
list.label: Vertex,
list.item: the Crown of the Head, is the gibbous middle part of the fore and back part of the Head.
list.label: Veſica, the Bladder,
list.item: is an hollow membranaceous Part, wherein any Liquor that is to be excerned, is contained; as the Bladder that contains the Urine, the Gall, the Seed.
list.label: Veſica, deſtillatoria,
list.item: is a Brazen or Copper Veſſel, which contains any thing that is to be deſtilled.
list.label: Veſicatoria,
list.item: are Medicines which act upon and rarify the Spirits and ſerous Particles, gather them betwixt the Skin and Cuticula, the thin fine Skin, and conſequently ſeparate them, and raiſe little Bladers full of ſerous Matter.
list.label: Veſicula fellis,
list.item: ſee Folliculus fellis.
list.label: Veſpertilionum alae, Bats Wings,
list.item: are two broad membranous Ligaments, on each ſide one, wherewith the bottom of the Womb is looſely tied to the Bones of the Flank. Aretaeus likens them to Bats-wings.
list.label: Veternus,
list.item: ſee Lethargus.
list.label: Vibex,
list.item: ſee Enchymoma.
list.label: Victus ratio,
list.item: is a way Living, whereby Health is preſerved, and Diſeaſes repelled by things convenient: It conſiſts in the Uſe of things called non Naturales, not natural (which ſee in their place;) and it is in Diſeaſes threefold, thick, moderate, thin; the thin is again either ſimply thin, more thin, or the thinneſt of all.
list.label: Vigilia, Waking,
list.item: is an Agitation and Expanſion of animal Spirits in the Pores of the Brain, whereby the Motions of Objects are eaſily repreſented to the common Senſory by the external Organs; which Spirits if they be too much expanded and agitated, they cauſe an obſtinate long Wakening.
list.label: Vigor Morbi,
list.item: ſee Acme.
list.label: Vinum Cos,
list.item: is a Wine of good Colour, Smell, and Taſte.
list.label: Vinum Hypocraticum,
list.item: is a Wine wherein Sugar and Spices have been infuſed, and is afterwards ſtrained through a Bag, which they call Manica Hypocratis, which ſee.
list.label: Vinum Medicatum,
list.item: is a Wine wherein Medicines have been infuſed for the uſe of ſick People.
list.label: Virga,
list.item: ſee Penis.
list.label: Virginale clauſtrum,
list.item: ſee Hymen.
list.label: Viſcera,
list.item: are Organs contained in the three great Cavities of the Body: They are called alſo Exta and Interranea.
list.label: Viſus, Sight,
list.item: is a Sence whereby Light and Colours, are perceived from the Motion of ſubtile Matter upon the Tunica retina of the Eye.
list.label: Vitalis facultas,
list.item: the Vital Faculty, is an Action whereby a Man lives, which is performed, whether we deſign it or no; ſuch are the Motions of the Heart, Reſpiration, Nutrition, &c. It depends chiefly upon the Cerebellum. It is the ſame with Natural Faculty, tho the Ancients diſtinguiſhed them, placing the Natural in the Liver, and the vital in the Heart.
